review_text: Buggy, shallow and obnoxious are the three words I'd use to describe this DLC. The culture system is the only worthwhile part but that only makes up a small portion of the content - say around 1/3. So my recommendation is to wait until you can get this for 1/3 the price. By then maybe the bugs will be fixed.

I was holding off on reviewing this until the first patch, and now that it has released I can safely say that this is a good dlc. Whilst slightly overpriced, the content is great and adds a lot to the game and makes it a lot more interesting to play. After the most recent patch most if not all major bugs have been fixed and the lighting looks better, so there isn't really much to complain about. If you're short on money I'd hold off on this because it isn't essential and quite expensive, but overall I would recommend this for people who enjoy the role-playing aspect of CK3.

I just know that the lion's share of features in this expansion were put into the base game [i]completely for free[/i] instead of put behind the paywall, and if we're all honest with ourselves we'll admit we know that sort of good behavior will stop happening if it isn't financially rewarded.

I got a couple dozen more hours out of this game playing around with the new stuff added, and that's worth 30 bucks to me.

This is one of the best expansion in CK series.
Some people are disappointed that it doesn’t offer much when it comes to GSG addition.
But IMHO CKIII is the best RPG ever created by far along with being a mediocre GSG.
So adding more RP elements is the best thing that can happen in this game.
I wouldn’t complain if Fallout New Vegas if it got a DLC that improve it’s RP elements with multiple choices and good stories rather than getting something that add to the FPS mode like a coop survival or something else.
CK series is primary an RPG and it arguably the best but objectively one of the best.

Ozymannaz review is spot on - the Royal Court itself is quite lacklustre, Paradox need to do a huge free update with lots more events for the Royal Court quickly because events repeat themselves painfully often, it seems like at least will pop up in two consecutive Royal Court event. All the events seem to cost money too, so you might end up specifically avoiding the Royal Court if you who need that money for war or building. The other downside is that it places heavy demands on your machine for laptops, the frame-rate becomes is jerky in a way it doesn't for the rest of the game.

I'm not going to mention the price, it is what it is - but some cool things for Paradox to put in: Put in a lot more Royal Court events, it seems like there is more variety from a feast or hunt that the Royal Court, and make some of the events giving you money; also when you equip artefacts then they should appear on you character, even if it's just generic.

This is a good expansion for CK3, building on the already strong basis of the game. You can see how in future years it will be a vital element of the CK3 experience. It really plays to CK3's strengths of role-playing and helps make the mid game more interesting, giving the player new goals and opportunities to engage in the world you are building. However if you are on the fence about this DLC, it may be worth waiting until you see it on sale. At the time of writing (1 month after release) there are still some fairly major bugs that have not been patched, and I will admit that the price is fairly steep for what it is. That said, I've had a lot of fun with it and can't wait to see how future DLC's and flavor packs expand on the excellent mechanics introduced by Royal Court. 
Update: Just a day after writing this review a fairly big patch dropped, fixed a lot of my issues with the update!
Es verdad que tiene bugs, por ahora, ya lo están arreglando, pero creo que es un dlc interesante con mucho trabajo en sima
Great dlc, not so much impact on "core gameplay" but still fun

The mechanics introduced in this game, add to the complexity of the game....... but not in a good way, this DLC simply adds ways to get more mana, rather than actually investing the player to have more agency. Sad to see my favorite game series to devolve into a cheap mobile port, toned for the casual gamer, instead of the hardcore strategy fans that made ck2 what it became in its apex. 

What the future of the game series seems to be is more mana based economy rather than the meaningful interaction that previous paradox titles offered the new UI is at best clumsy, this applies to this DLC also. The Court mechanics are hidden behind multitute of menus and offer very little for its price. The new cultural mechanics could be intresting but since they as well are at best shallow, like the confusing tiered combat system only add to the confusion. 

For those loved Ck2 or hardcore strategy, I recommend giving this a miss or at least more time to mature. Right now Ck3 is very shallow in every aspect. For new players and those who enjoy a more casual experience, this DLC offers more immersion and some new features.. but still it is not worth the price.

DLC is good but ppl complain about the price. I dont feel i payed too much.
If you are a fan of the game, you probably own the DLC already and if not buy it, full price or not.

If you are more casual about it all, wait till a sale, in any case, what is included in the DLC is worth it in my eyes, i enjoy the additions.

The changes to culture, the reintroduction of artifacts, and the addition of a new 3D court that players can utilise are all very welcome additions that I would mark as being positive to the game, but it's[b] laughably [/b] overpriced. 

It's always been well known that Paradox love their expensive DLCs, but come on. Glad to know that the 15+ DLCs this game will inevitably have will all cost the same price or more than some other modern game releases. 

Might as well avoid this Paradox DLC wagon - it appears that it may just be the greediest one yet.

See quite a few people hating on Royal Court and as someone who has played a bit of ck3 thought I would give my opinion. The DLC has its flaws, and, I agree, is slightly overpriced. However, I still think for a ck3 fan this DLC is definitely worth it.

Pros: Let's start with the good side of this DLC, which is pretty attractive in my opinion. Firstly, we have the royal court itself. It costs a hella lot of money late game, but I think it's a very good addition to the game: court grandeur seems like a necessary step for getting a leg-up on rival empires late game via getting some decent passive buffs and provides a gold sink for when you're making a bit more than you really need; court positions are interesting and fairly dynamic with some decent buffs (but are a bit too expensive early game); hold court is a feature lots of people dislike due to its staleness but in my opinion adds a few good opportunities for RP and different vassal interactions, and as an extension pay homage and petition liege make playing as a vassal (personally my favourite starting condition) a bit more flavourful; finally, the courtroom itself is pretty cool and provides many opportunities for RP and some passive buffs. Artefacts are less exciting than I would have hoped but, again, provide some alright passive buffs and RP flavour. 
There's also the other main attraction in cultures which I think is an exceedingly good revamp. Cultures feel a lot more dynamic and it forces you to consider cultures more carefully and be more careful of extending your realm into other cultures for reasons other than independence revolts. I think the diverging and hybrid cultures are pretty neat too and, again, give amazing RP opportunities.
Overall, as someone who likes a bit of RP to spice up a run, I think Royal Court excels in making the game much more flavourful, interesting, and dynamic. 

Cons: At the end of the day, the features are much less fleshed out than I would like them to be. The court itself feels a bit barebones when you've played for a while and tbh gets more annoying late game when you have other things to worry about than whoever your court seneschal is. Also, the claim artefact system is extremely annoying in how you often get bombarded with demands for some artefact you forgot that you even had, artefacts too are less interesting than I would have hoped. One more issue that I have is that, due to the new court system and grandeur, kingdoms and empires make much more beneficial alliances than before, which makes sense, but also sabotages the early game because kingdoms and empires at war (England and Byzantium in 1066 to be specific) instantly get incredible alliances and defeat everyone; this especially means that Harold Godwinson wins in every 1066 start, which is cool and all, but gets pretty stale.

Overall: 7/10. Has its flaws for sure and needs a few tweaks but adds a lot of cool new features and is great for those who enjoy RP. Also brings a lot of potential to the modding scene (looking at you AGOT) which is always exciting since the game facilitates modding and has a very good community.

The whole point of the DLC, the royal court itself, is the weakest part of the DLC by far. In addition to just not being very interactive in general, it actively hurts the other actual good parts of the update, like artifacts, by making them intrinsically tied to your courtroom. Court events seem to repeat frequently (I've had a cult trying to find a lost head that's rolled into my castle multiple times on the same ruler) and it's gotten to the point that I'm not even bothering to hold court because the events are too repetitive. These events also seem to exist in an alternative universe - you will have humble, content vassals demanding that you give them something because someone else recently got something similar and now they're jealous, even though the rest of the game is great about keeping internal consistency for these kinds of things. Not only that, but there's just an utter lack of things that use the courtroom anyhow. Weddings, coronations, and other party-like events seem like they would be right at home in the court and might actually give a reason for such a thing to exist. Nope, those are all still tucked away invisibly, only seen through the occasional event.

Furthermore, Paradox justified the price and delays by the fact that they had to have their team learn how to use 3D modeling tools to make the court. Beyond the fact that this is a stupid take (as a consumer, I don't care about time spent, I care about the value I get out of a product), it also seems like an overall wasted effort. You only ever look at the court when there is an event or you're putting in new artifacts. Your court is supposed to dynamically adjust who's in it based on the state your realm is in. Except, again, you never look in your court unless there is a specific reason. Even during holding court, when people take different positions to supposedly help build "immersion" within the event, it doesn't even feel worth it - the text alone does a far better job at allowing me to imagine the scenario in my head. I'm not sure why they felt the need to move away with ck3's basic event system where it simply shows you all characters involved with some expression on their face, as that system both gave you a quick look at who is involved in the event and just enough visualization to go along with the text without trying to do too much. In comparison, I barely know who's involved in court events because the camera is almost always hiding the faces of the actual people that are important to the event, instead showing only their backs. Once again, the major social events that actually would benefit from the court view don't take place there, despite the fact that the royal court trailer uses a wedding as an example of the purpose of the court.

On the other hand, Hybrid Cultures, Cultural Divergence, inspirations, and even the court grandeur mechanics are all pretty great additions. Hybridization and divergence finally allow for dynamic cultural outcomes from either owning large swathes of different cultural territory. Inspirations are alright, although it'd be nice if I, the ruler, could actually make something by myself, like writing my own book rather than making someone else do it for me. Finally, while the 3D royal court is extremely underwhelming for me, I do actually like the mechanical system behind it, wherein you can essentially bribe people to come live with you in return for nice things and how your court and by extension, courtiers, reflect your cultural ethos, with warlike cultures and courts naturally producing more military minded individuals.  That being said, Paradox made it clear the majority of their time and focus was on making the 3D court, which just doesn't bring very much value to the game, and in some cases, actively lowers the value of other things.

In conclusion, there's some really fun ideas that I'm sure modders will make good use of but even the good ideas can't hide the fact that the vast majority of the $30 this DLC costs is tied to a rather useless and underwhelming 3D court. In fact, while it seems like the other mechanics are well-integrated into the base game (such as grandeur affecting feasts and hunts), the courtroom itself seems to exist on its island.

I always go into buying things with an open mind. I like to read the comments to make sure that it is a decent buy and especially with paradox DLC because they have amazed me in the past with a lot of their production. This DLC has a lot of potential, but it is a heaping pile of bugs. They broke the de jure claims for wars in the late game by making it to where you can not complete the war goal. You can only take the king hostage or hope for a random victory. I had all of a kingdom sieged and it still didn't let me take it. Literally broke my empire because of the war because I wanted to make sure I was not crazy. They made it to where dynasty members have claims for literally hundreds of years causing you to get pop-ups and negative opinion penalties every 5 years. They made a huge amount of text and visual bugs for decisions and court pop-ups. Multiplayer is again desyncing. It is just like for every step paradox takes in the forward direction, it is actually not even a step at all and in fact just a pit fall into death. Congrats Paradox, this patch broke the game.

Fix it and as I said, the ideas in here are great ones. I love the concept of culture. I love the concept of regalia. It is a horrid implementation.

The DLC is pretty good, adding more customization for cultures, artifacts, and the headline royal court feature. The actual court adds some much-needed personality and roleplay value to the game. It is especially fun when playing as a small realm, which makes it all the more frustrating that the court is for some reason not available to duke or count-tier rulers. Artifacts are fine, though the various interesting ways to obtain them are especially fun. The best feature of the DLC is the ability to hybridize and diverge cultures, making them much less static and allowing you to adapt your character and realm's culture to your playstyle. This is unfortunately also plagued by characteristically absurd design choices by Paradox, such as hybridization being much easier to do than diverging despite generally conferring far more advantages, and each culture having a static 'ethos' that essentializes them into a specific specialization (nothing dubious at all about the fact that most Arab and Indian cultures are 'spiritual'). 
The pack also includes some nice new music tracks and a very few assets.
So while it's a good DLC, it's not nearly worth the full price (I got it automatically with Royal Edition), since it has less substance than some of the much cheaper CK2 expansions. It also makes you wonder what the development team has been doing for the past year. 
I'd say buy when 50% off, €15 seems a more reasonable price.

Das DLC Royal Court hat ein paar sehr interessante Ansätze. Die grundlegende Idee, durch ausrüstbare Gegenstände und die Hofpolitik mehr Tiefe in das Spiel zu bringen, ist sehr löblich. An der Umsetzung muss jedoch noch gefeilt werden. Items bekommt man zu viel und zu leicht. Ich bin als Graf im Jahre 888 gestartet und nach nicht einmal der hälfte der Spielzeit habe ich legendäre Items, die bei mir im Lager versauern, weil ich keinen Platz mehr habe, sie auszustellen. Die höfische Politik ist am Anfang zwar ganz nett, die Events werden aber schnell redundant. Es gibt einfach zu wenige von ihnen und irgendwann klickt man sich nur noch durch, ohne den Text zu lesen. Auch schade ist, dass man durch Hofämter und Items nicht mehr machen kann, als stupide Boni zu addieren. Schön wäre es, wenn Items oder der Königshof Einfluss auf die Politik hätten. Dafür müsste jedoch erst das relativ eindimensionale Diplomatiesystem überarbeitet werden... Vielleicht ja, beim nächsten DLC. Royal Court benötigt in jedem Fall noch Updates, doch dafür allein würde ich mir nicht die Mühe machen, eine Rezension zu schreiben. Das größte Problem mit diesem DLC ist der unverschämte Preis von 29.99. Selbst wenn die vorgeschlagenen Verbesserungen vorgenommen werden würden, wäre dieses DLC nicht dieses Geld wert. In seinem aktuellen Zustand könnte man 10 Euro verlangen, höchstens! Wartet am besten bis das DlC in einer Steamrabattaktion günstiger wird, wenn ihr es wirklich haben wollt.

Really underwhelming.  Some of the additions like Languages are neat, but the Royal Court feature is yet another example of Paradox bolting on extraneous BS that might have been interesting and engaging had it been baked into the game's foundation.  

It adds a system where you can give yourself little stat boosts by "upgrading" your court once a year, and every five years you can "hold court," e.g. get a few pop-up events at once that are not dissimilar to the ones that pop up on a regular basis).  Yawn.

Royal Court je dobré DLC, avšak má své chyby. Nejvetší chybou je cena, protože 30 euro za DLC, no pardon ale to je prestrelené. Mohu doporucit pouze a jen pro opravdové hardcore fanoušky tématu strategie, nebo fanoušky Crusader Kings serie.
Worth as much as the game. Changed everything for the better.

Look I can see where Royal Court has not been well received, and I have some of the similar complaints, i.e. court system is generic / doesn't seem that important, artifacts are just a token add on reminiscent of grindy dungeon crawlers (I shook my head when I saw the typical colour scheme for rare, common etc artifacts), game seemed incomplete or not worth the money / length of year in development, royal court seems removed from the map experience, blah blah blah. 

But I'm still happy to have purchased it, and for one reason only. The original CK3 is sick and has a lot of potential. Paradox has a pretty good track record with their games and DLCs compared to other companies (i.e. Bethesda, Blizzard), and so they still have my support for the time being. I hope they just use the money to pay their developers to really think about what the next DLC / patch will be,  or even how to update the royal court experience. It seems to me that CK3 is really a character game compared to say trade (Europa), or military (Hearts of Iron), it would be good to see more work done in that field. Even boosting the AI to be more aggressive (i.e in seducing your wife, fucking up your inheritance due to spawning bastards), or more historical moments embedded within the game could be areas of focus?

If you don't have the money, don't get it, the original game is still amazing. I have a comfortable job, and I'm happy to make the investment.

My favorite computer game of all time with Rome Total War 2 coming in a close second. I can play this for hours and love every second of it, literally talking out loud to myself and narrating the events as they unfold to my dog. Big fan.

They delayed this update and it's still riddled with game breaking bugs. 

Basic stuff like council tasks not doing anything, cultural perks not doing anything, etc. I get that the pandemic must have made game development harder, I really do. 

I think CK3 is a brilliant game overall. But some of these bugs in the new update are inexcuseable. Stuff that even in a few hours of testing, even an intermediate player could point out as a problem. 

Paradox, I am begging you, let a handful of people actually test your DLCs before releasing them and you can catch this stuff before releasing broken updates. 

Not to mention that the animated royal court has a much higher spec requirement than the rest of the game, meaning that people who could previously run the game on medium or higher settings now lag like crazy anytime they go to their court. 

Tbh, makes me question the leadership at paradox and makes me concerned for where the game is going in the future. There are tons of people that would test these DLCs for free, but paradox never offers open beta, and this is the result- a cool concept that doesn't work because of easily fixable bugs.
really? you all spent all this time and money making this goofy dlc?
I bought it on a sale, very good content. Don't listen to people that can never be made happy.

Should Royal Court be part of the game? Yes. Should it be a DLC? No. 

Compared to the DLCs of CK2, Royal Court is closer to a flavour pack. It only affects king+ tier rulers and even excludes tribal lords, making Northern and African rulers less desirable to play as. 

The royal court is supposedly intended to make the characters seem more alive through additional interactions with them. Conversely, I find the opposite effect to be the case. Much like the "romance scheme", the characters seem to act or wish for something that is very out of character when it comes to their traits. Such as when I held court and my wife-friend-soulmate came stomping up to my throne in front of my whole court demanding that I grant her the county I had just granted my uncle. An insignificant county of which she had previously had no known relation to, in a duchy of which I was the holder of several other counties I could have granted her instead. Challenging my uncle and steward who had better traits and stats that made him a more competent holder than her, and demanding that I performed an action that would otherwise be considered as tyrannical. It seemed so misplaced and as if the conflict was created just to force a difficult decision, for which there was no good solution, because either one or the other would hate me, or they would dual and either of them would die. As with most of the court decisions that are forced upon the player, they seem misplaced and ruin immersion, and are almost never have a beneficial outcome, meaning, holding court is not something you as a player would like to do and so it does not make gameplay more enjoyable, but on the contrary, it takes away from it. The other court features are interesting enough, but quite minor. 

In conclusion, I think the Royal Court should be part of the game with some tweaking, but I do not think that the content it adds justifies calling it a DLC level expansion and certainly not the price tag. Most of reviews of players I've read that are positive to this "DLC" state that they had already payed for the first expansion, and so they do not care about the value for money. It makes it even worse that this was delayed 8 months, meaning we should probably have seen the second DLC by now if the developers had stayed on schedule. Yes, yes, delays come with excuses, but that is the truth of it. CK3 was released 1.5 years ago and it still feels like half the game CK2 was. The Royal Court feels like it was hyped because the developers made an addition in 3D when they are used to making things in 2D. It's a flashy feature that grows boring after 2 hours of gameplay, because it has no substance and does not feel beneficial to gameplay.

I think Paradox kind of painted themselves into a corner with this DLC, and also were the victims of bad luck.

Crusader Kings II wasn't the most feature-complete game at launch, but every major expansion expanded the world and gameplay in ways that felt monumental - Sword of Islam, the Old Gods, and Rajas of India (not my favourite DLC but it did add a lot of content) hugely changed the game, and some of the more iterative packs like Legacy of Rome, Way of Life, and Conclave fleshed out the game in meaningful ways (I also want to mention The Republic which was low-key one of my favourite add-ons to the game). CK3 launched as a much more feature-complete game with two start-dates and an even bigger map than CK2 had, and even though some parts of the map are under-cooked everything was still playable except for republics (boo) and theocracies.

So here's CK3's first substantial expansion, more than a year after the launch of the base game, after multiple delays which wasn't really Paradox's fault. It is offering a totally re-hauled culture system and tons of interactions for king/emperor-tier characters and their courtiers. And the result is...fine. It's a good add-on that does add depth and decisions, but I can't help but feel underwhelmed. The court features add a nice bit of extra gameplay to your mid-late game and seeing hybrid cultures develop is fun, but for how long this pack was in development, and especially for the price, the end product just falls a bit flat.

If you're an obsessive CK/Paradox player like me, you will buy this price be damned and you'll enjoy the features it adds because they're mostly good, and that's why I ultimately chose the thumbs-up icon for this review. But this is a pretty unessential pack for people newer to the game or less invested, and the base game has so much content that you won't be left wanting by not picking it up. Pick it up on sale if you're on the fence.

It's like many reviews say: The scope of this expansion is far to narrow for the money you pay. I really really want to enjoy the DLC though, but it's just to easy to get the court maxed out, the events are pretty boring after a while because there are not much and all in all it doesn't bring much depth to the game.

TLDR: Stick to the free update. Most of what’s worth it was bundled up in there. New version and the 3D courtroom, although pleasant, feels insulting to paying customers. Optimization diminished for some reason and now the game is way more demanding in terms of hardware than it used to be. 
Long review:
I pre-purchased this DLC along with the other stuff bundled up in the Royal Edition. I Wouldn't have spent a dime on it if I had not pre-purchased it. Everything I've enjoyed about this DLC is included in the free update. That is cultures specifically, artifacts less so but are still a welcome feature. Court positions are… okay? They’re hardly noticeable as far as gameplay goes. In essence these are three stat modifiers, the Culture aspect being the most intricate, but all in all pretty shallow and unnoticeable, even downright forgettable. 
All of this is rightful content for a very juicy flavor pack, or a very generous free update. This means you are paying Specifically for the 3D room of the court. And in all honesty, it’s rather underwhelming. Like I said, the least enjoyable part of this entire DLC is what you’re actually paying for. Events related to holding court repeat themselves painfully often, the courtroom interaction with other characters is non-existent, and you can´t even roam freely in the room. Players pretty much need to wait for a popup to appear indicating there’s some randomized event in the courtroom, like an optional life event you can even bypass if you don’t notice the notification or just don’t care about it. Which, considering this is supposed to be the main attraction of this whole ordeal, is a huge miss in terms of execution and design of an overall neat but ultimately unnecessary addition to the game.  Actual improvements to the game were released in the free update. And while very generous from Paradox, it feels very insulting to the paying customers. That’s why I would advise you to save your money and enjoy the free update, which is ironically the best part of this DLC. 
On a side note, the game feels rather unoptimized. I run a rather beefy gaming laptop and I swear I had never experienced such high system demands. I don’t know if this is exclusive to the 3D aspect of the court or the entire new version overall. But all in all, it feels as if a lot in terms of performance and system optimization was forfeited in the name of a feature that hardly adds anything to the overall gameplay experience. 
Paradox needed a DLC that deepened Ck3, that amplified roleplay and immersion possibilities and brought both Ck2 players craving a more in-depth experience and new players used to a 3D environment and gameplay alike. Instead, they released… this. Save your money and enjoy the free update, you won’t miss out on anything and may even have a better time than those actually playing with the DLC enabled.
SONUNDA

The new culture system is a great improvement over the old system, but that was part of the free update. The 3D court room falls flat, in my opinion. Certainly not worth half the price of the base game.

It's a little bit sad seeing this DLC getting so many negative reviews, and I feel like Paradox do themselves disservice by naming this Royal Court, and I think most people give it negative review because of that. This DLC focus is more aimed towards the cultural stuff, with the court and artifacts being the big "luxury" feature. But I suppose the marketing team thinks it'd be more fascinating for players if it's titled as such.

Royal Court DLC allows you to play around with your dynasty culture. It tries to mimic the historical cultural divergence, like how whole Holy Roman Empire diverged into multiple kingdoms that each possess their own unique cultures as time goes by. Gameplay wise, it allows you, as an influential leader of your people, to steer your people towards a specific culture and lifestyle that you prefer (if you roleplay), or to benefit (if you prefer to minmax).

Culture and language also plays important part in your expansion. Having vassals that can't communicate properly with you and having different way of life is, of course, not ideal. You will find rapid expansions to be tad more dangerous, and might spell huge problem especially when it's time to pass the crown to your child. In general, you will find that large empires will have a lot of vassals with negative relations with you, and that's where the "Royal Court" mechanic comes into play. Having high court grandeur will net you positive relation to pretty much everyone, and this helps offset the negative relations you have with rulers of different cultures. 

Or you can just ignore everything I said and basically exploit the heck out of these new features and just conquer everything. Yes, you can do that, but really you always been able to do that without this DLC anyway. 

Of course, having artifacts to display and seeing a 3d court with people doing stuffs is a plus, but I do wish they are animated. They just freeze doing very simple animations (like whispering to your character) and the such, and I can tell that they have rather limited budget and time on this, as you can only access the court mechanic when you are at king/queen and emperor/empress level.

Overall I think this DLC is a good offer, and frankly I'm tad confused that some players think the CK 2 DLCs are more worth it. Like come on, while the court mechanic is rather basic, this is basically the very first time Paradox ever dabble in having something 3d and decent looking that are not just live wallpapers. The culture mechanic is fascinating and gives you the options to either play tall and focus as a small but super buff monoculture empire, or go for massive multiculture empire with all the caveats.

This expansion adds so little it's embarrassing. Especially when you consider the fact that it got delayed for several months because they felt that they needed to add more content in order to justify it to themselves. What would we have gotten if this released in 2021? Even if you get the court, which you won't unless you're a king or higher, it'll only add a couple of clicks every five years (you get to hear petitions every five years max). Paradox has completely lost their way. I am so afraid of what Victoria III will be at this point. Not going to preorder it.
1 year to make this small addition? 20 bucks? thumbs down

Okay, first things first.  The price IS high for what you get, even factoring in inflation and all that.  Only you can decide if the content is worth the price for you.  If you feel that it isn't, then wait for any of the inevitable sales and buy it then.

With that said, however, I do feel that this expansion IS worth owning and playing.  The two most common arguments I've seen among the negative reviews I've read are the price and general underwhelming scope of the DLC.  Royal Court may not be a great value for your money, and it may not be the DLC some people wanted it to be, but personally I love the added content.

To assist you with deciding if this DLC is right for you, at any price, I've put together a little Q & A session specifically calibrated for content from Paradox Interactive.  They have a reputation.  

Q 1:  Does this DLC break the game or make it impossible to play?
   A:  No. 

Q 2:  Does the accompanying version update make playing without the DLC almost or completely impossible?
A:  No. 

Q 3:  Can I live without this DLC?
A:  Yes.

Q 4:  Will this DLC change the way I play the game?
A:  Potentially.  You have to be at least a feudal kingdom in order to utilize the actual court aspect of the DLC but you can still acquire relics you can equip at any rank.  The relics themselves can have a very wide range of useful bonuses attached to them, from increasing your vassal limit to boosting your fertility rate, to boosting your combat abilities.  You could both treat all this as just background flavor, or make the acquisition of the best relics one of the main focuses of your campaign.  

Q 5:  Will this DLC warrant me starting up another new campaign?
A:  Maybe.  Again, the relics aspect can add a lot to your game, but largely everything is just about adding flavor to your campaign.  While the potential is there for an NPC to use a relic you possess that they have a claim to as justification for war (or vice versa), nearly every other aspect of the game is unchanged.  However, the changes to culture that came with the free version update are awesome and, in my opinion, warrant a new campaign on their own.

Final thoughts:  If you already love the base game, crave some additional flavor in your campaign, and don't mind spending the money, you'll probably love Royal Court.  But it's not going to be for everyone.  The relics do make for an awesome addition to the game but if they don't appeal to you in the slightest then you can ignore this DLC entirely.

Alright so i just played a full campaign with this new DLC. It took 125 hours from earliest start date to end date so I have some feedback to give. Im going to give this a hesitant thumbs up. I think there is a decent bit here that I enjoyed that helps round out the game, but it has many flaws and some odd choices in game design, not to mention many, many bugs still in the game.

Im glad they tried something different by adding the court system. It transitions into a new screen where you can visually see your court and change out artifacts and stuff, but to be honest, it sucks that you cant design your court more how you want to. Its cool that you can see artifacts, but why cant you full design your court if that is the point of the system. I suspect multiplayer capabilities would make this difficult so it was rounded down to a more basic function of a very limited amount of designs which is unfortunate.

Lets get into some pros and cons from my perspective

-Having equipable items is cool. Yes i understand that this isnt specifically apart of this DLC but it kinda goes with everything because of inspired people.
-The court itself is cool idea. -side note I had an idea for a new DLC that would be basically jousting tournaments or even gladiator games at the colosseum. With jousting tournaments having different events and based on where its held, weather, terrain, and time of year, or being at war could play different aspects of the tournament. The colosseum could have different types of fights and different creatures like lions, elephants, ect to change up, but this is just an idea i had.
-Holding court time of every 5 years is fine to me, if i was able to do it more it would be annoying.
-hybrid cultures and cultural divergence are great improvements to the game, that let you change what you want to do and if you want to also roleplay, more options for you.

Cons
-Im hesitant to say price, because I played for 125 hours and enjoyed myself, so to get it out of the way, I dont think the price is too high. BUT, for a new player who wont pick it up again because of this DLC, I think it is an issue.
-Grandeur is a missed opportunity. Yes it provides buffs and stuff, but it definately could have been more interesting.
-NEEDS MORE EVENTS. This for me is this biggest flaw of this DLC. This game needs more events full stop.
-A big problem for me is your vassels asking for artifacts too often, and if you refuse, you lose 60 opinion. This should be a court plea, or an event that triggered when you hold court with even worse consequences. I played and had the roman empire, I was getting spammed so much for artifacts i just kept clicking and closing them.
-Another huge issue is getting spammed about item durability. If you have a large empire, I had no joke at one point, 175 artifacts. And it seems that when you switch rulers or something, they lose durability even more because non-stop notifcations for it was just crazy. It got to the point where I would just close them all and have them be destroyed. The game shouldnt make you want to feel like you dont want to deal with your conquest rewards. You need to do something different with your items system.
-Missed opportunities in general. A few court roles I think are missing. For instance a jailer that maybe gives you dread and makes it less likely people escape from your jail. Grandeur in the form of grandeur events, or getting to choose specific things like culture dishes you serve, or types of fashion.
-Bugs. Some current bugs I ran into playing. Sometimes when renaming artifacts, it just wont let you because it says the name is too long, no matter what you type. Sometimes the screen flashes white when you clicking into the court. I had a bug where it said i was making negative 3 gold per month, and i was gaining around 12 gold per month. One or two others i forget at the moment, but were there.
-A final general problem, the spymaster role is boring, uninteresting, and needs reworking or additions. I very much enjoy the added abilities to the marshal, diplomat, and steward. The spymaster is very annoying, and also spams alot with useless information all the time. It needs to have one or two more actions that help give it more depth.


Overall I did enjoy my time playing the game and I do think it adds to the overall enjoyment of the game, however it does need to be reworked some and improved upon.

What I would like to see for future update and content

-The pope needs a rework. You should be able to destroy the pope for good even if you are christian. It kind of makes no sense he just survives for forever. Like I said before you could even add colosseum update in the same update as the pope since its the same location.
-Lots of events. More more more events for everything.
-More fun things to do with the northman. I havnt played them but from my understanding they dont get courts. I dont have a desire to play them because they have less to do.
-I think two more counselers should be added to the game. One of them should be Hand of the king/queen. This is an event where you get a minor bonus, but i think it could be a council member. One of its abilities could be to antagonize someone, making them more likely to attack you, or even them losing prestige. Royal engineer or something along those lines would be the second one. This would deal with artifacts and buildings and stuff. He would have the option to increase build time, search for artifacts, ect. This would get rid of the spam of ppl saying they have inspirations, which i think should also be a hold court event, and not just pop up all the time. It gets annoying.
-More stuff for the east, and additionally add more of the world/map. Would like to see a more fleshed out map and more focus on asian culture.
-Once again as i mentioned before, jousting tournaments. But please have them be alittle indepth with lots of events. I think the dueling system could help and go with it so thats a decent bit of the work done, but it needs to have options and lots of events to be fun. Also maybe special court positions for knights that joust ect.


ALSO i almost forgot. Counts should be able to make court pleas to the king. Makes no sense that a count cant make demands of a king, even if they are less likely to succeed.

Oh and one final thing, WAY MORE CLOTHING AND ACCESSORIES to make characters look cool and feel unique. Even the option of changing your crown ect in your rulers picture should be ESSENTIAL to the game.
Too expensive and broke the game, can't play with my friends because of constant RANDOM_COUNT desyncs.

I can tell a lot of work was put into this, particularly in the art department for modeling and rendering those court rooms. Though I have some hard-hitting thoughts. All of this was written from the perspective of a Pre-Y1K Ireland playthrough. And specifically, I couldn't bring myself to play longer than a single character's lifespan. I'll explain, in detail, why I couldn't. The short of it is how everything unravels overnight.

The one biggest disappointment with this expansion in particular is that I'm struggling to have my artifact sword build a reputation for mass slaughter in duels. (I can't have it win battles since the Commander of an Army does not count for being an active Knight.) Could've sworn that was a selling point, unless I missed something in the fine print. Because I wanted to get a blue "famed" weapon not from the craftsmanship, but from having it survive a hundred battles.
I really, REALLY like the idea of Artifacts being super precious and awesome, though looting the most developed empires seems a lot more profitable than building a locally commissioned sword, reforging it over the span of decades, and using that sword to slay all the enemies across both Britain *AND* France! I mean it, I want MY sword to grow into something more legendary and epic than just "I pillaged some king with my levy of 20,000 peasants". The same mindset could be applied to the other fields and types of artifacts (crown for holding diplomatic court, for example, or just having a huge territory being affiliated with my smithed Irish Crown yet that crown still feels puny when I have an empire to rival the biggest and best of the age).

The dueling, too...With ridiculous prowess, having tailored my character SPECIFICALLY to be an unbeatable God of War (even IN "Achievement Mode" where your ruler designer can still have one or two REALLY GOOD traits within their 400 point threshold), duels never ended before 3 or 5 action menus. Not even when my score was "Excellent" and I was against an aging Pope who had 0 Prowess! The way the information tries to convey how you're doing feels *RANDOM!* One time, same battle with the Pope, it'd tell me "We're evenly matched" and ALSO say "My form is near flawless, yet his is a disaster." How does that MAKE ANY SENSE?!

And for the final blow, when running the debug for the duel mechanic (which has a cute Yu-Gi-Oh reference, by the way, something you won't see in normal play), my "God of War" has ACTUALLY DIED in dueling against those fools. HOW! I mean, I guess that Martial focus branch was right in saying, "Luck can win a duel, and a fool can win a battle." But when the Prowess disparity is close to 100, I can't help but yell, "COME ON!"

And I noticed that no matter what the skill level of my councilor, the side effects never fired off (most specifically the martial "train" option to improve commanders, I never saw any of them actually improve even when I used debug powers to give a 50/50 chance of an improvement every month or year or whatever the in-game length of time was meant for).

Speaking of debug, if you think it'd be fun to play as God in this game with console commands, I have to be honest...that gets about as fun as a data entry job. When going full God mode, I find more time typing in the commands to make my whole court immortal than I do steamrolling whole dutchies and reuniting Brittania before the year 900. Admittedly, that's not how Crusader Kings is intended to be experienced, but still, keep that in mind if you ever get so frustrated that you want to show the computer who's boss.

Debug has other cute little Easter Eggs, like "Errorhoof" as a reference to "Glitterhoof" from Crusader Kings 2. Honestly, I absolutely MISS having a LITERAL "THUNDERHORSE" in my court! It gave such great Dethklok vibes, but I get that Crusader Kings 3 is emphasizing "nothing overtly supernatural", but still...a shame we lost such an awesome horse.

In all playthroughs, you are allowed only ONE God-tier character, and it shows. Without turning Crusader Kings into a data entry job, you can't modify your starting spouse, your children WILL get WATERED-DOWN congenital traits if your spouse has none (like the one *I* play as would have "Herculean" AND "Pure Blooded", the spouse has neither, then our SON would have "Hale" and NOT "Pure Blooded"). That's even WITH the dynasty perks focusing on breeding the best bloodline. So the only way to prevent this watering-down is absolute sibling-level inbreeding, which as you already know, will give the Inbred trait somewhere. Yet when matched with "Herculean", "Genius", AND "Beautiful", "Inbred" and "Genius" put together is basically a net-zero, meaning they cancel each other out so you get the same outcome as a common peasant in  terms of raw capability. I presume this is Paradox doing their strict "Game Balancing", but it's, again, NOT FUN! It also shows you get only ONE God-tier character, so might as well pack it up when that character dies.

Achievements...most of them are ridiculously specific, and that's not even counting how strict Paradox as a development studio is about what qualifies for "Achievement Mode". You can't debug a save, turn off debug, then load that save; it still won't count for achievements. Gotta hand it to them for thinking of EVERYTHING, but man it's frustrating. Don't play this game for the achievements.

Maintaining the court's "Grandeur" is a PAINFUL money sink, and with my God-tier character (both in "Achievement Mode" AND "Debug Mode"), my entire dominion falls to pieces the very moment my character DIES OF OLD AGE! Maybe it's historically accurate for a dynasty of 200 to 500 strong to see inevitable infighting and power vacuums, and also historically accurate for my groomed heir to have a FRACTION of the income as Dear Ol' Ma-an-Pa, or for the land to get cut up and divided among numerous heirs (a problem NOT in Stellaris, which I found more broadly appealing even though I truly want to like Crusader Kings for its more GRANULAR approach to empire-scale strategy and conquest, doubly when Stellaris doesn't let you duel your neighboring emperors to the death in toe-to-toe sword fights OR spar with your Vassals, OR give you the power to rob the weird tentacle aliens of the artifacts they have claimed). On all counts, I imagine that's the way it's supposed to be, though it isn't FUN when my God character creates an indomitable empire with the #1 court in the world, then it all falls apart the moment that character dies. It might as well be GAME OVER at that point, even though that's not the point of Crusader Kings (the POINT is to see your whole LEGACY play out). It's just seeing my work get undone is NOT FUN! 

The dialogue boxes are very plentiful, though after a while, I get tired of every in-game month (roughly 10 seconds of REAL time) having to pause because there are FIVE schemes at court involving random Courtiers, or my WIFE wants to murder my Physician. We're all on the same side, so why are you killing the best doctor in the land?

While Steam forces me to a binary decision on "Do you Recommend", I totally see where it'd get "mixed" reviews, and I'm kinda on the fence myself. The only reason I'm going with "Yes" is because I absolute appreciate the "A for Effort" that Paradox so far has earned. The core is HERE, it's that there is a GREAT amount of room for improvement.

Please, Paradox, improve this expansion!

I like CK games for their strategic gameplay, not the RPG elements. 
I like reading stories based on a playthrough, where the player used fantasy to create a story around what happened, and not creating the story with all RPG elements in game. 

The court system does nothing for me except pull me out of the game, and it worries me that it's made out to be such a big feature, making it harder to ignore. 

All the other features seem great, like the culture changes, but overall the courtroom steals the spotlight and ruins it for me.

For half the price of the game, I simply cannot recommend buying this. I am a long time PDX and CK fan and have almost all DLCs...except say EU IV for clear reasons of quality. CK 2 DLC even near the end was fantastic. Way of Life added SO much and that was quite late in the lifespan. 

This, this is the most expensive PDX DLC I've ever seen and it's a FRACTION of the content any old DLC ever offered. It's not even a 1/10th as enjoyable or meaningful. I'll be honest, I think it was falsely advertised. They showed lots of images in the dev diaries clearly making it LOOK like there would be animations of drawing daggers etc. in the court. No...nothing. The court is a dead, static place with literally no movement or life AT ALL.

It's the core of this mod and you almost never open it, not to mention the court is optimised terribly and makes a 3070 kick up to 99% utilisation for no reason. So now CK 3's excellent performance is dropping in quality also. It took them a year and a half to make a 3D room that looks the same no matter what grandeur level you are. No seriously, what have they actually been doing in this time?

By now CK 2 would have had nearly 4 DLCs with an insane amount more content even in ONE of them. Merchant republics perfect example. That took a few months in comparison. Nothing this DLC adds is actually useful. It's tiny stat bonuses. It adds no depth, no more enjoyment, nothing. It's a damn good thing CK 3 is really fun as it is because this is a SERIOUS misfire for a TWENTY FOUR POUNDS DLC. Insane to even ask that for a SIMS 2 room.

The only thing I will say, is there is a noticeable increase in fun flavour text again after CK 3 base is dry af in its humour and fun compared to CK2. I'm not saying it needs Cthulu, but my God CK3 base needs flavour events badly.

The free features are all you need, don't waste half the cost of a FULL GAME on this hit and miss. You'll forget it's even there in an hour. Not to mention it's KINGS only so if you like to play Count, don't bother at all.

This is half the cost of a new game. Honestly, I feel cheated. PDX DLC has never made me feel THAT bad.

I just completed a full CK3 game with Royal Court and my feelings are... mixed! But, I enjoyed myself and found that the additions of Royal Court were more positive than negative, so I'll give it a recommendation. Also of note, I bought the "Royal Edition" of CK3 at a reduced cost long before Royal Court came out, which included the DLC, so I didn't get the same sticker shock that most did. These are my thoughts without considering price:

The Good!
- It's a neat idea, being able to see your court and the characters inside it adds a lot of flavor to the game in itself.
- My favorite aspect, the return of "minor titles" from CK2 in the form of court duties. Having things like a jester and a cup-bearer adds a nice little extra element. Especially as you expand, you lose track of individual characters, and giving them specific jobs helps create "I know that guy!" moments.
- Language and culture feels better than it did originally (though this may be part of the non-DLC patch)
- Most of the events weave into existing things well, such as artifacts coming up in schemes.

The bad!
- Holding court is, unfortunately, a hassle! It's extremely buggy at the moment (many missing characters or actors that don't make sense, i.e. people asking me to take my own daughter in as my own daughter), but even when it works, it's a tedious and unrewarding process that pops up far too often. There's also an issue with repeating events, though this is a problem with all of CK3 for me ("a snake at court" and shocking fornicator secrets happen dozens of times per hour)
- Artifacts, while a cool idea, have a lot working against them. Durability is a nagging issue, vassals constantly demand artifacts from you (not only annoying, but very damaging to relationships), and the interface (particularly in court and gifting) is very awkward and disfunctional.
- I'm unsure how it will evolve. It seems like the idea of Royal Court is good, but it's buggy and could use a lot more.. everything. Since it's DLC and not a required part of the main game, it seems like they'll either have to integrate it (defeating the purpose of buying this) or ignore it in future updates and DLC. And, since it's Paradox, we all know there will be a lot more DLC.

So, overall, I'm recommending Royal Court with a sentiment of "I like the game more with it than without it". It always sounded like an ambitious idea while it was being developed, and I don't think they quite delivered what I hoped it was going to be, but.. that's kind of how I feel about everything Paradox does! Ambitious, really cool and complex ideas that end up more than a little busted, and absolutely no idea where they're going next.

Would have been cool if you could hold court as a count and duke, but even that isn't justifiable for what we actually got for $30. 

Either wait until this dlc gets more content and patched up or a price drop to like $5 or less, $30 is a scam.

Short: Do NOT buy this DLC if you play mostly Tribal cultures like the Norse or Africans. DO buy this DLC if you play feudal and clan cultures. 

Long: This DLC brings four main additions to the base-game: royal courts, cultural acceptance, hybrid cultures, and extra traditions. 

The Royal Court is geared mostly for Kings and Emperors. Dukes and counts don't get courts, but they can visit the court of their royal/imperial lieges and petition them for one thing or another. As a king/emperor, you get a snazzy throne room where you can spend money on various amenities, artifacts, and courtiers. All three provide *huge* bonuses to prestige, renown, approval, taxes, levies, dread, and a variety of other factors--assuming you generate enough income to cover the burgeoning expenses of your kingdom/empire.  

Culture received a major overhaul. Play nice with a culture, giving land and titles to that culture? Its people will accept you, giving you approval bonuses and even a chance to hybridize. This will allow you pick out the ethos and traditions from two cultures as you create a brand new one. Keep attacking the nobles of a culture, never letting any of them hold titles? Be prepared for stiff approval penalties from both nobles and the general public. You can reduce these penalties through steward projects and learning the local language.

A couple extra traditions round off this DLC, allowing you to mold your culture to better suit your playstyle. While some traditions can be found in the base game, there are the new ones that are particularly interesting. Infinite kingdom-level holy wars, +25 development when building/replacing structures, easily convince unwanted heirs to take religious vows while they're still children... these are just some examples of the added traditions with a huge impact to your game.

Oh, and there's the flavor text you get from Royal Court events. Most of these events are procedural, making you choose one option or the other. Some of them are also bugged, with names not appearing. Annoying, but not game-ending for an ironman run. It's the narrative-driven events that are the real treat, like a cult chasing after the missing skull of their beheaded messiah. 

In conclusion, Royal Court is an excellent if pricy addition to Crusader Kings 3. It breathes some much-needed life into games, especially when you get tired of blobbing across the map and just want to focus on developing your little corner of the world.

This expansion goes into the category "good idea, but poor execution" category. I do not find it necessary to comment on the price or Paradox DLC policy and do not really take that into the account of my review. I will let that be up to the judgement of the readers.

Royal Court allows you to interact with your subject by holding court. It also allows you to display artifacts which will give you various bonuses. This is all good, but holding court gets tedious very quickly when those reminders keep popping up and you have the same events happening over and over again. This DLC needs way more events to work out properly. It would be interesting to also see more events that can make an impact on the gameplay. For example you could allow your subjects to construct a holding or establish a merchant's guild. However, most of the time, the events are small and rather insignificant. Could be that is how it is to be a ruler, but CK3 is also a strategy game.

And that is where this expansion is not doing its job. The whole Court Grandeur system feels meaningless. There are ten different levels to go through and with bonuses you can get by attaining different levels. You can also choose between different types of courts to get different bonuses. All good in theory, but in practice it feels like there are only 2-3 levels. There is not much strategy involved in advancing the level of your court. It depends solely on your gold income so it is very easy to increase the level of your court. It would have been more interesting if there would have been other requirements and benefits in place to make this a bit more challenging. 

So in short the expansion adds too little for those into RP (events) and too little depth for those who are more into strategy.  The ideas in here are good, but an expansion is supposed to add to the longevity of the game. There is just not that much new here that would add many hours of content to the game. 

Even after half a playthrough I feel like I have seen most of what Royal Court has to offer. What I have seen is not bad, but I wanted to see more. Unless these issues will be addressed, I find it really difficult to recommend this expansion.

So, if you like to roleplay and story build than this DLC is for you. It adds a good amount of character interactivity and the ability to shape fictional history in fun and funky ways.

If you're more of a mechanics, big empire, map painting, or challenge kind of player than this probably isn't for you.

Also.. I do agree it's probably a bit too expensive. Wait for a sale unless what you see is really interesting to you like it was for me.

While I try to embrace the absurd nature of medieval horticulture as a treatment for a grievous wound or the sly tactics employed by my distant cousins, this is just unfun.

[h1] On peut vendre 1 DLC à 1000 personnes, on peut vendre 1000 DLC à 1 personne, mais on ne peut pas vendre 1000 DLC à 1000 personnes, en particulier s'ils sont de cette qualité ! [/h1]

Par où commencer ? Déjà, je vais préciser une chose, tout le contenu de la MAJ ne fait pas partie du DLC. J'ai vu certaines personnes mettre une éval positive en mentionnant les artefacts par exemple, sauf que cela risque d'induire en erreur les gens.

Le contenu associé à ce DLC c'est la salle du trône, les événements liés à elle, ainsi que la possibilité de réformer, diverger ou fusionner des cultures. C'est tout. Les artefacts, le rework du système des cultures, le système des langues et leur apprentissage, les nouveaux postes de la cour, tout ça c'est lié à la MAJ GRATUITE, donc n'allez pas acheter le DLC si c'est ce qui vous intéresse.

[h1] Ceci étant éclairci, que vaut le DLC ? [/h1]

Pour ma part, je dénote trois gros points négatifs :

[u] Premier point [/u] : Le contenu, forcément. 30 balles pour une modélisation de la cour, qui n'offre guère de personnalisation en plus. Au niveau des événements, y en a des intéressants, je ne saurais dire s'il y en a en grand nombre ou pas, mais au bout de quelques heures j'en avais déjà qui revenait souvent.

Et pour rester sur le point du manque de contenu, je rajouterais qu'en plus, la salle du trône n'a même pas été totalement exploité. Je m'en suis rendu compte en tombant sur un mod du workshop, qui rajoute la possibilité de célébrer son mariage dans la salle du trône, et là je me suis dis "mais oui!". Pourquoi Paradox n'y a pas pensé ? Cela rajouterait une plus-value sur du contenu déjà existant, et ça pourrait même en rajouter davantage. Imaginez pouvoir organiser des banquets dans sa salle du trône par exemple.

Non seulement la salle du trône n'apporte pas grand-chose, mais en plus elle n'a même pas été pleinement exploitée.

[u] Deuxième point [/u] : L'implémentation et l'intérêt du DLC dans le jeu de base. Pour faire simple, quand vous achetez le DLC et que vous lancez une partie, au final, il se passe quoi de particulier ? Vous jouez comme vous jouez d'habitude, et parfois vous allez avoir un élément du DLC qui va venir vous rappeler que oui vous avez claqué de la thunes juste pour ça. 

Vous pouvez accorder une audience tous les 5 ans, donc tous les 5 ans vous allez écouter les doléances des gens, ce qui se traduit par un système tout à fait similaire aux événements que l'on a régulièrement. Ils sont différents évidemment (heureusement), et certains sont drôles, d'autres intéressants, j'ai par exemple eu un dirigeant étranger venu me demander qu'il devienne mon vassal, c'est sympa, mais dans l'idée c'est des événements comme on en connaît déjà dans le jeu de base.

Parfois vous aurez un événement, hors audience accordé, qui va pop, mais ça reste un événement, avec un petit synopsis et des choix à faire.

Ce DLC n'apporte fondamentalement rien qui requiert réellement l'attention du joueur au-delà de quelques minutes de temps à autre, hormis pour une mécanique en particulier, mais je vais y revenir, et cela est du en partie au fait que : c'est trop facile.

La mécanique principale de la salle  du trône, c'est de devoir gérer le niveau de magnificence de la cour, le niveau de grandeur, sauf que c'est beaucoup trop facile. Il n'y a même pas réellement besoin de la gérer. À partir du moment où vous gagnez assez d'argent, vous augmentez les frais, engagez des gens à certains postes clés, et voilà, c'est bon, plus besoin de s'en préoccuper outre mesure.

[u] Troisième point [/u] : Donc la mécanique dont je parlais un peu avant c'est : la réforme, la divergence et le métissage des cultures. C'est probablement la mécanique la plus intéressante qu'offre ce DLC, et ce n'est en fait pas une si bonne chose que ça.

Là encore je vais y revenir, mais de tous les ajouts, c'est peut être celui qui va accaparer le plus votre attention, parce que déjà c'est une mécanique que je trouve ultra intéressante, de pouvoir en quelques sorte créer des build de cultures en piochant dans celles des autres (et l'intérêt va en être considérablement augmenté avec les flavor pack qui rajouteront des mécaniques propres à chaque culture) mais cela va vous coûter cher en prestige, vous allez donc chercher à en obtenir toujours plus ce qui vous donnera un objectif à moyen terme, mais en plus vous allez tout mettre en oeuvre pour que l'acceptation culturelle soit assez haute pour que la fusion des cultures puisse se produire. Demander à votre conseiller de travailler là-dessus, éviter de déclencher des guerres entre vos cultures, augmenter l'acceptation via les événements aléatoires etc.

Bref, c'est certainement la meilleure mécanique du DLC, mais si je disais un peu avant que ce n'est pas forcément une bonne chose, c'est parce qu'en fait je trouve que cette mécanique n'a rien à voir avec l'idée du DLC qui est la Cour Royale. 

Ça ne concerne pas la gestion de la cour en fait, et le pire, c'est que ce n'est pas réellement du contenu ajouté par le DLC, mais plutôt du contenu bloqué dans le jeu de base, dont le DLC va permettre de débloquer.

Si on compare ça avec les religions, c'est comme si dans le jeu de base vous aviez les religions, mais que pour les réformer ou en créer de nouvelles, il fallait acheter un DLC. Et donc j'en viens à ma théorie perso : je pense qu'ils ont mis ça dans le DLC parce qu'en fait, sans ça, il aurait un contenu totalement rachitique. C'est déjà pas fameux avec, mais sans, je crois qu'on pourrait clairement parler de DLC inutile. Là, ça va créer une espèce de frustration de ne pas avoir accès à une mécanique hyper intéressante, et donc ça va pousser à acheter [b] LE DLC [/b] , qui, si vous ne l'aviez pas compris après ce pavé, [b] NE VAUT CLAIREMENT PAS 30 EUROS. [/b]

J'ai mis un pouce bleu au DLC des Vikings, malgré un contenu malingre, parce que le prix n'était pas abusé, même si un poil exagéré peut-être, mais là c'est non, juste non. Un gros non.

Ceci dit, histoire de nuancer un peu, je reconnais volontiers le travail énorme fourni pour la MAJ Fleur-de-Lis. Oui, le rework du système des cultures, l'implémentation des artefacts, des langues, l'acceptation culturelle, le travail sur la forme comme sur le fond, est énorme, je ne dis pas le contraire, et il faut bien avouer que c'est plaisant de voir que, même avec le modéle économique des DLC, Paradox bosse sur ses MAJ gratuites et ne laisse pas sur le carreau les gens qui ne vont pas acheter les DLC, MAIS, ça ne justifie pas le prix du DLC. 

Au final le plus grand intérêt de la salle du trône, c'est ce que cela apportera grâce aux mods. Les salles du trône des univers du seigneur des anneaux, game of thrones et j'en passe. En tant que machine à fan service ça va être énorme.

Donc moi ce que je vous dis, c'est que non, ça ne vaut pas 30 euros, mais par contre, si ça fait un moment que vous n'avez pas relancé le jeu, et que vous attendiez le DLC pour ça, ben en fait n'achetez pas le DLC mais profitez de la MAJ gratuite qui, elle, apporte beaucoup, et justifie de relancer une nouvelle partie.

Merci Paradox pour ce contenu de qualité gratuit qu'apporte la MAJ.

Pas merci pour ce DLC par contre.

Too little too late.

After more then a year of waiting we got, in essence, a buffed up flavor pack, for a price tag of a full blow expansion.

No courts for tribal rulers. No court for feudal dukes. So in order to experience "court" content you have to be feudal king or higher.
Culture changes, while nice, give very little in replayability.

This content should have been much lower on the priority list after some more important DLCs and it should have been done right.

I fear that Paradox team is falling apart from the inside and that it will end up like Blizzard, destroying all of their hard earned IPs.

Only reason why I own Royal Court is that I bought it as part of a pre-sale bundle. I will not repeat that same mistake again.

This is a good DLC. Adds a lot of content to the game and is a promising step in further fleshing out this game. 
It's a little overpriced yes, but it's still a very clear thumbs up.
Good DLC nothing amazing adds some stuff to the game that is good, but way too much money for the content, i wont be buying the next one on release.
A nice experience

I love the CK3 base game and I've played it for hundreds of hours since its release. Whilst I was very excited about this DLC, sadly I think it's both extremely underwhelming and massively overpriced in its current state. 

Where the (very affordable) Northern Lords flavour pack brought a tonne of new features, events, lore, and world-building, which each felt impactful within the game, the Royal Court feels completely like an add-on that doesn't really add much that's substantial to the gameplay experience.

Within the Royal Court interface (which you can only access by leaving the campaign map, which doesn't help with making it feel integrated), you simply see a bunch of people standing around, alongside some artefacts that you can choose to display. And it feels thoroughly disappointing to see your court like this. At least before you could use your imagination to envisage the conniving, affairs, and intrigue of your loyal and disloyal subjects and courtiers. I feel like the imagination does a much better job at portraying this than Paradox has done for £25; it feels static and uncompelling.

If you have money to burn, there'll be things about this you'll still enjoy. But if you're looking for a CK3 expansion, either get the Northern Lords pack (for 1/5 of the price of this DLC) or wait until this is either improved or comes on sale. It's really not worth the £25 that it's currently retailing at.

Not enough content for too much money. For some reason, it seems like they believe that just because they were inefficient with their dev process (seriously, 18 months?), the consumer should have to pay a huge upcharge for an update with limited content or interesting features.
one step in royal court DLC, great skip for Paradox Games

Für 30€ kann man dieses DLC nicht empfehlen. Es gibt neue Events, Artefakte, den Rat und die Überarbeitung der Kultur. Die Events beziehen sich oft auf genannte Artefakte oder den Rat. Der Rat selber ist eher weniger interaktiv und ist in meinen Augen schmückendes Beiwerk. Das neue Kultursystem ist ganz nett und macht auch Spaß, jedoch ist es für mich auch die einzige große Neuerung in dem DLC. Da das Spiel keine große Überarbeitung erfährt, frage ich mich was an diesem DLC 30€ kosten soll. Für 15€ kann ich es aber guten Gewissens empfehlen.

Espansione ricevuta con la Royal Edition, quindi non a prezzo pieno. Ad ogni modo, con tutte le mancanze del gioco, questa espansione non mi ha soddisfatto per niente. Invece di migliorare aspetti della simulazione e rendere il gioco più "profondo", si va nella direzione opposta di aggiungere stupidi meme-generator e baggianate varie. Per me mai più un preorder da Paradox.
Good addition.  It adds some nice flavor that was missing as well as some interesting options when playing as a king/emperor.

Artefacts are pointless, having a single artefact will spam you with -60 negative relations with your entire dynasty unless you just give them everything you own. 

Councillor side effect/events have been disabled entirely. 

Courts are bland and have very little content, the events just repeat every couple of decades, meaning after a single character you've seen 90% of the events.

Court positions are just a chore, you have to constantly rehire new ones every 2-3 years for the 20 positions, and you have to keep checking which positions are vacant as people die or just leave.

You can't hybridise culture with any culture of the same heritage, for example if you're playing as Welsh and want to hybridise with Cornish to grab their ancient miner tradition... You can't. Even though hybridising is the only way to get that tradition, and Welsh and Cornish don't share any traditions, so their reasoning of cultures are too "similar" when they don't share a single tradition or pillar and one of them has an entirely unique tradition. This makes it easier for a Chinese culture to get ancient miners from Cornish vs their Welsh neighbours that speak the exact same language and are supposed to share the same heritage.

I can see what they're trying to do, but it just doesn't work. They tried their best to polish it and avoid the disasters that EU4 and Surviving Mars suffered, but it still has bugs and while they aren't game breaking they do make the game more bland than ever, not to mention the best part of the DLC the artefacts are a constant source of spam, as anyone related to you will demand everything you have and if you refuse you've just made an enemy for life, and you might face a full on revolt for not handing over your book of poems. I even had a distant cousin demand my crown while I was emperor, and they only held one county. 

This is the last Paradox game I will be buying, and I will never buy a DLC from them again, even when the DLC doesn't break the game with bugs it just makes it so bland that you don't want to play any more. I don't know what is going on in their company, but eventually people will stop buying their products because their current strategy is unsustainable. Their games become filled with tacked on features that either break the game or just get in the way of actually playing the game you bought.
overdue and hardly adds anything, not worth $40 NZD, i can't understand why it took them a year to make this, the 3d royal court is pointless and just takes up space on my screen.
Definitely not worth the full price, and it's definitely not worth more than $10

This expansion more for advanced players. Once you take time to understand it you realize it lets you play the game in so many more ways than before. Lets you make huge changes to your strategies and civilizations,(what cultures you wanna start with, change to, hybrid with, etc) the traditions of all the different cultures really change the game alot. The royal court stuff is good too and getting equipment for you character

Especially if you like making custom rulers and trying many different builds, this really changes game alot and lets you do so many things. really fun for advanced players, and finding overpowered builds.

Underwhelming and very overpriced at the $30 price tag. Artifacts are back from CKII which is cool but I was hoping that they would be more than just a stat buff. The updates to cultures is cool, a bit too similar to how religion works but it's okay. This DLC is only worth $15 imo.
great content, high price tag

I love the richness the new mechanics bring with this DLC. It especially adds some things to pursue mid to late game. In the base game, I would find myself rocketing through large swathes of time as I was waiting for a truce to expire or a new casus belli to get formed. With Royal Court, I find myself spending this time paying more attention to my culture (do I hybridize? diverge?) and also filling my royal court and person with artifacts.

Other people aren't wrong - it is a subtle change, but that is what I love about this. The game I knew and loved didn't disappear or get overshadowed - it got enhanced so seamlessly you almost feel like it was always there.

But to be fair, if you are looking for content for dollars, the Northern Lords is more bang for your buck - if you like playing Vikings. But hey, who doesn't love Vikings? If this is you, wait for Royal Court to go on sale. If you are dipping your toe into CK3 for the firs time and don't know if you will like it - buy the base game and get this expansion if you enjoy it.

However, for the most complete and best version of CK3 available, buy this expansion and don't be too discouraged if the first few hours feels the same. Your Royal Court experience will ramp us as you lose tens or hundreds of hours to the game :)
liek

Value is subjective. Totally worth it to me, and I enjoy the new content.

Also, 30 bucks to a person with a halfway respectable salary is not a big deal.

Honestly, this is a very good DLC easily worth the price when combined with the free stuff in the 1.5 update. The culture stuff is a game changer, the court position finally give courtiers some use, and the royal court is a fun system. The only big negative is that the tribal rulers are locked out of having courts for whatever reason. Ironic, since one of the Paradox-sponsored ads was a video about a Mongolian court.

IMHO, what led to the mixed ratings more than anything is the opaque nature of finance. Yeah, paying a full price game for a DLC hurts, even if I understand that the developers need to eat. Still, given the amazing quality of mods that CK3 has I'm hoping for more top tier expansions and to play CK3 for years to come.

Bad:

I hate to say I'm disappointed because I love Paradox strategy games, but sadly I am.

 I'm happy to pay for dlc and generally have had good value for money. I like the model whereby a successful game is developed over a long time scale with lots of new content but this time I find myself on the same side as those who feel this one is heavily over-priced. For me the problems are 

Immersion-so far what I've seen at court are  trivial or even silly decisions, with annoyingly frequent repetition. I should be able to summon people to court to influence what they are doing i.e. any member of my Council at the very least.  I have no sense of being the ruler of complex realm. The views are few and fixed. I'm really surprised there is no first person view looking out from the throne, that's a lost opportunity. 

Worst of all in my opinion is that I'm always broke with Royal Court. Playing as the King of Poland before the dlc came out I had just enough money to do what I wanted, with some hard choices. Now as King of France a much richer country I can do hardly anything because the court even at a most modest level swallows up so much cash. Paying a gift to the Pope now costs me 3 years national income! I'm not good at this game and no doubt could do better at managing the money, but I don't see why my court eats up as much money as my army. 

No doubt over time the dlc will improve but I am un-installing for now so I can get back to enjoying ck3 and would advise others not to buy until Royal Court has been substantially improved.
I love the Culture addition and the flavor added by the court.
