I was intending to leave a positive review, especially since most of the negative reviews focus on the price point, which to me is not an issue in a game i expect to play for hundreds, if not thousands of hours... i mean in comparison, how much would you spend on a night out? 

Anyway preamble aside, i have to leave a negative review for actual reasons related to the game. The main issue is that now i have frequent crashes upon loading a save game where i didn't before (also load times seem longer?). There are also other bugs, yesterday i had one where every time i switched between screens the map mode would default to the culture map view, odd but not exactly game-breaking admittedly. I've also had an issue where my gold was not counting my income, only my expenses, so it was impossible to make money, this might have been due to the hotfix though, but usually they don't mess with save files....

Generally i like what this DLC along with the free update is trying to do, the AI is marginally better for example (will mostly stick to a siege that is almost complete now), but there are bugs and crashes that while not necessarily game-breaking are immersion-breaking at least and really flippin annoying!

I'd sadly recommend that if you are interested in this, you wait until there have been a bunch of patches, it'll also probably be cheaper by then too :)

Edit: I was literally just thinking of changing this to a positive review after getting to grips with more of the content which i'm rather enjoying... but the game crashed on loading again. I thought i'd found a work around but apparently not.

I really enjoy the culture mechanic and the court itself is also nice but its definitely overpriced, get it on a sale if you can

While perhaps not the most complex concept, the new culture mechanic has been a long time coming. I personally find that alone to be a huge step forward for the franchise, and one I think that other related games (i.e. Europa Universalis) might benifit from in some form. 

It's so fun and satisfying to conquer a new land, and soon enough create your own hybrid culture - the best of both. 

All of this is not even to mention the actual royal court screen, which I think is a really  fun and immersive experience.

All told, while the expansion is one of the more expensive I have seen, I am pleased with my purchase, and hope that Paradox continues to release content like this that both broadens and deepens the historical and  immersive experiences.

The reviews feel like there's a tension between those who are heavily mechanics-focused and those who are emergent-narrative focused. Perhaps the DLC is lighter on the former, though languages and cultures are still quite compelling from that regard. Personally, I find the Throne room and the many issues brought towards you quite satisfying and enjoyable. With how  your traits and stress further interact with them, it's the most satisfying PDX game from a roleplay/narrative perspective.

A solid expansion even though most of it makes you feel like it should have been in the initial release. Is it worth buying? Yes. Are there issues? Also yes:

1. Creating your culture does not spread the culture to provinces in a logical way. E.g. you combine dominant Greek with Bavarian. Instead of the Bavarian provinces in the proximity of Greek ones and vice versa converting it only converted a hand full near the coast of cyprus. Which didnt make any sense at all. It also did not affect any more than just one of my 16 domain holdings.
2. AI being able to hybridize can ruin your game. Less dominant cultures can make hybrids with yours since the relation between the two is synched. In my case this meant that the handfull of Bulgarians hybridized with Greek and converted large swaths of my Empire with shitty cultural pillars and they even swapped my entire capital duchy and other important holdings.
3. The Royal Court can be really annoying with the "holding court" reminder which you cant really toggle. You also have to spend masses of gold to keep your court grandeur up so that your vassals wont just depose you because mimimi your perfect bread wasnt enough, we want some bread from Mars' soil. 
4. Artifacts are missing some quality of life love. Once you played for a while you will have shitload of trashy artifacts. Sure you could just gift them away or let them crumble. Sadly the latter will most likely cause you to lose important ones as you tend to ignore them. It is unclear to me why there is no toggle for "keep this artifact intact" which would cost a tiny monthly cost. Instead you have to scroll through 100 artifacts every couple of years and manually click on multiple buttons to repair them.
5. Artifact space: there is this gigantic hall with so much space but somehow youre limited to only few spots where you can place your artifacts. Id rather have weaker artifacts but more space to display them. Im sure modders will fix this eventually. 
6. Minor court titles: It is pretty annoying if you have not only the 5 major roles but also 22 minor ones to give away. I would really love the option to just pick the next best candidate for the roles I want to have always filled.
Months of wait for this ? I only have it because I bought the royal editions... Not my greatest purchase

Had this dlc been like half the price I wouldn't have written a negative review.

Okay, I DID enjoy this. But I'm always gonna enjoy more CK3. The issue is, would this be worth the US$30 price tag? And the answer is nope. I've now played Royal Court from count to emperor and the additions, though somewhat welcome, are not worth that price.

- The Court Room
So, I was really excited to get up to the level where I could have a court and that hype landed like a bit of a wet fart. You can't even actually look around your court. I'm not asking for a total free cam but there's not even a basic rotate. Can my court actually look alive too? With my jester juggling, my musician playing etc? Nope. It is extremely dull. They didn't even think of some kind of glamour shot view to look at your artifacts.

- Artifacts
Speaking of artifacts, the interface for putting them in and out is pretty awful, with no comparison tool like many an RPG has when swapping items. And I hope you like renaming the ones you have equipped to remember what they are because when NPCs try to claim them off you, good luck remembering. What's more, you'll end up with a massive stockpile of this crap that you can't even JUST SELL. Nope, ya gotta gift it, so hoarding them does you really no good. I will say it is nifty we now have a system to equip items, it's just janky as heck and the inventory management system is terrible. Oh and I would much rather give solid directions to my artificer than some vague handwave in the general direction of what I want. I have a dozen tapestries and banners and I still only have one small wall object, which I stole.

- Holding Court
Yeah, you'll hate this. Rarely is it anything just good that comes your way when you hold court, unless you are sitting on a mountain of gold to spend on an outcome. The events are very repetitive and most times you'll walk out having spent 100 prestige just to piss off everyone you know.

- Culture
The one solidly implemented aspect is culture and language. I enjoyed making my kids learn the language of their bethrothed spouses to be so they had a better chance at happy marriages. I liked modding my culture and checking out potential hybrids.  It was neat seeing the landscape of the world evolve. This is good.

VERDICT
DLC needs a few big patches. Wait till Royal Court goes on sale for cheap, then snag it. The bonus being that the wonky bits would likely be fixed by then too. Only get it, literally, for the culture.

Like good Swedes, Paradox subscribes to the Marxist theory of value.

That is to say that the value of a product correlates directly to the amount of labour put into it.

By extending the production time on this "expansion" as long as possible, working on a pointless graphical interface that could have been represented by the conventional UI, the devs feel perfectly justified in sticking a £24 price tag on what a feature-barren "expansion" that just feels like a patch.

A cynic might venture to wonder whether this first DLC being so bare bones is down to the fact that, as the first DLC of the title, it was bundled in with pre-orders?

Not worth your money, unless it comes in a DLC bundle for 90% off or something, years from now.

Paradox used to have decent quality but overpriced DLCs, the new trend seems to be less than average quality DLCs for even more money than before. Not a good direction to take, obviously. Here's to hoping they'll eventually take a step back and start making proper DLCs again.
fat too expensive. There are not many things to do in court, all it adds are seeing charatere on a throne, a bad one!

First of all, I like the idea of this DLC. I always though: Wouldn't it be nice to have a 3d scene with all your courtiers around, now that we have 3d models? Though it certainly never was a top priority for me.
For the sake of this review, let's ignore the price-tag and that maybe this shouldn't have been the first DLC and that it took so long (with almost no patches in between) and just have a look at what you get.

[list]
    [*][b]A 3d court (if you are a king)[/b]:
To be precise 4 of them. Each with a few minor texture variations. The thing is: The game covers an area from portugal to india and tibet, from iceland to the subsaharan africa. There are distinct court representations for western europe, the mediterranean, india and one middle eastern looking one for everyone else. I do understand that there aren't distinct visuals for England vs France, but at the very least there should be a eastern europe (slavic), one asian and (at least!) one african court room. By the way, this has nothing to do with the price, just with the scope of the game requiring it. If it's too much work, then don't make such a DLC. Do it right, or don't do it... 
Speaking of things missing from the 3d court: It doesn't feel alive. Many players report that they rarely look at their court screen, and if you decide to buy this you'll soon understand them. Why? One reason is probably that they didn't invest just a little bit of money into better animations. Also, the sound design for the royal court is off, but I suspect that, to some extend, it might just be bugged: I often don't hear any background music but instead a quite loud and quite low quality background talk recording. Btw, it sounds very much like a latin, so have fun with your indian court...
    [*][b] You can hold court[/b] (and court events):
    Sounds great, right? But I'd recommend you don't click that button. Just don't do it.
    If you do, you'll get 3 petitioners that teleport into your 3d court (because having characters walk around in a 3d scene is black magic and no one can do such things). There are a few types of petitioners: 
A) The two mayors you have never heard about that have some problems with each other. Actually, these events are probably somewhat accurate and dealing with them was certainly part of a kings job. It would really help though, if the mayors were actually your mayors and not the mayors under some count under some duke of yours, because in that case, you really don't care at all.
B) The meme-guests. They are here to entertain you. At least, maybe the first time you'll see them. Sadly, the number of events is quite limited, so expect them to tell their bad joke more then once.
C) The characters who are totally confused what they are doing there: A big problem with CK3 (and also this expansion) is that there doesn't seem to be any quality control on events and content designers just make stuff up as quickly as possible (and for some reason even that way they don't event have loads of court events...) and don't think about which event would make sense for which character. So you're wife, the queen will be accused of eating from the royal cake. Your 3-year old son will be accused of being a drunkard, neglecting his duties and fighting your courtiers. You daughter will petition you to take care of her son "who's dear mama went missing" - seriously? Aside from these obvious examples, there are quite a few more where characters aren't entirely out of place but certainly acting against their personality and thus breaking immersion.
The DLC also comes with great, important decisions like "change court fashion/architecture", which do nothing except for giving you a minor modifier. Cool!
    [*][b]Artefacts[/b]
Loads of artefacts. Expect to be bombarded with them. Of course, the interface gets cluttered with them quickly and they'll just become a hassle. Despite the vision of "not have OP artefacts", a few went under the radar and for example give you the totally sensible superpower of (almost) immortality. Others are just boring. Yeah, balance is a problem in CK3.
Oh and by the way, if you expected the presentation of artefacts in the court room to be cool I'll have to disappoint you. Most of them have generic models (a chest containing stuff, a weapon rack, a diamond). At least a little bit better than crowns which of course your character won't actually wear (because they have no 3d model). Most artefacts in your court feel a bit out of place. Its a court, no a treasury. Also, they decided that you get stat modifiers from the artefacts displayed at your court, so they had to severely limit the number of artefacts you can have at display. And you can only place them at specific slots, so you cannot have a nice looking arrangement of realm/dynasty banners behind your throne.
    [*]Culture Customisation
    If you feel like it, you can customise your culture. Like religious customisation, its more of a once in a playthrough thing to make your culture/religion kind of OP or super weird, but hybrid cultures are quite nice when playing a viking and conquering a realm elsewhere. 
   Be warned though, the AI might go a little bit crazy with that feature.
    [*][b]Grandeur[/b]
    Nice idea. You can get maximum level grandeur (and insane boni) in 20 years if you have a small kingdom for almost no cost. If your kingdom is large, good luck, because the amenity costs will scale depending on the size of your realm (measured in #counties, not development). It's totally unbalanced, but maybe they'll balance it eventually. Though, to be honest, they haven't balanced the base game features yet, so I'm not very hopeful on that. 
   [*][b]Languages[/b]:
   Courts have a court language. Not very important, but this feature exists. 
   Languages in itself are a pretty underused feature in general: First of all, you'll need a personal scheme to learn a language, it's gonna take ages and be kind of weird. Then, speaking a language could have far more useful effects. Also, for some reason PDX decided to ignore that most of medieval europe spoke latin and therefore, literally no one in medieval europe speaks latin. Great.
[/list]
When RC was announced, you might have expected some other features, such as court intrigue features and all kinds of celebrations, from feasts to coronations, funerals and weddings. Yeah, you'll get none of that. Btw, I made a mod to add weddings and it took just a few hours to make, but they had over one year to work on it and did nothing like that. 

Note that the coat of arms designer and the culture overhaul base game features and no reason to buy this DLC.
Should you buy it: Nope. Wait for some time and only buy it if its on sale, they've fixed at least the most obvious problems it has and delivered some missing content post release. Though I'm not sure if they'll ever do that.

Not good enough

All the people complaining Royal Court isn't worth the money haven't actually played the game.... 

SO MUCH content and SO MANY mechanics have been added with this expansion. And I'm not just talking about culture, which is pretty huge on its own. Most of the changes were introduced with little hype or fanfare: you only know they're there by playing the game. That's where the value of this expansion is imnsho. 

But the expansion is called ROYAL COURT. Paradox has been hyping the court to no end and it's the most visible thing they're selling. And the royal court itself is by far the weakest and most uninspired part of the expansion -- a HUGE missed opportunity. 

The mechanics and content behind the scenes add complexity and depth to the game. The royal court, on the other hand, stands out for its trivial, shallow mechanics. The court is so shallow mechanically, in fact, that I find it breaks immersion and detracts from the story making experience that CK3 is all about. Again, the court was an disastrous missed opportunity. It coulda, shoulda been so much more. 

CONCLUSION: I give Royal Court an equivocal thumbs up. Up because real depth HAS been added with this expac. Equivocal because its flagship feature -- royal court itself -- is little more than bells and whistles.

[h1] CK3: Royal Court is Not Worth The Price [/h1]

I'm just...a little bit confused. 
  I don't understand how the amount of time required to pull this DLC off was a worthwhile endeavour if this is all that's offered by the final experience?
  The actual content is fine, no problem with it really. It's just that it has quite a hefty price tag for a DLC of this size and what you do get would be better suited to a free update that launched alongside a DLC pack that actually changes up the gameplay a significant amount. As it is, Royal Court only really offers a distraction and can be completely ignored. Furthermore when you do engage in the royal court's systems, you'll more often than not come across an event sequence that penalises you for engaging with it, with an unbalanced number of choices that lead to penalties (often a resource, such as gold), which can feel like a punch in the gut when you're already struggling to balance income with the new costs that this content brings to the game (on top of every other expense you already have in vanilla CK3). 

I feel like the devs could have spent a lot more time fine tuning a experience people wouldn't want to ignore, if they didn't need to break apart and rebuild their code to make these 3D courts etc work. I would be more than happy with a set of 2.5D court screens, it's not like the 3D ones look particularly impressive. They certainly don't compare to the artist's renditions seen as backdrops for your ruler's portrait/character screen. 

What's also odd (aesthetically) is the inclusion of artefacts and treasures inside the court. It just looks blimin lame having peasants from the city come in and stand next to a precious and highly valuable treasure. When playing multiplayer I noticed a friend of mine had nabbed a valuable ring that when it was displayed in his court was represented by a pile of gold coins and gems that were on the floor by people's feet and looked like a splatter of vomit. I couldn't believe what I was seeing. 

So yeah, all that development time...That price tag...And yet the flavor pack held my attention far longer and was way more enjoyable. 

Good luck for the next DLC of this size, dev team.

Royal Court is a fine addition to CK3. I wish that more people than kings and emperors could have a court interface, and I think that is a big miss for the DLC. Overall though I enjoy it quite a bit, but the price point is definitely way off for the content added. Wait for a sale, as in don't buy this for over half off.

While this DLC adds nice court flavor for Feudal and Clan kings and emperors, it doesn't quite live up to the trailers and hype. Modders are already hard at work expanding the court features to include tribal rulers, weddings, and lesser courts; but that is a reminder that those features are not included by Paradox. The culture overhaul is very good and reflects history more than the previous idea of static "national" cultures. The new artifact system already comes with the ability to steal artifacts via the diplomacy skill tree.

Despite these good things, the flagship court systems introduced are too static, infrequent, repetitive, and too disconnected from court events outside of the court screen. Currently the base game 2d event screens feel more dynamic than the 3d court scene, since you currently have minimal control over court architecture, there is no artifact search function, the court fashion decision does not change what your courtiers wear, and food and servants do not appear. In sum, Royal Court feels like early access.

I would recommend this on sale if modders and Paradox expand the court features and framework with more unique events, scenes, and architecture. Since that hasn't happened yet, I would not recommend buying at full price.

Actual Review:
This DLC is good. I recommend it to anyone who likes CK 3, because I like the new features. The royal court is a good addition to the game. It needs more events and I am sure those will come. The new mechanic for cultures are interesting and create a more believable world, where peoples mixed on a regular basis.

Metatalk:
I rather play the game than writing a review. But this is DLC deserves a vote of confidence. Most negative reviews here are about the price and that is a disservice to the community. Everyone has to decide what their acceptable price is. You can argue all you want about fair prices. Nobody is forced to buy the DLC right now. Paradox DLCs are in sale very often. I recommend to everyone displeased about the price to do a bit of introspection, reflecting about whether they would have given a negative review, if all free content would be DLC-exclusive. Because technically that would improve the price performance measure.

Paradox could alter their strategy to make all new features free and create a digital supporter pack for each release instead of giving some features away for free and others in a paid DLC. Paradox could then charge whatever prices they see fit for such supporter packs and I will still buy them without any direct material benefit whatsoever. Although I might gain a miniscule amount of satisfaction over the lack of negative reviews from the casualized and entitled portion of the user base, who are besmirching the reputation of these great games captivating my attention over years.

Not only is this DLC not worth the price tag in regards to the content it adds, even if all of the content added as part of the free update that came with it was included in it, it still wouldn't be worth it. 

This DLC costs more than half as much as the base game, do you get half as much more content again? No. Do you get a  quarter as much? Again... no. A tenth as much? If you played every game specifically and solely trying to maximise your engagement with the mechanics added by this DLC (and thereby removing some of the base content by not touching tribals or rulers lower than King rank)... maybe you could argue this to be the case.

Beyond that, and I concede this is personal preference, the mechanics actually added by this DLC are... well they're not bad but they're honestly pretty meh. Let me put it this way. If I wanted to look at a bunch of awkwardly static people standing around a courtroom I'd go and play Mount and Blade, at least then there's the possibility of getting the visceral satisfaction of bashing some of their annoying heads in. The effort to reward ratio, and by reward I mean both mechanically and in regards to enjoyment, just isn't there for me.

The honchos that decided what would be the content of this expansion though it was a great idea to shape it around a 3D scene of the Royal Court, something the coders at Paradox don't technically master and as such, took a lot of resources to achieve. 

Besides the point that the 3D image is a useless trinket that could have been made in 2D in 1/20th of the time and that only serves as the background to a mildly interesting management feature of the court that is used as a kind of money sink - and it is unbalanced - the expansion has to offer a very good new cultural redesign, an unbalanced but necessary artifact system and more static events that soon will reach the stage of "been there, done that" to the prospective buyer. 

Events can be very good for the emergent story telling if they are well crafted, with different chances in the options based on different variables, with options that only appear half the time, with other options that are devised in a pool where one option is randomly picked to be presented and with options being present only if certain variables are present. Of all this, only the last technique is employed by Paradox, unfortunately. 
Also, events can have checks to not fire in X years, making their appearance more spaced out. In this way the same events can almost ever be different, interesting as presenting different dilemmas and not fire within a small amount of time.

Is the base CK3 game good? Yes, indeed. It is a great blank canvas Paradox must fill with content based on the sound foundations devised. Is the game worse with Royal Court? No, it's better. But...

All in all and compared with DLCs from CK2 like Holy Fury or Conclave that costed 20€, 
[u]Royal Court offers less content for 50% more of the price[/u]. Without particular considerations regarding my capability to pay the demanded price and desirability to have the full version of the game until the last DLC, my willingness to play the game completely modded and being to the point, it is an overpriced product. Cannot recommend.

If you're not an addict, get it when it's on sale. The only reason people are giving negative reviews is because it's still release-level buggy and a bit expensive for something that doesn't have any much-awaited Byzantium flavor. 

The court and culture mechanics are great though, and I don't think I can play without them now.

Price is a little steep for this expansion - but it adds a significant dimension to the game. Get it on sale perhaps. 
DLC is some what buggy still, although not game breaking. 
Variables load up incomplete, UX for inventory management is very clunky, feels like a draft. 
3D courts are a nice touch, but not really needed. 

Court system & cultures makes the mid game less of a grind and something to distract from the impending vassal and populist revolts every time you die. However, i think the snowballing may be even greater in the late game. Court roles don't seem to make a significant enough impact but it would suck if you're running ironman mode to be killed by your jester or to open more avenues for people to scheme against you. As though you do not have enough powerful vassals to manage..

Still interesting and gives the game a nice randomness, albeit an expensive one. Could say this just introduces a gambling system on artisans and adventurers. Hope the culture differences can lead to some interesting outcomes still.
I exect more for 30 european freedom bucks

Une extension décevante ... elle change légèrement le gameplay en rajoutant du divertissant mais ne change rien de plus.
Attendez qu'elle soit à 5€ pour la prendre.
Pour 30€ on aurait pu s'attendre à un nouveau continent ( amérique ?) une nouvelle ère ? de nouveaux scénarios en plus ... mais non, juste une salle du trône où l'interactivité reste minimale, où on ne peut interagir et surveiller les intrigues comme il était dit dans la bande annonce.

Le jeu de base sinon à un potentiel énorme ! Il est excellent et immersif. Il y a moyen d'en faire quelque chose de top !
Definitely not worth $30 but if you can get it on sale there's fun stuff to do.

I'm going to recommend this for the long game I plan to play with it - and that's riding on the modding community. As mentioned in other reviews, there are some brand new *systems* introduced with this that aren't part of the free patch. The modders have already started to put things together based on those systems. Over the long run, that's going to enhance my fun with the game. As for the "as-is" aspect of the DLC, I'm having fun with it. Yes, there are lots of randos entering my court with issues I'll see once and then never again. I happen to like that, and that's good for me. True, the court default view is clunky, and I'm limited to what I can hang on the walls and what I can display - my aspirations for becoming The British Museum are curtailed - but I do get the buffs from the gear, and I like that part. I don't play with animations, so I can't use the mod that allows a free camera in the court room, so I do miss out on that. 

The settings for my court stylez are disappointing. I just max them out, build a few more farms to support the cost, and I'm on cruise control to awesomeness. The higher levels should have something necessary to unlock them and occasional nerfs from judgmental churchmen or relatives about extravagance to keep them toned down from time to time. If those extravagances also boosted chances of peasant rebellions, then I'd have a reason to go more Spartan in my court. 

The culture blending is great, I love that part and I love taking time to add/remove/change elements of the culture I'm head of. There's a mod to add more culture slots over time, and I'm thinking of giving that one a go... and that puts me back where I started, planning out my long game with the DLC. 

Will the next DLC be US $30? That or more, quite likely. Will it be buggy on release and get better with patches? Undoubtedly. Will there be complaints that it doesn't do enough and, meanwhile, this other mechanic is unaddress? Absolutely. But... will the modders go crazy with it and create add-ons that make it all worth while? YES.

Let me repeat that last line: will the modders make it all worth while? YES.

Hence, my upwardly-displayed thumb.

This dlc is an absolute disaster, one after the other, not only is CK3 a primitive game that requires little skill from the player- something opposite of CK2, it has huge absence of quality and the game itself is ultimately 90% incomplete. Furthermore, the dlc has no huge qualities to provide the game with and in its entirety is over-priced for what you get, which is barely nothing.

This DLC was sold on the strength of its core feature: the Royal Court. 

On that score, it falls pretty flat.

We were told it would feel *immersive*. It's not. It's like looking at a lacklustre screenshot of The Sims 2 - minus most of the charm.

3D objects just aren't Paradox's bag, it seems. The thing is, there's no dynamism. If you increase your court spending, it looks the same. Decrease it, it looks the same. You can add objects, sure, but they're from a limited pool and most look the same as the next or very similar. This is what I really don't understand. We're Grand Strategy players, most - if not all of us - will love reading, and the descriptions for these randomised objects are vivid and charming. So why wasn't the Royal Court an interface like the personal inventory is?

Paradox claim it was the 3D court where they sunk all their time, but it's lifeless and vapid. Why didn't they pour all those resources into a brilliant 2D interface - rich in hundreds of 2D representations of court objects - with those colourful descriptions to accompany them? Think how many more events, object portraits, and other things that might have been created in the same time period?

Instead, we got a series of mannequins standing around a bland space that won't change in any meaningful way, which you have to leave the flow of the main game in order to even visit.

Give it a miss, I'd say. But I'm genuinely sorry to say it, because anything that expands the roleplay elements of this amazing game are welcome to me. I just think Paradox should stick to their strengths and do text-based and 2D-object work.

Plus most of the main features which I haven't mentioned are included in the free patch, so obviously I'm not going to review them here when you don't have to fork over $30 to use them! Fortunately, I bought the base game with all the trimmings when it first came out, so the cost was all factored in when I initially purchased it, which takes out the sting somewhat. I couldn't justify buying this separately at this price.

Frankly, I'm more excited to see what the total-conversion modders do with the template they've got! They'll ace the task, of that I'm sure! I can't say the same of Paradox anymore...

If you are on the fence wait for sale.

I got this DLC for a discount due to my having faith in Paradox when CK3 was announced. I'm not going to speak in depth about the huge delay between the release of the game and this (which is the first significant DLC/Update). Sike. In my view there really are no excuses for that, and any attempts at such are just inexplicable rallying to a company that cares more about its shareholders than its customers. To an extent this is reasonable, and I'm not in the Paradox management chair but this DLC really is god awful for what it is. Its price can only be justified by the bloated development time. 

I believe that there are certainly talented/inspired individuals at Paradox. However, they don't seem to be in control of the scope of long-term development for certain franchises any more (Imperator: Rome, EU 4, and now CK3 sadly). In fact, this experience is very similar to the release of the first (and only) major DLC for I:R albeit that CK3 had a much sturdier foundation. Yet Paradox management seems to have decided that resources where better spent elsewhere as content has been lacking. Northern Lords was an interesting yet minor DLC. However, does it make sense that it took half a year for that to go live? 

Paradox decided to split their dev studios not too long ago and I believe this is the result. Some are good, but some are struggling. The content from the one's that are struggling are seemingly becoming only more hollow and/or incomplete (i.e.  lacking quality control). 

TL;DR THIS SHIT (dlc is not awful but ok at best) IS NOT WORTH 30 OF WHATEVER YOUR LOCAL CURRENCY IS! Wait till it's 50% off for a fair price tbh

Ironically the best part of this DLC is the culture rework and not the royal courts. Royal courts feel underdeveloped due to strange decisions such as no courts for tribal rulers of any kind. Lack of regional flavour for 3D assets and events. Very few events and some of these events requiring conditions to be met, which cuts down the event pool significantly. You will see the same events repeating within a single rulers lifetime (I've gotten the mayor rivalry event multiple times in a row). no real consequences for ignoring your court (Why would I even bother holding court when most of the events lead to negative outcomes when I could just instead refuse to hold court). And just feeling isolated from the rest of the game. Engaging with your court currently isn't worth it. Artifacts are okay but there needs to be a system to either destroy or sell unwanted artifacts to deal with inventory overload.

So I actually made the mistake of buying this DLC, even though everyone was saying it wasn't worth 30 dollars I decided fuck it I want some new features and to support Paradox. Ever since I got it my dynastys have been dropping like flies from natural causes even as children and its more buggy and laggy then it was before.

Pay 30 dollars to make the game worse, your choice.

This latest addition to the Crusader Kings saga is a typical example of Paradox's tendency to create content that is lopsided, disjointed and half-baked. If this was an indie outfit making a game on a shoestring budget it would be understandable, but this is a major games developer ten years down the line in a best-selling series who had an opportunity to draw from deep well of player and modder input but instead keeps rehashing the same fundamental errors again and again: abysmal writing (Holy Fury's sainthood line was painful and the devilry of Monks & Mystics was farcical, but at least we didn't have so much in the way of unavoidable fart jokes and meme-baiting pop culture references), poor research and commitment to the setting, woefully unbalanced mechanics, scope overextension (creating vastly more breadth than depth), and features that were clearly developed separately and do not work in concert or are awkwardly inserted into systems for which they were not designed (see the 'language learning' element of the new cultural system, which has been jankily inserted into the 'scheme' mechanic). Where is the pre-release quality control? Such issues with the development culture are thrown into stark relief by the output of unpaid, amateur modders -- some working on their own! -- who continually show up the official Paradox sub-Renaissance Fair content with imaginative, engaging and soulful work.

This DLC is shallow. The latest of Paradox's ambitious, hyped-up ideas which turn out to be poorly executed is the titular royal court. The devs have put a considerable amount of time and effort into getting a 3D physical room in-game; however, this is revealed to be not much more than a visual gimmick, and an at-times ugly and buggy one at that: clipping issues abound, and as a jumble of artefacts are put on display in the middle of the room the court feels less of a functional, lived-in reception area than a poorly-curated art gallery. The royal court is neither necessary, nor particularly interesting; and as the courts don't really differ in any substantial way except appearance and the odd eunuch, once you've seen one court, you've basically seen them all. This is ironic given the effort also put into the new culture system, but since that also essentialises rich and complex cultures into dull, arbitrary building blocks that can be changed on a whim with sufficient mana, you should expect more memetic weirdness than any real-world flavour.

On a personal note, as an historian it pains me to keep seeing media that has something to say about history, but doesn't actually seem to be interested in the field of history itself: most of what it does say is not just wrong, but fundamentally misunderstands the process of history and the basics of anthropology, let alone the material culture of its subjects. At this point I would much rather Paradox stop making games with an historical setting, and instead start doing whatever they like in a fantasy world of their own devising. This would allow the developers the creative freedom that they clearly desire, while freeing them of the difficult work of attempting any kind of historical verisimilitude.

Indeed, there are so many basic 'didn't do their research' moments in this DLC: just off the top of my head, this includes (but is not limited to) the lack of the 'Refined Poetry' tradition in any of the Arabic cultures (despite poetry being the most celebrated and omnipresent art form of medieval Arab culture); to the cold, bare stone walls of the Northern/Western European throne rooms (even the most spendthrift monarch would have at least plastered and whitewashed his walls); to the completely un-medieval (and sometimes immature and immersion-breaking) attitudes present in a significant number of event texts.

Pop history media makes my job so much harder. I was initially grateful that the Crusader Kings series had given people greater awareness of Islamic civilisation; I am less keen now that I am aware that the cost of basic name recognition is a growing pile of inane nonsense. Avoid this DLC unless it is a necessary prerequisite of one of the several exceptional total conversion mods available for CK3 (and on sale) -- after all, the lively modding community has extraordinary facility of taking broken Paradox ideas and turning them into gold.

It IS good, but WAIT for a sale.

I have never written a Steam review before, so that should tell you how much this DLC has pushed me to do so.

Is the Royal Court DLC fun? Does it add enjoyable content?

I would say yes to both.

HOWEVER! The price they are asking ($33.99 in my locale) is nearly extortionate, in my opinion. Had I not gotten Royal Court through my ownership of the CK3 Royal edition, I would be requesting a refund. 

The royal court and its associated functions can be useful. The artefacts in particular can be a great way to boost dynastic reknown income. The actual court itself feels like, essentially a cosmetic expression at most - Like being able to see my characters clothes. Aesthetic only. The actual royal court tasks feel boring, same-y, and a chore. The new court positions, like master of horse or jester or architect really should have been base content. The culture changes are the big draw, in my opinion but are not world changing.

To sum up, is this content worth paying for? Yes and no. Royal Court is a blend of content that should have been either included in the base game, free content addition, and the remainder paid for... at about $10 max.

So far ck3 has seen alot more love by the developers than pervious games. 
Royal Court is a really good dlc, and it shows they really listened to the reviews of bad dlc cashgrab.
It's not a huge amount of content but, the content changes alot.
Its is something you will have every playthrough, it is always relevant. And pretty instrumental into roleplay.

The cultures system: changing the cultures to make your culture feel more how you want them to be OR what you need on paper, makes it a mainstay is every long playthrough. Before prestige was something u saved at the start of the game, until you hit a point where you are massing 5K, 8K, 10+k prestige and it seemed like a stupid resource. It makes sense that the king, the head of a culture could sway its folks into certain beliefs and directions if he had enough gravitas and importance. 
The royal court: The inventory is another really baseline mechanic, that intregrates the artifacts system from ck2 very well. You can get these in many manners. Now the royal court itself is personally a very nice addition:
As a player who is 50/50 roleplay tactics, i won't always be looking at it and i sometimes wished it was tuned to annoy you less during times of war. On the otherhand, you sometimes get impatient and want to blast 5X speed to get that amount of gold you need for a title, building, holding, etc... It creates a nice breather, that makes it feel a little more like a CK game.

So the thing is, in any other game this mechanic would be bs. It works for ck3.

I think personally the reviews are a little too harsh. See it like this:
CK3 unlike europe universalis, vic2, hoi4... is not a tactics grand strategy, it is not a resource management game.
Many of you will enjoy the game however, as a medieval military strategy game. And good for you!
I think if you see ck3 as it's supposed to be this DLC will be a no-brainer

Some people have complained about the price of this DLC, but I think it's worth every cent. 

The way cultures have been modeled is very realistic and nuanced, and I can see that a lot of work has been put into defining the cultures and how they interact with each other. In addition to cultures forming historical sub-groups, each culture has a "cultural acceptance" for every other other culture that varies by culture. You can convert (or cleanse, if you prefer) lands to your culture, but then the original culture will gradually start to hate you. Alternatively, you could increase the other culture's acceptance to your culture, and even end up creating a hybrid of the two cultures. 

The royal court and artifacts are good money sink for your gold and provide things to do in the mid game, while waiting for your culture to discover new things. I laughed my arse off when I hired a foreign artisan to design my throne and it ended up looking totally out of place.

All in all, this DLC is a must-have for CK3. You can wait until it gets cheaper, but trust me, you will end up buying it if you you play this game, and IMO it's worth the research and love that has been put into it.

Think of the games you can buy with €30 on Steam and this price is outrageous. I have seen DLC worth €15 with 4 times as many features as this one. Even if you have plenty of money to spend I still don't recommend buying this DLC because it's frankly a grave insult to loyal fans. In fact, you can almost entirely ignore the royal court features (except maybe court grandeur) and be just fine during your playthrough. My faith in the Paradox DLC policy has once again plummeted.
OVERPRICED
It's buggy, REALLY BUGGY. And mechanically disappointing and not worth the money. Don't make my mistake DO NOT BUY. The game is literally worse off for this DLC.
10 out of 10 DLC for sure. a must have!
worth it

I was expecting more, the addition is nice, but it feels lacking.
viykvgtik
Great DLC. The court itself is beautiful and they did a great job with the cultures and court languages.

Bastante bueno, sinceramente. En el Steam de Perú el costo a la tasa de cambio actual es de aproximadamente 14 dólares. Por dicho precio, vale totalmente la pena adquirirlo. yeeeah honestly I'm enjoying it but moreso because of how it breaks everything
the dlc really doesn't add much, you could say the whole culture reformation and divergence thing should've been part of the free update because it makes more sense than for the dlc (but you have to sell, right? almost as if the main feature was kinda bland)

Speaking of which
the main feature of the dlc is honestly bland and uninteresting. The first time you get your courtroom you'll feel excited and hyped to see all the royal stuff you can do (keyword royal as dukes don't get courts, neither do tribals so good luck to those who expected a nice looking viking court) you can "hold court" once every 5 years and what that does is spawn random court events that can either help you or be mild annoyances (and also there's no penalty for never ever holding court so what's the point then??? lmao. Like seriously you get random court events whether or not you hold court so you're just saving 75 prestige by not doing it)

And the court amenities
it's hilariously easy to manage the upkeep, my court outshined the one from byzantium purely because I made more money monthly. And you want to prioritize monthly income because the bonuses you get from splendour are really good

Oh yeah, that's also a thing. You'll get random events that you won't actually read after the first time. Seriously they scripted like 20 and that's it (and it's the same no matter your culture or location as long as you're a feudal king) someone should count them
and the whole courtroom isn't varied at all you're locked to a default style according to your culture group so the only thing you can actually "customize" is whatever you want to show in your lil museum room which really isn't much, every slot is reserved for a specific kind of artifact

something really odd too sometimes the courtroom will tank all of your framerate and sometimes it'll run smoothly. I think you boys could've used a few more days to polish it

The artifacts thing is cool but also incredibly annoying, you wanna take a rare artifact? oh wait nevermind you didn't know such thing existed but you randomly got it in a single siege along 7 different low tier artifacts to the point that your inventory is scuffed with random stuff you found
random stuff that you can't destroy and the "gift artifact option" for some reason is restricted

And also, I've been messing with cultures like a madman to test the dlc to its full might and I'm a bit disappointed in the culture fusion feature
as for the reform culture yeah that one's the best. Anyway
they showed us examples of cultures that existed from fusions like the normans, the english and whatnot
but when you merge cultures in the game (which by the way can take you more than one lifetime if you don't have a good steward) rreally isn't that interesting

-you get innovations from both culutes (like if you're norse and you merge with greek you'll get a bunch of innovations for free)
-you get to pick the character naming, the styles of coat of arms (which is pointless because in ck3 EVERY COA looks the same aside from the inner designs)
-you get to pick the name and map colour 
-only a few counties will convert, yes you have to wait like 10 years per county which is a bummer (did I say wait? I meant promoting culture because counties never convert at will like they did in ck2. Awesome to preserve cultures in your realm, but terrible if you wanna have an efficient demense because you get reduced taxes from wrong cultures)
But when you do fuse, very little changes. You might be tinking "AWESOME I CAN CUSTOMIZE MY COA AND MY KINGDOM'S COA with the little soldier displaying how your troops will look like. And then, when you do create your own new culture you can't customize much of it, only the map display and name (which by the way can only be set ONCE, so if you don't like the colour there's nothing you can do about it). The naming feature is weird, as I mentioned earlier you have to choose either one or both

So you can have characters named Björn or Nikomenos in a same family, which is a bit funny, it'd be cool to set our own like "default list" of names like culture groups instead of getting forced into those 2 you have
oh by the way, speaking of either one of those, the lil soldiers you see on your map? you can only choose 1 style, and that's permanent, for example either norse or greek. You can't customise that one like at all


Tl:dr?
The main feature is really bland, sorry paradox I know you missed on december to polish this as much as you could but you really didn't make that one feature that interesting
The culture features that I'm betting were stripped from the free update to the dlc are kinda worth it
gives it a lot of roleplay value (lacking some customisation but still about enough, there are unique culture names you can create like Burgundian, Austrian, Rhinelander, etc. I did a run as burgundy and that one felt really nice)
Worth buying?
Yeah you might want to wait for a discount on this one, it's good to have sure
but for that price it's a no-no
specially since its main feature doesn't hit the spot
Un buen DLC que complementa la estética de juego y entrega algunas mecánicas nuevas con las culturas, artefactos y la corte.

Wirklich ein sehr schwaches Update bzw. DLC. Ich habe die Royal Edition gekauft, demnach musste ich nehmen was ich kriege. Ansonsten wäre mir schon nach den ersten Dev. Diaries klar gewesen, dass ich dieses DLC nicht für den vollen Preis kaufe. Das erste große DLC und die Entwickler legen eine großes Augenmerk auf ein kosmetisches Feature. Der Hof ist an sich eine wirklich gute Idee, aber zu diesem Zeitpunkt schlicht erbärmlich umgesetzt. Repetetive Abläufe ohne Tiefe, es geht nur um Modifier. Die Events wiederholen sich bereits nach 6-7 Hoftagen. Dem Spiel fehlt noch so viel Tiefe, dahingehend hat sich leider nur sehr wenig bis gar nichts geändert. Für 10€ würde ich darüber nachdenken, es zu kaufen.
This DLC makes a good game better, I can't think of no real complaints

Essa expansão dá muito mais fundo ao jogo. Podem criticar Royal Court por não adicionar cortes aos duques e títulos menores que rei, mas os mods lançados podem acrescentam isso. Apesar disso, é uma expansão que aumenta muito a diversão do jogo com o sistema de artefatos, cargos da corte, culturas, idiomas e os modelos 3D. Mal posso esperar pelas próximas expansões com novas eras, eventos e roupas.
very lacklustre for such an expensive dlc. Cultures having some depth to them is nice, but the court and language add nothing to gameplay.
overpriced and only adds one feature
£23.79 is tooooo much just wait for a sale

Pretty massive rip off for 30$. Barely adds any actual gameplay content and what it does add just becomes annoying and repetitive after not long. Sad that this is what theyre doing for the free pre order dlc and charging 30$

I've got about 100 hours in this DLC content alone. One thing I have noticed in the reviews is complaints about the price and the lack of features that are added to make it worth the price. This has some truths, it does feel like the content added to the game is somewhat limited with this DLC. What is missing from this story is the versatility of the new cultures system that is the main content added here. It is clear the ck3 team has a vision of customization and versatility for the future of the game and this shows in the culture additions. It also gives players much needed uses for prestige, comparable to religious reformation using piety. 

Should you buy this DLC for 30 dollars. Maybe not based on just its own merits. But I foresee it being an essential DLC in the years to come, with its versatile system likely interacting with future DLC and providing lots of content. So I would wait for a sale and get this.

If you like the RP aspects of the game then its worthwhile based on its own merits, and can add much needed flavor to ck3.

[h1]DLC-Review:

Crusader Kings III: 

Royal Court[/h1]

"Crusader Kings III" ist eine typische Paradox Grand-Strategy-Simulation.

CKIII deckt den Zeitraum von 867 bis 1453 ab, der Vernichtung Byzanz, dem Fall Konstantinopels der das Ende des europäischen Mittelalters markiert. Als Startpunkt kann man neben 867 auch 1066 wählen, das Jahr der berühmten Schlacht bei Hastings, in der Wilhelm der Eroberer den Grundstein für die normannische Herrschaft über England legte und damit das gesamte europäische Gefüge neu austarierte. Aber spielen können wir nicht nur als europäische Großmacht. Die Karte schließt im Osten Indien und die Steppenvölker ein, reicht bis an die Grenze des chinesischen Reiches. Im Süden reicht die über das Horn von Afrika hinaus bis zum (auch spielbaren) Mogadischu. 

Und spielen können wir jeden Herrscher (ab der Größe eines Grafen). Ob als ghanaischer König, als indischer Maharadscha, als Graf von Augsburg oder als uplandischer Jarl. Lediglich Theokratien und Republiken sind (noch) nicht spielbar.

Paradox deckt mit seinen historischen Titeln jeweils eine bestimmte Epoche ab. Die herausragende Qualität von diesen Paradox-Titeln liegt in der Erkenntnis, daß jede Epoche eigener Mechaniken bedarf, für jede Epoche eigene politische Agenden wichtig waren, Mentalitäten und gesellschaftliche Strukturen in der Geschichte grundverschieden waren. Damit begreift Paradox Diskurse, die etwa durch Michel Foucault ("Die Ordnung der Dinge") wesentlich befeuert wurden. Er geht (vereinfacht beschrieben) davon aus, daß jede Epoche einen Zentralpunkt des Denkens hatte. War es im Mittelalter etwa die Religion, tritt in der Neuzeit der Mensch als Individuum in den Fokus. Aus diesem Zentralpunkt ergeben sich dann als Ausfluß wesentliche gesellschaftliche, kulturelle und politische Strukturen.

Dieses Prinzip hat Paradox schon seit ihren ersten Titeln begriffen und inkanalisiert, was sie auch wesentlich von anderen Entwicklern unterscheidet, die diese strukturelle Denkleistung nicht vollzogen haben. 

Mittelalter. Das wichtigste hier: die Dynastie und die Religion. Das Konzept der großen Nationalstaaten existiert noch nicht. Kaiser und Könige besitzen nicht das ganze Land über das sie herrschen, sondern haben stets begrenzte Macht über ihr Vasallen. Und so können wir denn auch immer nur eine begrenzte Anzahl an Provinzen selbst besitzen. Kommen wir über das Limit, müssen wir empfindliche Mali ertragen. Also geben wir eroberte Provinzen lieber an andere Charaktere, an unseren Sohn zum Beispiel und stellen so sicher, daß die Provinz erstmal in der Machtsphäre unserer Dynastie bleibt. 

Jeder Charakter hat eine Reihe von Werten wie Diplomatie oder Verwaltung und eine Reihe von Eigenschaften, Tugenden und Sünden. Hinzu kommt ein neues Schwerpunktsystem, in dem wir uns auf einen Fokusbaum konzentrieren können und unseren Charakter, der stets schon mit erblichen Dispositionen ausgestattet ist, so in eine bestimmte Richtung entwickeln können. 

Überhaupt ist die Charakterentwicklung, das rollenspielerische, relevanter und umfänglicher geworden. Zentrale Charaktereigenschaften sind durch den Avatar direkt sichtbar. Stolze Charaktere etwa tragen die Nase hoch, unmäßige neigen zu Fettleibigkeit.

Zentral wichtig ist auch nach wie vor der Kampf und die Diplomatie. Bündnisse werden durch Heiratspolitik geschmiedet. Stehende Heere gibt es noch nicht, sondern alle Truppen müssen erst ausgehoben werden. Sehr gut ist das neue System der Ritter, relevanter Einzelkämpfer und der Einheiten wie Pikeniere oder Bogenschützen, die wir zu den üblichen Bauerntruppen rekrutieren können. 

Überhaupt wurde vieles entschlackt, einiges auch vereinfacht und übersichtlicher gemacht. CKIII konzentriert sich auf wesentliche Mechaniken, wie Krieg oder Intrigen, streicht aber auch einige Mechaniken des Vorgängers. Insgesamt tut das der Reihe aber gut, denn alles ist konsequenter, fokussierter und logischer geworden. Die an einigen Ecken noch vermißte Komplexität wird sicher paradoxüblich über die Jahre noch reichlich ausgebaut werden. 

Viele Mechaniken könnte man noch beschreiben. Die Vermächtnisse etwa, die unseren Dynastiesprößlingen schon bei Geburt einen Bonus geben oder das neue System der Druckmittel, mit dem wir andere Charaktere beeinflussen, uns aber auch selber in der Hand eines Anderen wiederfinden können. Auch die vervielfältigten Religionen und die Möglichkeit selber eine Religion zu gründen, sind überzeugend. Es fehlen aber Systeme des Vorgängers wie Artefakte oder auch das System der Seuchen. Auch der Ausbau der Provinzen ist eher simpel gehalten.

Bei allem Detailkram sei nun aber mal deutlich gesagt: CKIII ist großartig. Noch ist es eine fokussierte Basis, die schon verdammt viel Spaß macht, überzeugend funktioniert und sich als ein wunderbarer endloser Geschichtengenerator erweist. Die Geburt ist mehr als gelungen. Die angelegten Strukturen sind besser denn je, die Bedienbarkeit weitaus übersichtlicher geworden. Bugs gibt es nur wenige irrelevante. Und wenn auch das Kind noch Erfahrung braucht, sich noch entwickeln muß, der Sprößling ist jetzt schon ein Genie. 

Anders gesagt: CKIII ist zum Niederknien überzeugend gut geworden und wird sich im Laufe seiner Entwicklung ohne Frage zum besten Grand-Strategy-Spiel aller Zeiten mausern. 

Ein Meisterstück. 

Das DLC "Royal Court" kommt - paradoxüblich - zusammen mit einem riesigen Patch, der neue Spielmechaniken einführt, die durch das DLC noch ausdifferenzierter beeinflußbar werden. 

Zentral scheint der erstmals dreidimensional dargestellte Hof, in dem sich alle wichtigen Mitglieder des eigenen Hofes wiederfinden, in dem man Artefakte, Banner und Möbel ausstellen kann, seine Hofsprache und Hofart festlegen kann und in dem es Ereignisse geben kann, die unsere Entscheidung verlangen. Allerdings ist der Hof nur für Könige und Kaiser verfügbar. Interessant ist die Hofpracht, die mindestens einem Erwartungswert entsprechen sollte, um diverse Boni abzugreifen. Bei vier Hofannehmnlichkeiten - Mode, Verpflegung, Unterbringung und Dienerschaft - können wir entscheiden, wieviel Geld es uns Wert ist, die Hofpracht zu steigern. 

So interessant und optisch primär der Hof auf den ersten Blick wirkt, für mich ist er nicht der einzig relevante Teil des DLCs. So oft wird man die 3D-Ansicht auch gar nicht nutzen. Zudem merkt man, daß Paradox hier ein Modul einführt, das noch einigen Raum für Erweiterung und Ausdifferenzierung bietet. 

Fast wichtiger scheinen mir die neuen kulturellen und mechanischen Möglichkeiten, die uns auch in niedrigeren Rängen zur Verfügung stehen. Es gibt einige neue Hofämter, die zu besetzen sind. Der Erzzeugwart kann persönliche Artefakte zu Hofartefakten umschmieden. Als Vasall können wir unserem König huldigen oder eine Petition an ihn richten.

Wir haben deutlich mehr Einflußmöglichkeiten auf unsere Kultur. Als Kulturoberhaupt können wir Traditionen wechseln. Wir können auch eine neue Kultur entwickeln, indem wir uns von unserer bisherigen Kultur abspalten. Wir können auch neue Mischkulturen bilden und so die sinnvollsten Vorteile zweier Kulturen verschmelzen. Auch ein neues Vermächtnis, das sich auf den Spracherwerb bezieht, kommt hinzu.

Der DLC bietet einen netten 3D-Hof, er bietet aber vor allem eine große Menge an neuen Mechaniken, die vor allem für den Roleplay-Aspekt des Spieles eine Fundgrube für neue Geschichten bietet. Dadurch entwickelt das DLC den zentralen und wesentlichen Bestandteil von Crusader Kings, nämlich den historischen Story-Generator, sinnvoll und facettenreich weiter und vertieft dadurch das Hauptspiel.

Noch immer ist Crusader Kings III weit davon entfernt, die ihm mögliche Komplexität auszuschöpfen, aber die Schritte auf dem Weg dorthin sind deutlich und bestimmt. Immerhin hat der Vorgänger auch zehn Jahre Entwicklung genossen, bis er zu dem bekannten Komplexitätsmonster mutiert ist

Ótimo jogo porém só vou recomendar quando houver tradução para português.

"BRAZILIAN PORTUGUESE TRANSLATION NOW"

Love it. You can play this game for 1000s of hours and you can play other similarly priced games for 8-100 hours. This seems like a no-brainer for me. Everyone knows Paradox games get better over time and this is already great.

The new update for CK 3 was big. It adds much depth to the culture mechanics, reintroduces the artifact system from CK 2, and brings us a completely new royal court mechanic. 
The problems start when you realize that the DLC consists only of the court, hybrid cultures, and cultural reforms. Everything else is available after a free update. And even then, the free update has a feature that partially replaces the functionality of cultural reformation.
So in the end, the 30 $ DLC gives us a 3D static court, which is available only for kings and emperors, and in which you can't freely move the camera. An ability to create hybrid or diverted cultures, which I don't have really used so far. And cultural reformation which functionality is partly replaced by a feature from the free update.
Is it worth 30 $ (half the price of the full game!!!)?  Everyone should decide for themselves, but I would say no. It is however worth the additional 15$ I spent on the Royal edition.

Shoulda been 15 bucks, 30 bucks on top of this wait is kind of atrociously bad. The expansion is findamentally decent- in line with what you might expect from an average CK2 expansion, but again, for twice the usual price. I cannot really recommend this unless you are buying it half-off or you are REALLY starved for achievement-friendly content in this game.

Ich finde die Erweiterung gut, denn sie lässt einen tiefer in das Hofgeschehen eintauchen. Und ehrlich: ich mag es tatsächlich "Hof zu halten" und dann mal die ganzen sonstigen Aufgaben zu vergessen. Ist es das 30 Euro wert? Nein. Aber ich finde, mit dem Kultursystem bekommt man etwas geboten. Leider ist die KI immer noch strunzdoof und lungert rum. Da erwarte ich einfach mehr. Selbst bei einem Bündniskrieg, wo man selber einen "Gefallen" erweist, wie Nordmannische Eroberungskriege, verhaart die KI wie ein Trottel und greift nur an, wenn es um das "Kriegsgebiet" geht. Sehr schwach, aber auch sehr durchschaubar. Schön finde ich die zahlreichen Hofämter, sogar mehr und logischer als CK2. Aber die Kosten und resultierenden Entscheidungen machen es noch mal schwieriger - wobei, kann auch manchmal gut sein. Mit einem Pass war es eine gute Entscheidung. Ich hoffe, dass dieses Spiel noch lange unterstützt wird - es ist weiterhin mein Favorit. Mein Wunsch wären noch viele Lieder aus dem damaligen CK2 - aber wer weiß?
This is a very good expansion. The Royal court tuff makes it easier for me to roleplay this thing. It will make the replayable value of this much higher. Great Work Paradox!
This DLC really improves on the base game and gives you a way to spend currency if you become too powerful. Seemingly reduces the AI map painting "late" in the game.

I love CK3 and I like this DLC, but even if it was much cheaper I would still be disappointed, because there are so many things that could be added to really improve game play, but this is not it. Its fun, it gives me more flavor to the game, but it does not expand the scope of the game or how I play it.

Finally, it terms of balance, CK3 is the most fun for me when it is challenging, so I like dealing with the costs of the court, and I am currently trying to use the court to legitimate my young bastard queen who is surrounded by internal enemies, but this feels so small for a DLC.
One of the best DLCs ever.
Precio muy inflado para lo poco que añade este DLC tan básico.  Más vale que las siguientes expansiones añadan nuevas capas de estrategia y complejidad, por 30 eur, no podemos esperar menos.

This DLC isn't worth $30.  Save your money and wait for a sale, or for them to add some much needed content to it.

I do not recommend it at all. I only have it because of the CK3 Royal Edition. 

Look, the free patch content? Great stuff, everyone should be happy. But the DLC itself is pathetic. The devs said they wanted to do bigger, more meaningful expansions and here, the flagship feature of a $30 product, is one room with a bunch of events that you are better off ignoring since they do more harm than good. And the worst thing? You can completely ignore the court and there will be no real impact on the gameplay Compared to Stellaris' first DLC, Utopia, at this price tag this is embarrassing. The throne room does not seem to be implemented well. Before, I could play the game from mostly one screen, now I feel torn away while I look at a room that simply feels like an excuse to use the 3d models they created. While its certainly not bad, its also not very good.
And given the long wait and the high price i cannot hide the fact i am disappointed.
The awesome modding-community will or in some cases already has, solve a lot of those issues, but the vanilla dlc is lackluster.

I do have to preface this by saying that, as I bought the royal edition, I got the DLC at the same time as the free update so what is part of what is a bit murky for me.
That being said, this is a real game-changer. 
Sure, most of the content of the DLC is only relevant if you are playing as a king or an emperor, the culture aspects can be relevant otherwise especially if you are set somewhere between two cultures or conquer a different culture (for instance, through a Varangian adventure). For the characters the DLC is relevant to, however, this Expansion really makes the game come alive. 
Before this expansion I still had the feeling, much like I did (and still sorta do) with Imperator, that CK3 was still not a full game. Sure, it was fun, but a bit lackluster, especially when compared to CK2. And CK2 also has the problem that your court really doesn't mean much. Even with the council having to approve your actions, it was more of a game of making opinion numbers go up to be able to do stuff (and sometimes killing some vassals whose numbers refused to go up ;). 
This expansion solves both issues. The entire culture mechanic makes for truly interesting gameplay, havint to choose whether it's worth it to hybridize a culture to make your realm more manageable but making conquest of your old culture a bit harder, choosing whether or not to conquer somewhere with a different culture that is going to be a hassle to manage, and so on. It makes me excited to see if they do a religion revamp, as a similar possibility of religion syncretism (as historically happened, for instance, between Muslims and Hindus in northern India) could make the game more interesting in that aspect too. In regard to the court itself, and the artifacts, people are very right to point out the lack of visual changes. The court does change it's look when changing grandeur levels, but the changes are so subtle they can easily go unnoticed. However, I don't exactly play paradox titles for the looks, but for the game, and the court events and artifacts are very good at telling a story and making gameplay more varied. It is very interesting, for example, when you pay someone to make you a sword and your wife, who knows nothing about fighting, decides she want's to give an opinion on how it's made, and you have to choose between making her sad or getting a worse sword. The court positions are, for me, the star of the Expansion. The fact that the courtier's abilities are relevant to their position and that they truly change the game, be it by giving you bonuses or by allowing you different decisions, really stands out against CK2's court positions that merely made people happier. And courtiers may get mad if you give a position to someone they consider less important, which makes juggling expectations something that you actually have to do.
Overall, this Expansion is worth it. It is a bit expensive, and maybe it should have been part of the base game, but I do think it is a great expansion and a step in the right direction to make CK3 really stand out among paradox titles and grand strategy games in general.

Although I like the content introduced (in general), there are too many problems for me to recommend it at the $34 price.

To begin, the crashes. I had over 300 hours in CK3 before this DLC came out and I had only had it crash on me once. Since the new update and DLC, the game only starts up properly about a third to a half of the time on first try. Not only that, but I have had 3 crashes while playing for seemingly no reason, which is extremely frustrating when the game takes like 15 minutes to load up again. Related to this is the hardware-intensiveness of the actual Royal Court. Now, my computer isn't anything crazy, but it is a good computer and doesn't have any problems running CK3 normally. But I dread going into the Royal Court for any reason because it is so laggy and poorly optimized compared to the rest of the game, that it is agonizing to hold court, add decorations, or even just appreciate the admittedly nice looking art.

There is a lot to enjoy about this update, with the wealth of new events to keep the game fresh being my personal favourite, but it doesn't add enough for the price and needs a lot of optimization and stabilization before I can recommend it. Also, add some sort of court for Tribal leaders you cowards!

The 3D scenes allows the player to feel even closer to their characters and care more about whay happens in the game. CK3 was always an amazing story generator, but now we have more reasons of why we should care for the characters and their stories. Not the most complex PDX game, but the most personal.
pretty good expansion pack
I mean it's not a bad DLC but it is EXTREMELY overpriced, plus a bunch of stuff(Courtroom weddings) that we saw in the trailers are just not there so thats kinda dissapointing
A year and a half has passed, and there is almost no content. Why don't developers sell the engine to modmakers instead of selling the game?
How did this take a year and a half to make? I could do better unfortunately.
Really like this DLC and all the flavor it adds, granted the price is pretty steep for what it is.
It's a nice addition to the game still coming in at 30€ it's not worth it.
The content is fun but does not merit a £25 price tag
Not worth 30 euro. Not at all.

This DLC is focused on graphics with very little actual content. Not only the few features they introduced aren't interesting and feel disconnected from the rest of the game, but it's not even that good on the graphical aspect which is supposed to be what they focused on. The graphics are very basic, to the point that they didn't implement a free camera to avoid the players looking in details at how bad it is, and they also introduced a new bug, making every portrait look awful. This is something immediately noticeable as soon as you start the game and it's especially annoying considering it was added in a DLC focused on graphics. This is only the tip of the iceberg as the game is riddled with bugs since the DLC was released, and a week later there is still no hotfix including for the major ones and very little communication on this. 

The culture rework is nice, but not as game-changing as you would think. It's very easy to not interact with it at all.

Lastly, this is extremely overpriced. I got it through the Royal Edition on which I had a very good deal, and I still feel scammed. The DLC would be alright if it had been for half the price, without the bugs and if it hadn't been the first DLC of the game, but in its current state, it's just not worth it.

Here's a basic summary of everything the DLC adds:

Dynamic Cultures: Adds tiny stat changes and opinion modifiers you can basically ignore. Changing or customizing cultures is basically only relevant very late game when you have nothing better to use your prestige on. 

Visually Modeled Courts: Watch a series of bland static images play out in a court room that looks functionally identical to every other court around you regardless of your wealth or power. You can't customize anything substantial, it adds nothing visually to the events other than the occasional character model standing motionless in front of you, and you'll basically just ignore the screen until you're forced to interact with a random popup event. Want to watch feasts, weddings, assassination attempts, executions, coronations, and more? Well maybe one day you can spend another $30 to see those things, for now you're out of luck.

New Events: Every new event pretty much comes down to a single choice between a few options where you just pick the one with the best chance of randomly landing on a good result. Watch as you're forced to make countless inconsequential dice rolls that usually just affect your popularity in a random county or make a certain mayor you didn't know existed slightly mad at you, and basically nothing else.

Artifacts: Constantly accrue more minor stat changes attached to copy-and-paste junk that is tedious to get rid of. Only a few of the historic / legendary artifacts offer any kind of interesting bonuses, but getting them is purely random chance. There also seems to be a grand total of 5 different artifact models in the game to show off. Who knew the Iron Crown of the Lombards looked exactly the same as the cheap copper one I paid a random metal smith to make for 20 bucks?

Grandeur: What could be more dynamic and fun than constantly pay some of your gold income for more minor stat changes? Yup, that's pretty much all it is. 

Overall, the Royal Court experience was bland, uninspired, and left the gameplay feeling essentially unchanged. Even if you're a hardcore fan of CK (like I am), I would still avoid buying this DLC for anything more than about 5 bucks, certainly not for 30.

I love CK3, the base game. The Royal Court expansion is very disappointing. First, the update broke my saved game, forcing me to restart. The court system gets boring and annoying fast. I wish you could turn it off or ignore it, but there are penalties for not managing your court.

I have to say I don't see any reason to complain. Sure some things could be further improved but that is critique on really high standarts. The dlc is great and the update that goes together with it is as well.
And 30 euros for content this polished is well deserved as well if you ask me.

The real reason the DLC feels like too little for the price is that Paradox continues its tradition of making most of the underlying systems that support new DLC part of a free update for all owners of the game. So yeah, a bunch of stuff has been added to the game for free, and if you're concerned about raw bang for your buck, wait for a sale - but if you love CK and want to have full access to all the latest systems working together, just drop the $30. Either way is fine. You know this team is going to continue supporting and expanding this game for years - some of us want to be in the front row, some of us will wait a bit. It's all good.

This is the DLC that made me decide to never buy another product from Paradox.  This is clearly just a way of getting rid of deluxe edition passes without delivering any real content, much like the Northern Lords, which actually offered more content than this for 1/3 the price.

Once you get over the novelty of the new systems and mechanics, it quickly becomes apparent that they have almost no tangible effect on the way you play the game.

It's clear that Paradox invested far, far too much time and resources into representing the royal court in a 3D space, and no where near enough on the actual gameplay mechanics.

Northern Lords had a much greater impact on gameplay (albeit only when playing a Scandinavian ruler), with a price tag less than 1/3 of Royal Court's.

Is it good?  Well, you're mileage may vary, depending on how you play and what you look for when playing the game.  For my part, I've rather enjoyed the content that's there, although as others have said, it isn't exactly anything groundbreaking.

Now, is it worth $30 (or your regional equivalent)?  No.  No, not at all.  And frankly, if this is the kind of content we're going to get for the price we're paying, I'm legitimately worried about CK3's future.

[h1] The Good [/h1]

CK3 desperately needed this. The artifact system is pretty good, and the prowess modifiers are great, since you didn't really have any unless you had a blademaster, hunter, or strength trait(s). All the bonuses to renown are great since it was really hard to come by unless you had high intrigue, lots of kids, and willingness to micromanage to get your descendants on other thrones. But the best part is by far the cultures. The first time I made a new religion, I thought, "wait, can I make a new culture too?" I was disappointed when I found that I couldn't, but when this was announced, I cheered out loud. The customizability is amazing. When mod makers start to get in on this in full, [i] evil laugh [/i] the things they'll do! I can't wait. 

[h1] The Bad [/h1]

The Royal court/court languages give more immersion, they have little effect on gameplay, and when they do, it feels forced. It sometimes becomes unavoidable that someone important loses opinion of you, and you're assassinated or that one vassal not yet in a faction joins one and you lose the throne, along with that fancy throne room that cost you the throne in the first place. The expansion is also overpriced (I did preorder though, sooooo...). Wait for a half price sale, or for paradox to drop the price. Wait...

[h1] The Potential [/h1]

Mods. All the mods. I can't wait. I also hope that this inspires paradox (or even mod makers) to give more customizability to religions, whether in a dlc or a free update.
