CK3 Royal Court completely overhauls the culture system in a way unseen in it's predecessors, along with a roleplay rich artifact and court system. If you are interested in roleplay in CK3, this DLC is essential. Otherwise, don't buy it.

Firstly, the culture overhaul. For the first time in a paradox game, culture is important and something that you actually think about. Each culture has at least 3 traditions, with each tradition adding more flavour and potential for roleplay. The genius of this system comes from it's modularity. New traditions can be added or swapped in for a cost of prestige. The cost is reduced if you fulfil certain requirements e.g having 5 cynical counts of your culture reduces the cost for "Life is just a joke". This system discourages minmaxing (somewhat) and encourages you to choose traditions which make sense for the story you are creating. However, these changes take time to implement, thus you can diverge your culture, allowing you to swap out any of your traditions (costs applied) immediately. This adds massive storytelling potential e.g An independent Epirus may diverge from their Byzantine forebears, or may diverge even as a vassal.
If 2 cultures have high enough acceptance (usually 40%), they can hybridise, taking a mix of the traditions and pillars of the parent cultures to form something wholly unique. Finally, I can merge Irish and Italian cultures to create potato-based pasta (that's just gnocchi but you get the idea). 
And yes, the AI does utilise these features. I've seen some interesting creations such as Greco-Bulgarian or the monstrous Croato-Carato-Franconian. Thankfully, how frequent the AI diverges and hybridises is at the player's discretion, in case you wish to prevent the emergence of Afgan-Polish-Franco-Afgan-Albanian.
Whilst the overhaul of culture is part of the free patch alongside the update, hybridising and diverging culture are DLC features.

Next, there is the artifact system, which is executed more elegantly than in CK2. You can commission specific artifacts, or loot them from others but the main method of acquisition is by sponsoring guests' inspirations. Whilst this can get frustrating if you are after a specific type of artifact, it does add a sense of excitement to the system- there is no surefire way to know what exactly you are about to receive. There is a system for artifact claims, but unless you are in the habit of getting raided, nasty succession, or borderline exploits, they don't factor much into gameplay.
Whilst the system adds great potential to storytelling as a battle-winning axe becomes a treasured heirloom, I found I was often swamped by a deluge of low-quality artifacts, mainly attained from sieges or random inheritance. The constant supply of trash made it difficult to navigate through menu's to see the artifacts that mattered. My Queen's prized dagger was buried beneath a pile of more, identical and worthless ones. I wish there was a mechanic for artifact quality to improve as certain weapons or pieces of armour become instrumental in the history of the Polish-French people, Except there is a system for that, kind of, Your dynasty banner gets upgraded as you gain more renown, and some artifacts gain extra effects or flavour text over time. Unfortunately, without a straight increase from Fine to Masterwork level, this difference is hard to spot at a glance. There is also no convenient way to get rid of artifacts- there is a reason that a popular mod lets you auction them off. The system is definitely an improvement over CK2's but it just needs to go a bit further to be truly great.

Finally, the titular Royal Court system is a great addition to the game. It feels great to fill my courtroom with rare artifacts, although I feel that there aren't enough slots for all of my most prized possessions- perhaps a slightly larger court for emperors would work best? Holding court is a great bit of roleplay, along with the court events. However, these events begin to feel a bit repetitive, and a few dozen more of them would  be much appreciated.
Many in the community feel that the restriction of courts to Kings and Emperors is unfair and that dukes should also have access to this new feature. Whilst I understand the frustration, the restriction is most likely down to performance- there are far more dukes than kings and emperors, thus if each duke owned a royal court, there could be significant slowdown. The best solution would be an option to enable duke courts for beefier systems, although I am fine without duke courts for now.

Despite the high price, I do feel that Royal Court is worth buying due to the new depth in roleplay and a massive increase in options for storytelling. Not every addition is perfect (the language system is so minor I forgot to mention it in this review), but the breadth of new narratives to create is worth the asking price. If you just aren't into roleplay in grand strategy games, then this DLC may not be for you.

TL:DR: Wait for a sale if you really want it. $30 and over a year of development with barely anything to show for it. Most of the important stuff you will get with the free update anyway. 

The majority of the paid content is gated by only being available to non-tribal Kings and Emperors. The 3D courtroom is ugly, a glorified diorama since you can't move around it freely. Also, there's only 4 variations of the courtroom, so there will be a lot of unimmersive overlap. Court decisions are extremely repetitive, and they don't impact your game as much as you'd want to; aside from a couple that I won't spoil here. Artifacts are busted and op, they make the game even easier than it was before.

Culture overhaul is AMAZING, though not really part of the paid content since that comes up with the free patch. You pay to be able to diverge, hybridize and reform your culture. Which is pretty cool, to be fair. This allows the player to forge their own distinct culture from the rest. 

In the end, if you paid, half of this DLC is severely lacking, and the other half OK. Both of these do not add up to $30. So I can't really recommend this outside of 50%+ discounted sales.

Won't change negative review until the expansion pack is fixed.

Introduces a culture pack, changes Daju (Darfur / Whats Left of Egypt) culture to female only inheritance. Leaves religion male dominant. Now only my daughters can inherit but I can't give them titles. Sick move mixing gender laws into two different aspects of the game that aren't tied to each other and can cancel each other out, who could have foreseen the consequences? Additionally there is ABSOLUTELY NO historical context for this. There would be more historical context adding this to the vikings than here, and on top of that you made an unplayable game state. 

Look I get you want to make fantasy experiences happen at the fringe civilizations of the game but maybe make it mechanically functional. There are already options to change gender laws in the settings. Either change it back or remove the religious setting that overrides the cultural one.

This is why you have bugs Paradox. The second you think of something new you throw out all design principles and slap it in place.

This expansion is absolutely not worth 30 dollars. "Glad" I got it for the price of pre-order but unless this is on sale for 10 bucks it adds barely anything more than the previous 6.99 Nazi fantasy flavor pack DLC targeting the 3 wolves howling at the moon audience at full price. This broken minor tweak only experienced at the kingdom level or above (save for the bugs which trickle down into the other levels) is sure to add some functionality for modders to play with so that they can make the game Paradox can't. 

I'm sure it will be polished 6 months from now, I'll check it out then.

Honestly Royal Court is a little bit of a letdown. It was a long wait, which sure that's whatever, but the best parts of that wait are all centered around the dynamic culture mechanics and the free update additions. 

The actual Royal Court feature, which the DLC is named for, is novel but disappointing. It's all optional, so you don't have to hold court or engage with the mechanics, which is kind of a plus because after a few hours they're already kind of tedious (Plus the court itself doesn't look good with the lighting being all washed out and uber-bright, not to mention characters' eyes and stiff poses. I'd rather it be dark and realistic looking so I didn't have to see how awkward everyone looks). 

It's not all bad - artifacts and court artifacts are a welcome addition as something that felt missing when CK3 released. 

Court events seem a bit skewed to the point that holding court is straight up dangerous; my half-brother and friend who was imprisoned by another king showed up at court and tried to murder me despite being imprisoned and having +80 opinion. Another time a random mayor who wasn't in any factions drew a knife and disfigured me, my wife, and my seneschal for unknown reasons (Opinion +10). Alrighty then.

It's also not very multiplayer friendly, as you're either rushing to click through as fast as you can or you're sighing as your friend takes too long to finish and unpause. It's definitely an improvement over the base game, that's for sure, but $30 is far too ambitious of a price tag. Maybe I'd review it differently if it were only $15.
The content that comes the DLC introduces does not justify the 30 Euros price tag.

TBH, in my opinion, problem of this DLC is mostly that main game was made exceptionally appealing to broad community of players, but THIS DLC looks like it was exclusively focused on old CK fans. Culture changes was a wet dream of a lot of ck2 players for forever, and ck3 got it in FIRST DLC. As well as expanded artifact system, but I wish it actually added more actual progression. Court building (or what is it?) should be a buildable and expandable entity, accessible from any rank and to any government, limiting you only with how much it costs. Language things are too much micro, court titles are a lot of micro too. That's what OLD CK fans would be more tolerant to, but not the broad community that ck3 managed to gather. Devs managed to get to the next level of accessibility with main game, but failed to do so with an expansion.

This royal letdown would be tight for a €10 minor dlc, not a [strike]€20[/strike] €30 major feature update.

This dlc has been a huge let-down: when CK3 came out, it showed solid foundations despite being pretty bare-bones compared to then fully developed CK2, so I had faith it would have evolved in a superior game. Then, 1.5 years later, the first major expansion is a glorified event generator which gets repetitive fast and makes you feel more like a talk show host than a medieval ruler, since you get to hold court about infidelity, lack of personal hygiene, farts and such kind of meme-like nonsense. Also, why waste so much time and resources to create it in 3D while it basically gives the same results of normal events? It's pointless and the visuals are mediocre at best.
The artifacts aren't bad per se, but they lead to the same kind of power creep that Jade Dragon introduced in the final years of CK2, making the game easier and easier while the dynasty gradually piles up items. Giving it high priority imho isn't a good sign.
The new culture system is probably the best mechanic of the dlc, but imho atm there is little reason to stay committed to a campaign long enough to really make it shine.

TL;DR: overhyped and vastly overpriced but underwhelming.

Hope the devs will ramp up the porting of CK2 mechanics and events to give CK3 the much needed variety instead of going down the The Sims road, otherwise this will be the last dlc I'll buy for a long, long time.

Feb 27th edit: almost 3 weeks after the release and the bug preventing Councilors tasks events from firing hasn't been fixed despite being a major issue. Disappointing.

A few things I noticed:
1. The gear that you equip does not change your visuals at all - it is just another stat for your character. This is quite a shame for a game that has 3D characters that change clothes based on culture or rank. If you are a king, you have a crown displayed even though you have no crown. This is a bit stupid.
2. The royal courts are fairly similar - apart from the cultural differences. My own royal court didn't change all that much from when I got my first king to my last emporer. It was the same glorified shed I started with as king.
3. Over the course of a normal ironman game I got so much gear that it felt like I had too much gear. The good gear, is not THAT much better than the bad gear. If I lost some gear, I certainly wouldn't start a war to get it back.
4. I noticed a bug or two, that I dont know if it's just part of the base game. I asked for a divorce, paid the piety cost, the pope accepted it... but I am still married and got no popup or anything explaining why.

This would have been a "yes" recommendation if gear was displayed on characters (even at 30€). I hope modders can save this missed opportunity.

So this DLC is definitely going to be more for the roleplayers out there, and leans far more heavily into that than most of the DLCs from the previous game.

The major features are the Royal Court, the events associated with holding court for your vassals, the titles, and the court artifacts, then theres the culture overhaul. The former adds a lot of flavor to the game and more to do if you're into acting out more the whole being a ruler aspect. The artifacts are also a nice addition, being able to forge that crown that your dynasty passes down for generations. Then the culture is an amazing change that definitely adds more to the realism aspect. Now if you're a viking that conquers India you no longer have to simply become the local culture or create a random Nordic area surrounded by completely unreleated cultures, you can now combine the two and become Indian vikings. Live out various what if scenarios, what if the Pechenegs decided to settle down in Georgia and merge with the local peoples, what if French nobles slowly integrated with the local culture in Flanders forming a new distinct identity, do as you wish.

The issue with this DLC is that these features aren't game changing to the actual mechanics of the game, as even though the culture mechanics are completely revamped they're not really something you're going to be interacting with more than a handful of times throughout the game. For the people that simply play these types of games to paint the biggest empire of the map you're not going to get anything out of this pack, and unless you just really want these features I'd honestly wait on a sale since $30.00 is definitely a bit much for whats provided.

 I like the direction they're taking with the DLCs for CK3, leaning more into adding more to the flavor of the game and giving more to do as we live our royal in game lives rather than doing a major war overhaul for example. But this DLC desperately needed more content within it as a whole, so I can't recommend it.

I have to say having read a few negative comments I disagree with all of them. It is obvious from a game design perspective why ducal courts and below are not implemented, and while it would have been nice, considering the amount of actors in the game it would have been madness. Besides, being a King is a real goal now ! And goals, this DLC gives you plenty : get a beast economy to pay for your massive royal spending, dress up your court nice ; find those forgotten daughters of your dynasty who were buried in the menus now hanging in front of  your throne (and all the other characters for tha matter ) ! 

That last part is the massive game changer for me. The court. It's not cosmetic. So many fantastic opportunities I found out about, just by seeing who is who today !  And the artefacts too are a game changers. Aristocracy as it's core is about spending money on luxury items instead of infrastructure development. Before you could only spend money on the growth of the kingdom ( lol ) now it's all about who has the most treasures. I won't call them trinkets, because they are powerful items in their own rights, even those you don't use are a potent gift, and those in you inventory can be re-purposed for your throne room ! 

Culture changes are excellent, a fantastic prestige sink. Some religious tenets were turned into culture, meaning less hard choices to create the socio-religious build of your dreams !

I will say this, if you do not enjoy this expansion, I am sorry to say you don't play the game right. I get some feel the game needs more events to feel complete, but the system, the opportunities, the family drama is already there.

I did not pay for a single episode of Game of Thrones. But 30 euros for this ? Take my money and make more content with it. My campaign is sure to have a more fulfilling ending anyway.

I like CK3 but it is missing some depth in play.
The culture update is a good addition and pdx should continue to work on improving game systems like this.
The rest is rather undercooked and forgettable in the current state.
The Court system sounded like a great idea but has far to little actual impact on what you do in your day-to-day business and is in not tied into the game enough, it feels they made it 3D to be able to justify the price of this dlc but it looks rather boring, like most of the connected events, it is a good idea but the implementation is lackluster.

Overall I expected a more in-depth update after such a long hiatus, especially for this price.
A great expansion, however the price of 30$ is a bit steep. 20$ wouldve been perfect

This definitely helps bring back some of CK2's charm, but misses the point so hard it feels deliberate. Courts and cultures are fun gimmicks, but that's all they are. If you love CK3, you will love this addition. If you're looking for ~$1/hr of enjoyment, you won't find that here.
So uh, that's it?

Overall I’d say this is a solid foundation to build on for future DLC. A lot of people take issue with the paradox DLC policy… I think your all wrong. This is a niche genre, and paradox gives us more content than any AAA developer over the course of a games lifetime. I’d much rather pay 200usd(usually much less considering sales) over the course of the close to the decade they support a game then deal with the nonsense going on in the rest of the gaming industry. I get hundreds of hours out of these games… consider a sports game player pays 70-100 dollars every year, is slammed with micro transactions, and then does it again the next year for essentially the same game… and this is just one example. Stop complaining people. You like these types of game? Put your money where your mouth is, if we aren’t willing to support the companies that make these games there will not be any left.

The only reason I even have this "expansion" is due to it being in the Royal Edition. At the end of the day there is no way you can argue that what's on offer is worth the $30 price tag. What we did get essentially boils down to the following:

- The so called "Royal Court" which was over hyped by the devs to the extreme. 
   > Rather mediocre character models 
   > Reused animations from the base game 
   > Some of the weirdest and frankly annoying court events that frequently produce more negative effects than positive. I 
   mean they have a court event for leaky latrines but not like a wedding event or a real feast event to see any of the court 
   amenities you shell out gold for.
   > The aforementioned court amenities; Fashion which never visually changes, Food, Servants, and Rooms. 
   > Oh and you have to be at least a king and either feudal or clan to even have any of this so if you're a count, duke, or tribal too bad you don't even have access to any of the previously mentioned things.
   > There's also a court splendor level which doesn't have any visual changes, only stat changes. 
   > Only a handful of court types with little variation for different regions, cultures, religions, etc 

- The artifacts system from CK2 makes it's return and it's a mixed bag. The court artifacts are pretty interesting but are very poorly placed in the court that makes your court look more like a history museum exhibit than an actual noble court. The personal artifacts however are pretty much just glorified stat modifiers. None with the exception of your weapon are visible and even that is only visible in duels.

- And finally the culture overhaul which expands cultures a bit and does make them a bit more interesting but not enough to be game changers like the devs claim. The divergence and hybridization features are cool and allow for interesting combos but once again nothing game changing considering the asking price

In review the devs seem to think that just because it took them 18 months to figure out how to code the royal court visuals (which are rather mediocre mind you) somehow justifies charging over half of the price of the base game for a what is essentially a few gimmicks and no substantial content that will open up more interesting scenarios or change the way you approach a playthrough. This especially when compared to the Northern Lords culture pack that made playing the vikings so much more interesting and added new and meaningful features all for a $7 price tag. They really hyped this dlc up, treated it like it was a Far East expansion (now that I would pay $30 for), and took a year and a half of dev time all for something that I would barely justify paying $10 for let alone $30. I would say wait for a very deep sale to pick this up and don't waste your money because this definitely isn't worth it.

Garbage. Game is still buggy and AI is completely broken, crusades don't work, no basic features and QoL that were in CK2 (like attach ally army to own army), economy doesn't make any sense what so ever - a cat costs years worth of taxing your subjects, not building walls or some other stupid event can give you 5+ years of income, a pilgrimage can cost the same as building a castle, etc. Events are random and make no sense. Like your vassals will complain your 3 year old heir doesn't spend enough time managing the realm or something and you can disinherit him, you can have random pagan tribals come and live with you at your year 1000 medieval chrsitan lord castle and you can learn their language for no reason so that you can get an event about reading an erotic book (in a language that was only oral) and then somehow your courtiers who don't know the language can make fun of you for it (yeah like anyone back then would make fun of a ruler with absolute power over everything, okay) and so on. I got this dlc for free and I have no idea why anyone would pay for it, given that the game itself is still not even as good as CK2 and the flaws have only gotten worse.

I got the dlc and the game with royal edition during winter sale. I got about a hundred hours of gameplay before the dlc is released. The dlc adds a lot on the cultural system and that's my favorite part about it: creating a hybrid culture of ten different cultures. The court though, it is cool, but more diversity is needed. I see people complaining about the price tag of the dlc being 30 us dollars and I don't know why but my steam shows about 14 dollars. Royal Edition on the other hand is about 40 us dollars on my page. I guess it's cuz my region? Nonetheless it was a good deal.

The most significant new feature is buffs and bonuses given by your royal court to a tall domain vs the expense of maintaining your court with a wide empire. It definitely gives more flavor and variety to the game vs just painting the map in the middle to late game.

Honestly, I feel like this was over-hyped. I like the systems they gave like the inventory, the cultures, and the courts, but I feel like they're under-developed. The court events aren't very special and I was disappointed with how little events there are. It also doesn't help that there was a royal court mod made WAY sooner by the community than paradox themselves. Not to mention the price... $30.... really? For a DLC that adds not that much that you will be focusing on, this is very overpriced.

I was surprised to find all the negative reviews. Months of devblogs illustrated in great detail exactly what would be added in this expansion pack. There were no surprises here. 

For me, it added a good amount of day to day king activities to help fill the time between wars and succession crises. The throne room is actually really cool and the character models themselves have improved a lot alongside it. The bonuses are great including some pretty powerful perks and even new councillor tasks. Plus, I just like poking my head into it to see who is mulling around and sometimes meeting new people or commissioning new inspirations. Getting to look at other people's courts is nice too, as I can immediately see who's who, which helps me plan my intrigue ops. Overall, it feels like a big gap in game play was filled by this expansion and it executes on its vision and promise flawlessly. I also found the new culture system to be more impactful than I expected. The bonuses are pretty good, and it isn't hard to add new ones. I have enjoyed modeling my culture around the particulars of its place and time in history. 

My primary nitpick is that Dukes are not allowed to have courts. Some of the most famous courts in history belonged to duchies and it seems like some sort of allowance could have been made in this mechanic for Dukes. I enjoy playing at the lower ranks, but now I am missing out on most of what this expansion has to offer if I do. Even a more limited version of the throne room would still be fun. 

I got it as part of the pre-order deal, and I agree that it could be cheaper, but I would still pay $30 for it and not feel cheated.
Its good. It ain't worth $30.

It is nice to see your courtiers but most of the actions in court are just replacements of events that used to be pop-ups. I am still encountering a lot of bugs. My iron-man save was ruined by a game-breaking glitch. Not worth $30.

This is a DLC that isn't so much 'bad' as it is 'out of order in the DLC roadmap'. In other words, this is something that would be cool, for $15 bucks (half the cost) after a bunch of other content was filled-in via other DLCs. 

I mean, 3D throne room is a good idea for immersion, and culture and court language also help for immersion as well.

But there are a lot of places that could have been filled in prior to the spots Royal Court touched on. More bookmarked start dates (beyond, you know, 867 and 1066) would have been a good initial addition that doesn't happen here. Further, law-setting and more tools for running your fiefdom would have been great... this DLC *kinda* adds a bit of that with some of the cultural stuff, but basic government options are missing. Prior to having high crown authority, it would really help if there were more tools to keep rivals and factions in-line rather than so often resorting to intrigue. 

Which gets me to maybe the most egregious problem with Royal Court: it adds so little to the start of a new game. You don't even get the court until you achieve a high enough rank, so duchies and counties play pretty much the same as always. Byzantines and a couple others do get a lot right away (the court, but also a few artifacts already). But a lot of the fun of CK as a series has always been playing it the opposite of how I'd play EU-IV: in CK, I want to start small and really grow, meaning that I don't want to play the majors as often. 

I wish there was a numerical score or some other format on offer for Steam reviews sometimes, because this is probably a 4.5 to 5.0 out of 10... simply giving it a thumbs down obscures the fact that some of what RC adds is relatively good.

But overall, it feels a bit too expensive for what it is, and what it adds is good but is what to put in a 4th or 5th larger DLC, not the first.
I mean, yeah, it's $30, but people also pay full price for fifteen new Medal of Duty: Cold Warzone III's each year, too, so what do I know?

Wait for base game and this to be 50% off at this point. I love Crusader Kings but at these prices and the problems it's just not worth at full price at the moment. I like all the new stuff there is so much! i almost would have changed my review for the base game. but the problem comes in the user interface and intuitiveness of it or the lack there of. it's beneficial now to put someone of the counties culture as the count. yet the grant title screen is not up to par with this. be ready to scroll through mass lists of people because you can't simply search for an exact culture in your court or the world. trying to promote a cultural melting pot in your realm? be ready to painstakingly browse hundreds of cultures while searching for a single one with no way to filter this. also whatever happened to the option to filter characters willing to join your court in the find character screen? we are going backwards. again just wait for it to be on sale and or also wait for the major changes that usually come with all paradox games at some point. it's good but for 30$ and considering the base game is 60$ there is just to many problems to recommend it in good faith

I wish there was a neutral review option because this DLC isn't terrible. However, it's way overpriced and potentially somewhat useless to many players, including me. I like to play a lot of games as tribal power, and they don't get a tribal court, so this DLC is basically pointless in those games. I also like to start out as a Duke and, since only kings get a royal court, this DLC is again somewhat pointless for me. 

I did try out a game as a king so I could comment with some experience on the actual features, and some of it was definitely fun. It does get old fast, and once you have large court, you will have piles of pointless artifacts. I'm glad they added these features, but it definitely hasn't been a game changer for me.

For a $30 DLC, I'm pretty disappointed they didn't give tribal governments some type of royal court. If I bought this as a standalone purchase and not part of the Royal Edition, I'd be extra annoyed. A quick browse of the Steam top selling games highlights that $30 can buy some pretty amazing full games. Not even counting the sale price games, this DLC is more expensive than Stardew Valley, Project Zomboid, and Valheim, 3 games that I've each had hundreds of hours of fun with. I love Paradox games, but in my opinion, this DLC represents pretty poor value for money. Buy it when it's 50% off or if they drop the price. Otherwise,  don't bother.

I can't believe just how lazy this expansion is. 30$ for a joke of a 3D court where they couldn't even be bothered to have shadows as if we're back in the early 2000s? No wonder they didn't allow free roam camera, as you might have noticed the glaring issues such as everyone squinting like a Japanse (did they even bother playing the game?)

One of the main selling points  is having character items like swords and armour. Yet these have the most generic designs imaginable - a sword is just a 2d image which you can't do anything with by the way. It would be too much to ask for a dlc that's based around the idea of displaying stuff in 3d to show you the "rare" armour you're wearing! Same with artefacts which you can't see in your court (most are just boxes) 

The entire DLC is essentially just an amalgamation of different modifiers that you could easily go through the entire play through without even noticing; that's how inconsequential they are.

Finally you have the most grandiose court in the world, with top notch fashion and food? I doubt you'll notice it as the court looks exactly the same no matter how much you invest in it! The naming of court levels being the most bland "level 1 - 2 -3 - 4 court" should tell you all about how little they care about the product.

Overall, I enjoy this expansion, I still tend to play CK2 over CK3. I think people complaining seem to be mostly people who don't like the price, which I am not going to get into. Others don't think it adds anything, and I think this is more the people that play this as purely a grand strategy and don't get into the story telling and characters in the game. The main things it adds are culture changes, the royal court/holding court, and artifact crafting and displaying/equipping. 

1 - The cultural changes. I think these are good, but can be better. I love the idea that you can merge cultures to create custom cultures from the two. I am now paying attention to my culture and actually trying to create and merge cultures to make my culture stronger. I used to just stick with the culture I started with for the entire game. I still don't love the cultural research aspect of it, but that hasn't really changed

2 - The royal court/holding court. Its fun to see your court, but not for everyone. While CK games are 4x, they have an aspect of role playing and characters that make them stand out for me. Seeing the characters that make your story is interesting, but its pretty static. Its more for the people that don't purely play it as a grand strategy. Holding court is done well. Instead of getting constant popups, there are a bunch of events that you can roll through when it is convenient for you. If you are in the middle of a crusade or war, you can wait until you're done to go through all of them. They have a lot of flavor, and I haven't seen many repeats. Again, this is probably for the people that don't purely play this as a grand strategy and like the stories and the characters.

3 - Artifact systems - I love these and they are done far better than CK2. Instead of just hiring a smith and paying absurd amounts of money, the system has inspired people with different levels of skill and different events that affect the quality. There are slots and maximum amounts of items that can be equipped, there are inheritances and the ability to demand artifacts back. Its just overall a really good system, and for me this adds a lot. I love it.

The content in the DLC is fun and the culture stuff very interesting to play around with. But especially for that price tag there is so little actual content added to the game.
The game still feels a bit empty compared to its predecessor when comparing the content that dropped in about the same time since release.

So I recommend you get this DLC when it's on a pretty big sale rather than full price.

Very little game-changing stuff actually here, and you don't get to experience any of it unless you're a Feudal/Clan King or higher. It's just extra fluff that apparently ate up a bunch of development time for basically no reason. I got this as part of the Royal Edition and it's quite a real disappointment. I'd get it for like 75% off if I was going to buy it now.

Howdy all

So CK3:TRC adds a few new features. The Court system, and a new culture system among others. I've enjoyed the time I've played with it, as it adds a fresh coat of paint to the CK3 experience. It also adds a decent amount of modding ability for the modders out there. The biggest gripe most people have with it is the pricing, which I can't say I disagree with. It is a bit overpriced for the content added, however in my case I've negated my buyer's regret type of thing by getting the expansion pass... This was the first time I've ever pre-bought a game or dlc for a game. It lives up to the hype in my mind. I would buy it again if I had to, but I would probably wait for a sale.

For the first time buyer/player, I'd highly suggest waiting for a sale, maybe like 10-30% off is best. If you can or can't wait for a sale, get the bundle. You pay for TRC and NL, and also get 2 flavor packs essentially for free. Though I must note when I bought the expansion pass I already had bought NL, so my math may not be perfect.

I hope this helped any future buyers!

Plus, the court room itself doesn't change, so while it seems like it would work fine for a Count at first, when you get to Emperor it feel s like you're ruling from an unfinished closet. I should say it WOULD be good for a Count, as there's no content for tribal rulers, or any position below King. So if you like to start as a count, it's gonna a be awhile before you see anything. [h1] Jesus help me on this one. [/h1]
The new culture system is undoubtably a nice addition to the game, adding flavor and giving the player the option to create your own culture. But this feature that some say should have been in the base game already, quickly gets overshadowed by the royal court itself, and it is something special.

The special thing is that the court is at first glance cool and all but those few events that happen, quickly get repetitive and boring. Not to mention that a late game court is ridiculously expensive and unsustainable for a late game empire. The Throne room feels and seems ackward since it is so out of place. The artifact system they brought back from ck2 also feels this way and these factors break the immersion that has been ck for me. The visuals are nice but definetly not what crusader kings needed. 
What it needed was new gameplay additions, for example like they had in ck2 playable republics or more startdates with more character events, flavor for muslims, supernatural events, silkroad, sickness mechanics, crusade mechanics that are actually fun and rewarding for the winner, great project designer, china, horde mechanics, indian flavor, immortality for the absolute chad ruler you are playing, they had all those things and surely many more in ck2, but nothing anyway close this epic in ck3. If you want to experience these things you have to rely on mods.

But by far my biggest compaint is the fact that, this doesnt add anything new and you'll play the game the same way you did before and the fact that they charge 30 bucks for this which is insane. The first flavor pack in ck3 Northern Lords added many fun and interesting events and options for asatru characters. But this lacks in comparison. This, a major expansion which adds practically nothing gameplaywise, lacks in comparison to a flavor pack that added new gameplay mechanics for a fraction of the price. I would honestly not even recommend to wait for a sale here since the obvious right thing to do would be to return back to playing ck2.

[b] tl;dr RIP 30 bucks for everyone not owning ck3 Royal Edition, go play ck2 instead. [/b]

Paradox honore sa réputation de studio incompétent et avare avec ce DLC. 

Des mois et des mois d'attente pour un DLC qui ne concerne qu'un tier du jeu, les cours ne sont accessibles qu'aux gouvernements féodaux. Pire encore, seuls les rois et les empereurs ont accès à une cour (l'un des mods le plus populaire du workshop y remédie et est sorti le premier jour, voyez la compétence de la communauté face au je-m'en-foutisme de paradox). 

Pour ce qui est de la cour en elle-même les interactions sont maigres, en tant que vassal la plupart du temps les 3/4 des options seront bloquées car hyper spécifiques et franchement pas vraiment utiles, et en tant que seigneur lige vos décisions n'ont aucun réel impacte sur votre économie ou la politique de vos terres. Paradox s'est contenté de rajouter un énième système de loterie à modificateur, choix A modificateur fort +20% sur un stat, choix B modificateur faible +5% sur une autre stat et ça s'arrête là. 

L'intérêt du DLC se résume à la découverte des nouveaux événements pendant une dizaine d'heures, suite à quoi poursuivre une partie (sans rajouter de mod j'entend) devient inutile, puisque ça se résume à blob en boucle étant donné les problèmes d'équilibrages toujours pas corrigé permettant une expansion exponentielle, farmer en boucle les mêmes décisions pour gagner du prestige et de la piété et c'est tout. 

Passez votre chemin si le DLC vous intéresse, passez votre chemin si le jeu vous intéresse, restez bien au chaud sur CK2. Le jeu sera enfin digne d'intérêt et jouable dans 2 ans après la sortie de 8 DLC supplémentaires pour qu'enfin peut être on retourne au niveau de CK2. 

Seul point positif de ce DLC : les moddeurs ont maintenant accès à une toute nouvelle mécanique (la cour) pour faire le travail des développeurs et nous pondre un contenu intéressant.

I'm flabbergasted that this cost $42 Australian Dollars. And for what? The extremely mediocre visuals in the Royal Court, regardless of how much effort they took to make, aren't worth the price-tag or the period of time we've had to wait for them. The actual royal court features, as another reviewer has mentioned, really do just feel tacked on (e.g. I don't believe any events that originate outside the royal court screen ever make it  into the royal court; it's just specific, automatically generated royal court events). They don't seem to have justified the direction this DLC has gone in and they don't really seem to change the way I play. I would have been equally happy with an artefact system that was purely abstract without the visuals. The court is also, at this early stage pretty unbalanced in terms of its costs and potential benefits.

I'm a much bigger fan of the cultural changes. More attention should have been directed towards that side of the game. I'd be much more interested in political and ecclesiastical improvements to religions and more role-playing depth in the church; e.g. introducing improved versions of Catholic Investiture, the papacy, anti-papacies, the Byzantine Empire's imperial system. We're 18 months post-launch and we still don't have even CK2's level of realm management/customisation via laws and council voting. We don't even have regencies.

The modding potential that Royal Court has opened up must be enormous and the game will probably be better for it in the long run, but at launch I really can't say it's worth the price-tag

Expensive, but I got it as a pre-order bonus. If you didn't, wait for a sale. Features will likely come to bear fruit with immersion packs, since customizing these mechanics to be region-specific would've delayed this DLC further.

The new rpg mechanics moves the game away from "map painting" and more towards a "medieval simulator." The game is even more enjoyable now.

I'm recommending Royal Court because I believe that this concept is 'unique' and adds more levels of fun to the game. However it's important to point out that for the current price you're not getting much. 

First let's start with the positives, the special part about Royal Court is the 3D modelling. The new events that can occur from within your throne room are fun to play through and helps make the game last a bit longer by creating more things to do. Furthermore Royal Court introduces changes to the culture system best described as more dynamic now. Following that is the reintroduction of artifacts and different court positions. So there's a good amount of features within this DLC.

But on the contrary to this, Royal Court can be a bit lacking in areas. As a player you get to decide how much money you'd like to spend on your court and sadly it doesn't feel like your financial decisions carry much weight as you alternate your spending. Additionally there isn't much you can do inside your throne room besides tending to random events and holding court, even then there isn't much that visually happens within these events either. It doesn't feel as if they're utilizing the full potential of what they created which is a shame.

However these are baby steps into new territory. Hopefully Paradox keeps the momentum going and does something impressive with how you handle your court in the future. Until then we can only wait and see

Overall if you like playing CK3 and want to purchase DLC for it, you're better off waiting for Royal Court to go on sale first. If I could pick between 1-10 for this game it'd be a 6.5, the features itself are very nice in concept but in practice needs more polishing. Let's hope the polishing are free updates and not something you have to buy.
Nice

My relatively brief thoughts on each of the new systems:

3D Court Room: So from the start I had a bad feeling about this when they said they wanted to go with a 3D court room, because in my opinion that makes no sense. Paradox makes map games, and map games are what we love from Paradox, they are incredibly unique in that way and there are few other developers we'd consider make "grand strategy games". Them trying to create a more RP friendly experience is well and good but I don't think that idea should ever take backseat to actual gameplay and mechanics. The immersion you get from the court is... okay, I guess. It's not something I'm ever excited about, and personally feel looks extremely bland, adding very little to the overall experience.

Culture System: This was what I felt was the true meat and potatoes of the expansion, and a revamped culture system is what I've been wanting for a very long time. However does it really add up to the original hype? Not really. The new systems are nice and definitely will make each playthrough more interesting and more diverse, but ultimately it's a very slow-paced system that you can't utilize all too well until mid-late game when you can accumulate a lot of prestige or decide to make random hybrids just to steal peoples innovations (something I don't care to do because it doesn't make sense from an in-game narrative standpoint, and Paradox is really trying to push roleplay so this doesn't make sense). It's great if you're playing a viking though. I think I'm starting to see a trend with Paradox, hmm.

Language: What in gods unholy name is this? I don't know if I'm just an idiot who can't figure out the most basic thing but this feels not only completely useless mechanically, but also functionless. Learning other languages doesn't seem to actually do anything productive other than add a slight RP flair, which I don't care for. The idea seems nice but I feel like even if it does have some function that I'm not properly making use of, it's still worthless and adds nothing.

Artifacts: Aight here is the big money. I honestly don't have any real complaints about this, I think they did a pretty solid job on it and it's just CK2's system but infinitely better since it works with the court room. You feel like the things you create and collect actually matter in a way, and sure you can probably break the game with some insanely OP items but honestly that is probably part of the fun, just like in CK2.

Minor Titles: I like this quite a lot. At the end of the day it feels almost as pointless as they were in CK2 but they are in fact, not useless. So that is nice. The buffs you get from most of them aren't really noticeable most of the time, but when you start bringing in the cash it adds some more flavor to your playthrough since they can do some neat stuff. During one of my playthroughs I had my trash diplo viking leading armies and he didn't get hurt once, most likely because my bodyguards were actually doing their job. Perhaps I got lucky, but I like to think the feature was doing its job.

Is It Worth It?: I'm probably forgetting some big things but honestly cba about thinking about it. Overall it may seem like my attitude is quite negative towards the DLC but I enjoy it quite a bit, and it will a lot of fun to each of my playthroughs going forward, and since this is one of my favorite games with about 1000 hours into now, it's worth it for me. So for me it's a no brainer, however this is 1000% overpriced. The amount of content it brings to the table feels on par with Northern Lords in size, but obviously more ambitious. If you are having conflicting thoughts about wanting to get it then you should probably wait for a sale, but if you plan on playing a lot like I do, then it's worth it. It's a shame we waited over a year for just this, but I'm hoping this is just the foundation for bigger plans that Paradox has for CK3s future. I understand that the pandemic slowed things down drastically, and we were supposed to get this ages ago so I don't hold that against Paradox, and always am hoping for the best. 

I do hope the DLC pans out well because it would crush me if they canned CK3 like they did with Imperator and many more projects they had in the works. I know it's been a very difficult year for them financially, and part of me is worried this isn't going to help all too much.

This was announced nearly a year ago and I was incredibly excited to get my hands on it, as I figured it would be a meaty expansion which would add depth and flavor to the game. Instead, this DLC offers little depth, and the flavor elements are largely restricted to Kings and Emperors. Many of the additions are superficial and I got bored quickly due to the mindless and repetitive tasks my character ended up doing just to keep the game going, just as I did prior to this expansion. 

I keep going back to CKII to enjoy what Crusader Kings is all about. CKIII remains a superficially beautiful game with little depth.

Its a big meh from me. I don't hate it.  I think the new culture changes are great, but the whole effort feels half baked.

I think what makes this expansion really sus is that it adds nothing new for Tribal leaders.

Which is weird because the Northern Lords pack expanded on the mechanics.  It just seems like a real missed opportunity to expand on some of the groundwork they already laid.

Truth be told I enjoyed Northern Lords more than Royal Court.  Though my play style I prefer starting as a tribal and reforming all the way to Fuedal / Clan.  Royal Court really does little to change my early game experience and makes only a marginal difference to the mid and late game.

Not worth the full $30 wait for a sale. Added much-needed flavor and an interesting mechanic for modders to use, but otherwise lacking. The game could still use a trading mechanic (something like RGO output in Victoria 2 or trading in EU4). Adding the Silk Road or the Trans-Saharan Trade route would add a whole new reason to play African and Middle Eastern realms. Only giving it a thumbs up for the content modders will be able to create.
I paid 30 dollars for my game to not launch. Noice.
If I wasn't waiting for the game of thrones mod, then i'd prob rate it negative. This adds something Im exited to see in the mod, but other wise, meh. Def get on a sale if you can wait.

Not a bad dlc but not really what this game needs right now. Culture system seems to be a variation of the religion system. All the artifacts and court stuff really just boils down to a bunch of modifiers and doesn't really feel like a serious attempt to further develop the game. 

To be honest I don't even like the customisable culture and religion system. I have no interest in creating a meme religion. The customisable cultures also take away the uniqueness of certain areas. There should be drawbacks and bonuses from playing certain cultures. Having the ability to create some super culture takes away from that. I like the idea of divergent, melting pots and hybrids however there should be some drawbacks.

I want something significant like an improved war system, deepened diplomacy and a more in depth economy. For example the intrigue and hook system is a meaningful improvement of CK2's mechanics. Aside from that there isn't much really here.

Just a big meh.
Look, I like this DLC, I really do, but 30$ is ridiculous, wait for a sale
cool
hört euch den Gamestar-Podcast mit Steinwallen und Shurjoka an, die sagen alles
An absolute must have.

Typical Paradox, $30 for slight gameplay change. The court gimmick is half-baked at best, and is only for kings and higher. So basically if you want to be a court or duke, maybe once in a while you get to pop in to see your rulers room- thats it for the royal court. Even if you are on council in the court room, there is nothing to do. As with most paradox games, you only can have the immersive addicting fun you expect from the base game once you are about 4-5 dlcs in, or modded to hell. So you will eventually get royal court. Ck3 keeps begging the question of "whats missing?" and paradox knows.

Anyways for the artifacts and culture mechanics, it feels like half of it was in the free patch (learning new languages etc.), and the artifacts while cool, isn't anything that is worth $30. And honestly, there is less content here than ck2 dlc, so don't expect much. 

Quite frankly, paradox not only delayed the release for royal court for almost a year, but its not worth the wait, nor the dough.

GET IT ON SALE.

This is a pretty good DLC, but it is very hard for me to give it a positive review because of the price tag and how long it took for it to come out. It adds some cool new mechanics and if you like roleplaying like me this DLC adds a lot of useful mechanics. Honestly though I would wait for sale, it is not worth the price.

Its just...boring. You can't even access the main feature of this expansion without being a king or emperor, and tribal rulers, as of this post, can't access it at all. For the $30 that Paradox is charging, it's not worth it at all.

Au moment de la rédaction de cet avis, je découvre encore l'extension. Je précise que j'évalue le dlc ainsi que la maj qui en découle.


- La cour royale offre une immersion assez agréable, et une dimension RPG cohérente avec ck3. Une feature qui apporte un nouveau challenge si on souhaite développer l'une des plus belles cour royale, et bénéficier de ses bonus qui en découlent. On s'y croit vraiment assis sur le trône, royale :)


- L'ajout d'artefact, et de l'inventaire des personnages permet de personaliser d'avantage notre avatar et offre encore une fois un nouveau challenge RPG, si l'on souhaite pocéder les meilleurs et plus puissants artefacts du jeu. C'est l'élement le plus prometteur qui soit. A voir au niveau de l'équilibre du jeu si tout ces ajouts ne font pas du joueur un demi dieux imbattable trop rapidement dans le jeu.

- La refonte culturel est sympathique, tout comme l'ajout de l'apprentissage des langues, et donne un interet négligé jusque là.

MAIS 

En toute honneteté, le DLC est beaucoup trop cher pour le peu d'ajout apporté. D'autant plus que certaines features sont disponible avec la MAJ. Je le recommande tout de même  pour une immersion supplémentaire, mais clairement le DLC n'a rien d'indispensable dans l'état actuel.

NOTE : 14/20
Even though it supposedly adds a lot to the game, it still feels exactly the same to play anyway

Northern Lords costs £5 and blows this out of the water.

£24 for this DLC isn't worth it. Don't pay anymore than £10
Excellent addition, highly recommended.

This honestly is a terrible DLC even if you view it through Paradox's rose tinted glasses, for all the extra "3D" shit they wanted to add and show off, if you upgrade your court fashion you can't see the difference, there is no discernible difference between your court after upgrading it and paying the extra gold upkeep cost for it which is near never worth it. All the events are still basically just pop ups, just inside 3D courtroom space, the event where someone becomes your footstool? Your ruler will not have a footstool within the 3D courtroom. the only thing you can add to your courtroom is artifacts which give measly bonuses and you never spend gold on because it isn't worth it, they just stack up over the course of conquering AI. Also one big glaring problem is that if you are tribal or not at least a king in rank, you don't get a court, so easily over 50% of the starting game just doesn't have a 3D court at all... 

The cultural aspect of the game is interesting but at the same time, there seem to be arbitrary caveats as to when you can reform or divulge, like "Your culture is not at least 100 years old", why does that matter if I want to start a different culture?  On top of this there are huge hurdles for what seem again like seemingly small buffs for such a vast amount of effort focusing on it.

In conclusion, its terrible, the fact I waited so long for this and sat through 30 minutes of Paradox's stupid Twitch stream for it to drop makes me want to go back in time and smack myself. This could've and probably should be base game content, it doesn't honestly seem like they did much for how long it took and how much they acted like they added.
I am enjoying the new game mechanics.

The culture mechanics are interesting, but the court gimmick is half-baked at best. This DLC is way too expensive for what it offers ($30 for less actual content than most CK2 DLCs, which are half that price). If you're really gonna buy it, do so on sale, because otherwise you're getting ripped off.
The fact that the devs spent this much dev time on a DLC that ultimately does very little is worrying, when they probably could have pumped out multiple flavor packs to help make different parts of the map actually feel, you know, [i] different [/i] in the amount of time it took between Northern Lords and Royal Court. You can tell that most of it was spent on the Court itself, which is ultimately just a vehicle for flavor events that could have worked the same as the pre-existing events without needing a fancy 3D model gimmick. While the Court could be improved over time, I don't think it'd be worth the effort of fixing this lackluster Sims Medieval wannabe mechanic.

The change to culture is something I find incredibly enjoyable. The ability to social engineer the culture and faith of my peasantry while I rule high and mighty from my big-ass throne in my fancy court is super fun. 10/10 would make hybrid Bavarian-Berber culture again.

Dodaje fajne mechaniki które sa tylko troszke za mocne , rozbudowuje ck3 ale za 108zl kompletnie sie to nie oplaca to juz jest inny poziom jak w hoi4 masz za 80zl 3 drzewka narodowe to tu za 108zl dostajesz z 3 mechaniki , kilka eventów zajebista  mechanike artefaktów z ck2 , generalnie nie ma tu nic nowego czego by nie bylo w ck2 ale mniejsza

The court system in this DLC is a complete failure, it looks and runs awful, the events are about memes and farts and the whole thing only makes me think that the shift to 3D for CK3 might have been a huge mistake. Way too much time dedicated to making a failure of DLC that is made to appeal to redditor "haha le funny incest" screenshot posters and cringe streamers. 
 Other than the culture rework, there isn't anything in this DLC to justify even paying 5 euros, let alone 30, its barebones and a huge letdown. Hard to trust Paradox with CK3 after this one.

Toto DLC pridává pár vecí, které dále rozepíšu. 
1. DESIGNER pro dynastický erb a znak zeme je hezká a pro me velice vítaná vec. 
2. ÚPRAVY A VYTVÁRENÍ KULTUR jsou zábavné a zajímavé ale chtelo by to aby se vývojári trochu více zamerili na jazyky, které jsou v soucasnosti absolutne zbytecné. 
3. ARTEFAKTY jsou hezká blbustka se kterou se dá vyplnit dost nudy v pozdejších cástech hry. Jediným problémem je množství, které budete vlastnit po pár hodinách hraní.
4. POZICE U DVORA jsou spíš otravné a nezajímavé, protože krome dvou nebo trí pozic jsou témer všechny k nicemu, stojí hromadu penez a i když je nemáte vubec o nic nepricházíte nijak to gameplay neovlivnuje. 
5. Jako poslední je zde váš vlastní DVUR, ve kterém si mužete vystavit své artefakty a odehrávají se tady eventy s vašimi poddanými, sousedy, rodinou a poskoky od dvora. Zní to hezky ale eventu uvidíte za celou hru maximálne 15 z nejakých 36, pokud nesplníte všechny požadavky, zkrátka jsou všechny na stejné brdo a navíc vetšina má negativní následky a nebo pricházíte o peníze. Vzhled vašeho dvora ovlivníte pouze tím kde se nachází a pravé vystavenými artefakty nic víc, je jedno jestli máte nejúžasnejší dvur na svete protože soused vedle vás bude mít dvur úplne stejný i kdyby ho mel nejhorší. Animací je zde opravdu málo nejsem nejaký vývojár ale myslím si že za takovou cenu by hlavní cást celého dodatku mela být opravdu propracovaná což není.
Cena je obrovská, mám hromadu celých her a ne dodatku za stejnou nebo i menší cenu. Oduvodnéní COVIDem a casem mi prijde hloupé a pokud Paradox ješte dál nerozšírí obsah, který zde zatím je, díky nejaké aktualizaci, tak své kladné hodnocení budu nucený zmenit.

Good DLC! worth it for the price, it adds tons of content to the game.

I'm seeing a lot of negative reviews on this dlc . Alot of them are saying that the game is buggy, but I personally haven't had any issues with it so far. I love CK3 and this dlc got me back into playing it. It is nice that they added 3d models to the game to to the royal court to make it more immersive. I personally think this dlc is a great addition to the game and is worth the purchase.

So much focus on features that don't add any actual depth.. Took such a long time to develop and it's a buggy mess that crashes your game at least once every hour (even without mods). Paradox brainded
30$ for a Northern Lords size flavour pack, labelled "expansion" taking twice the dev time to release.

I feel like Paradox put a ton of time and resources into this DLC - but to so little effect! What the game needed was some new, solid, FUN mechanics and regional flavour; CK2's Holy Fury should be the mark towards which every CK3 expansion should aim. Unfortunately, what it got in this DLC was a pretty, but otherwise boring and irritating, extra menu, i.e. the royal court itself. It's heart-breaking, because it looks like it's taken the developers forever to make, but it makes the game less, and not more, enjoyable.

Credit where credit's due; the culture overhaul is exactly what the game needed. (I wonder what might have happened if Paradox had spent more time on that sort of thing, rather than pretty gimmicks?) But I'm told that that's part of the free update.

Excellent produit, j'adore lire les mêmes events répétitifs sur un courtier que je ne connais pas et dont je n'ai rien à faire qui s'offusque qu'un autre de mes courtiers que je ne connais pas et dont je n'ai rien à faire ai roté à table. Je suis fier d'avoir eu la brillante idée d'avoir payé plus à l'achat du jeu pour une édition royale sous prétexte que les dlc seraient plus conséquent et travaillés et en me basant sur les excellents dlc de la fin de CK2 comme base de la qualité à laquelle s'attendre. Vraiment, la représentation 3d de sa cour est une idée formidable que je suis sûr a été demandé par tout le monde comme une addition essentielle qui manquait cruellement à ce jeu, surtout quand la moitié du monde a une cour arabe. Vraiment, rien à faire d'une refonte du système militaire, un approfondissement de l'économie ma foi très rudimentaire du jeu ou de plus de différenciations entre les différentes régions du monde et plus de types de gouvernance, voilà ce que je voulais : une dizaines d’événements qui sont répétés ad nauseam et des blagues sur les prout et les rots et ne donne aucune rejouabilité et profondeur supplémentaire, vraiment l'apogée de la stratégie et du rp combinés, pas du tout pensé pour que les Redditors s'envoient des updoot entre eux en partageant des screenshot de leur premier playthrough 

Refonte culturelle est sympa, mais bon ......... 30 balles et un an et demis et c'est tout ce que le jeu a à offrir

Hands down one of my favorite DLC's for Crusader Kings. It adds a ton of things to do. Especially being able to effectively lead your vassals of different cultures from rising against your rule. Taking other kingdoms items when you go to war with them and putting it all inside your court is a huge plus too - big slap to the face. 8/10

A big... meh. I got Royal Court as I've preordered CK3 but there is absolutely no way I would've paid €30 for it otherwise. I could deactivate it and my life in the medieval world would be the same. Ignoring the price tag, the DLC is actually pretty good for Paradox's level. The 3D court is such a cool idea that adds just another layer of depth to the RP and interactions in general, especially in the HRE. Only get this if you don't mind the 23 quid except that I highly reccomend

I really liked this game until I bought this DLC. Looks like old saves aren't compatible with this DLC. It means that once you load your old save after installing this DLC the game get messed up. All characters are are near death. Your gold, prestige and other resources are reset to 0. Also everybody loose their armies and got almost 0 troops. dlc guzel ama alakasiz yerlerde alakasiz diller ve kulturleri degistiriyor ai. ingiltere krali ibranice ogrenip kendi kulturunu hintlilerle mixliyor acil duzeltilmesi lazim yapay zekanin.

Adds some nice flavor but is an absolute joke for $30 USD. People do not play this game for visuals, I am not sure why we are paying for mainly the ability to look inside a court room that adds absolutely nothing to actual gameplay.

Everything I have seen of this DLC has been amazing. I've always seen The Crusader Kings games as a story building game. Sure some folk like the minmax or see how much they can build/destroy, or just play it as a numbers game. But I bought Ck2 after watching folks build their own Alternate histories and try to get into the minds of their rulers- a great dynastic roleplay over the centuries. And never mind about the modding community and the content they add.

With all that said I believe Royal Court is a grand addition from videos I've seen for players like myself who want to play out a story through their rulers and their court. I'd be playing it now if my computer wasn't in the shop. And I eagerly await what the modding community can make with the added content.
You MUST HAVE this DLC if you really want a perfect DLC for this game.
Cost too much add so little content for 30$ not worth it maybe 10$ and that's steep for amount of content ,thank god i got it with base game as a preorder

Lots of reviews out there.  Many of the negative reviews are based on price vs content.  They feel for 10-15 it would be a good buy but 30 is a no go.  I do not really judge if something is good or bad based on pricing.  Sure it can and should be a contributing factor in deciding IF someone should buy something.  Remember, pricing determines how good or bad a deal is, not the quality of the product being considered.  So now that I got that out of the way, let's begin.

I have enjoyed Royal Court thus far.  There has been a definite layer of depth added to the already great game-play.  If you enjoyed CK3 from different perspectives, cultures, challenges, etc this will not disappoint.  This takes all of what was already great and adds even more ways to play.  It does not however change how I feel about the game.  If you did not enjoy CK3 before, this content will do nothing for you in terms of changing that opinion.  I recommend this if you are a fan of CK3 and have the finances to spend on games.
Its realty good worth the money adds a butch of content to the game. some people complain about the price but they probably still think you can get fredo's for 10p .

I've really enjoyed it. The artifacts and court are cool and give me something to work towards later in the game besides conquest. It was very satisfying stealing the pope's hat. 

I think the criticism on the price is valid. If you don't want it now I definitely recommend picking it up on sale sometime.
overpriced, doesnt really bring anything new to the game.
This is not worth $30.

I thought the whole courtroom and artifacts business would feel like a bit of tacked-on busywork. But I was wrong, it absolutely adds some much needed life to the game. There is a ton of content there which flows quite well with what is happening outside the courtroom. It can have quite impactful consequences if you choose to accept them (you always get a choice). And while the adventures your courtiers go through to gain you new artifacts might not be the most immersive they're certainly entertaining.

I get that not everyone is convinced by the pricetag, but if you're buying Paradox DLC at full price you know what you're getting in to. Either get the Royal Edition at launch or wait for the inevitable sale if the price matters is that important to you. Personally I think it's worth it, it really fleshes out the game.
I love this, it adds a lot to the game and finally i can see nudey bits when i'm on my throne. :) 9/10

I love the hold court mechanics. 
Receiving people at court to solve their problems is an excellent way to immerse yourself and even care more about your subjects. 
On a funnier note I instantly loved this DLC the moment I had the choice to cut a baby in half so that two claiming mothers could have their part.
Doing so reduced my stress by 85 because I'm a sadistic [spoiler]f*ck[/spoiler] and now I'm known as "The Child Killer".
11/10 would slice babies in two again.
The DLC is ok but the price is far too high, it cost more than half of the base game and is not adding nearly enough to justify it. Don't pick it up unless it is 50% of or more.

Les ajouts et changements sont vraiment pas mal même si on doute sur l'équilibrage avec la salle du trône en exclusivités aux rois et empereurs. Sinon non, trop peu de choses pour 30€, 1 an et demi pour ça pas top.

Great game!  Adds some depth to the game that was missing prior to the DLC.

Base game now has bugs EVERYWHERE.  DLC is full of bugs.  Game is almost unplayable due to the bugs that you run into every 15-20 min of playing.  Watch any big streamer and you'll see all of the issues or just check the forums lol.

Impossible to recommend it at the current asking price. The systems that are added aren't bad at all, but the level of content is barely existing; I honestly feel like I have to wait for some dedicated modders to make some content so I can properly play with the new mechanics

The Content this DLC adds is good, but no is only worth £8, not £ 24. The features don't change the way you play the game in any real way, so the game you are playing is the same. I do not find the mechanics of the culture interesting because they only affect stats, they don't change the way characters act or look, or how you play the game, it's not bad, just not worth much. 

The courtroom is cool, but it barely changes anything and has serious balance issues. Compare this DLC to ck2 DLC,s which fleshed out and seriously changed how you played certain regions, like the middle east or trading republic, to create an incredibly immersive world with endless opportunities because the changes deeply affected how you play. 

This DLC does nothing exciting, and it would have been much better had they added new game play mechanics, which changed or added to the game play I have been playing for a year now.

525 days in the making and I think it was worth the wait. Come back to this DLC in a year or 2 and it'll be looked upon as a crucial foundation to where the game will be. The price is more than justifiable for the amount of content added. The only thing this game really needs right now are more flavor events and a hard and very hard mode. The foundation is set, i'm very excited to see the future of this game.
Too little content, way too late after the release date of CK3.

I could spend hours looking at the new cultural content alone, it adds some much needed dynamism to your choice of character and progression. Artifacts and inventory are a very welcome return, and much easier to get than in CK2. Court events are a little mundane in terms of mechanical impact, but do add some fun and flavor to roleplay. Court amenities and courtier upkeep are a bit high considering the court doesn't really add opportunities to make money, but that's a fairly easily sorted balance issue rather than a conceptual issue, so hopefully that gets tweaked soon.

Playing tribal at the moment, so I haven't got to the actual grandeur mechanics. Divergent/hybrid cultures add to the overall complexity of the history happening: I like seeing the way that cultures grow and change almost like dynasties themselves.

Expanding the culture mechanics has always been one of my biggest desires for CK, and Royal Court does a really good job of it. I hope that something like the divergent/hybrid mechanics comes to religion as well one day, but as stands now, Royal Court changes the game for me in such a wonderful way.

Royal Court is a decent expansion, but if you were burned out on CK3 already it doesn't do enough to make the game fresh again. The titular feature, holding court in a 3D environment, seems like a big waste of time on their part, and a chore on the player's. I understand it was meant to draw players into the roleplaying mindset, but the court falls right in the middle of the uncanny valley, with all your courtiers and petitioners standing around, posed like mannequins, waiting for you to interact with them. The changes to the culture system are great. I was looking forward to launching my own unique, custom culture in game. But I can't overcome my deep sense of boredom long enough for the feature to mean something. If you are completely new to CK3 then Royal Court is probably worth picking up. If you're an existing player, you may wish to wait for several more expansions before coming back to it.

My patience for paradox is starting to run thin, after waiting for months this dlc feels unpolished as usual. If this was the delayed product I truly fear what would have been launched three months ago. The features/foundations are solid but the price tag is quite absurd. The culture change is good but it does often descend into chaos. Its just clear that the dev team is ignoring their play testers as they often do. The only paradox product that seems to be learning from their dev mistakes is Stellaris, with the open beta that's been going for the past few weeks which is rad. Thank you stellaris dev team for taking a step in the right direction. CK3 team learn from the stellaris devs and provide an open beta to people who pre-purchase the dlc, and listen to the feedback. The community needs to be more involved in development because I feel you have lost sight of what makes these games fun. I always buy paradox products but rather than being an enthusiastic fan I feel more and more disconnected from these games.

This DLC is overpriced, yeah I get it. Who cares? This is paradox. People are willing to buy hearts of iron 4 dlc for 15 quid, when it should of been in the game in the first place. This is different, this is content that has never been before seen in any crusader king's titles, lets strip this down a bit into parts. The parts will go in order of what a normal player is likely to see to what a hardcore player is going to see.

Normal Player:
A normal player of this DLC will most likely only scratch the surface, the main bragging points of Royal Court are better cultures, courts with 3D MODELS!!!! And even a little bit of polish sprinkled on top, the first thing I noticed is that the map looks much, much cleaner and the models on the characters are just better somehow. It is hard to describe how great these features are, the less interesting feature (in my opinion) is the inventory system. It brings some very minor bonuses but its pretty cool from a RP standpoint. On a different subject, the RP potential and storytelling this DLC can provide is crazy, I would love to see a Game of Thrones mod with this DLC.

Ironman Player:
For those unfamiliar with Ironman mode, it does not allow saving and is pretty much considered hardcore mode. You will probably be able to reform, diverge or form a hybrid culture with your culture if you are specifically devoted. This can provide some cool bonuses too like "Malleable Invaders" which allows hybrid cultures in your realm to form more easily, and this slots in PERFECTLY with the Northern lords too. I suppose since this is a review I do need to beat up the DLC a little, they left tribal ruler's, dukes and counts out of the Courts of the DLC called "Royal court", this can make the expansion feel barebone's early game- Especially if you are going for achievements such as "Rags to riches" or "Mother of us all" which both start early game and usually in tribal realms. Now don't ask me why, but every game I have so far played has been on Iron Man mode, usually starting in a tribal realm. This expansion can feel non-noticeable at times and that does not bode well with the amount of people shitting themselves over the pirce. 

Hardcore Players- I don't consider myself a hardcore player, like a 1000 hours reddit moderator kind of person. The closets I have came to that is a near 200 hours, but that's probably just because when I first started playing this game I was engrossed like a child discovering a bottle with a thing that makes it look ever so slightly look like a rocket. 

My Opinion- This DLC is pretty good, I would not go as far to say it is brilliant. But it is moldbreaking in the sense that it gives the player new RP potential and better yet. custom dynasty banners. Many hours were spent making the Amogus banner, or maybe even the banner of house Lannister. But... I don't get why people are taking it in turns to kick paradox to the ground, like, you already gave them a solid blow to the jaw with the review's on "Northern Lords" and you all seem to have atleast 100 hours into the game, so suck it up, take it at face value and see what it really is- A cool DLC that adds cultures and 3D models, if this DLC is not for you, then I get that. But please, please don't go bitching about its price. This is paradox, and 2021 was a tough year for them.

It is a little expensive for the content that it adds, but the content itself isn't bad.

If you love Crusader Kings, I'd say pick it up. You'll get enough playtime out of it to justify its price tag. If you can wait for it to come down in price a little, then I'd say wait.

If you're into RP I recommend this DLC. I have felt so in control of my kingdom since this, dealing with peasants coming to my court asking stuff. Maybe 50% of my time since DLC release is playing with my court on events.  100% recommend if you value RP or immersion.
Little pricey for what you get, but I like the new features overall. Maybe wait for a sale if you're skeptical.

Recommending this DLC for one reason only - it's a great platform for mods. That's it. Vanilla Royal Court is absolutely pathetic. 

For DLC that has been delayed for as long as this one did, it's more than pathetic to have as few new events and limitations that make no sense. 

Do you think it'd be cool to focus on your courtly duties as a count/duke? Nope, only kings and emperors have a place to chill with their courtiers and their vassals just rules from the street, apparently (Fixed by mods) 

Do you want to play as an epic jarl why rules from his badass mead hall? Nope, Paradox thinks tribal governments were a bunch of savages with no concept of a court (Fixed by mods) 

"Oh well, they've spent so much time developing this DLC. Surely they must've made a lot of flavour events" you might think. Nope, there are about 5 events in your court, 10-15 "hold court" events and 5-ish world events. (Yet to be fixed by mods) 

All of it can be excused for a rushed DLC. This one has been delayed by almost a year! 
So get it for mods, but please spit on Paradox. 

Oh, also, inventory system is pretty neat, can't complain there.
