I agree with the consensus on this DLC. It's not bad, but the actual content here feels like it amounts to the patch that usually comes along side a major expansion, rather than an expansion itself. The two primary features here are firstly a court which does very little other than act as a money sink and a store room for items that mostly give you slight prestige bonuses. Secondly, it has culture modifications, which are more substantial but don't seem to offer a huge variance in play style. 

The problem with culture is it still hasn't really changed to be more notable from CK2, which is to say that it's almost irrelevant, providing minor or aesthetic changes rather than sweeping playstyle changes. Mercantile seafaring peoples get some extra income on the coast, highland warriors get some slight bonuses to combat in hills etc. The problem with bland bonuses like that is they don't change at all what you'll actually do in your game - Play a religion that has a lay clergy and you can hold temples. Pagans can raid while unreformed. See the difference between how religion is portrayed and how culture is? Culture feels like background fluff even in the places where it does provide benefits because it provides benefits that don't alter how you play. There's a city builder tradition in the game, but it still doesn't enable you to hold cities as a feudal.

Even for hit and miss DLC in CK2, they tended to change how you played substantially. The Horse Lords was a good example - I am one of the few who enjoyed the clan based government even though it was extremely rudimentary. At the very least it was an actual different experience. All of the CK2 governments felt substantially different to play as.

It does seem like the only reason this has been priced so high is that the court has actual visual representation. All it is at the end of the day is an abstraction of what CK2-3 already had: Events and interactions with other characters. It all seems like a serious overreach for something that doesn't add any new core gameplay experiences. 

CK3 doesn't need to be prettier, it needs more in it. The most important things to the game are religions and government types, and unfortunately that hasn't changed, culture still isn't really that important in that mix beyond what it already was. Which makes the choice to ignore expanding the currently limited options regarding government very strange on the part of Paradox as well.

At best this is a culture flavour pack. Certainly doesn't add anymore content than Northern Lords did. At worst this is a content light DLC because Paradox know most players with the Royal Edition paid before they knew what they were purchasing. What's included helps add flavour to the game, but it's not an expansion, and I'd not spend more than £10 on it.

Even though the DLC is a pit overpriced it still adds a lot of interesting game mechanics. The royal court mechanic really makes your realm feel more alive, furthermore it adds more play to your economy, by constantly balancing the  level of court grandeur with the amount of gold you can miss. Furthermore, the new culture mechanic really allows for a more dynamic playstyle, that was previously not possible. The artifact system is a cool addition, however you can get so many useless artifacts that it may be difficult to find the ones that are actually good, it can make this system a bit tedious. Paradox should find a way to fix the sorting systems for artifacts because it does not appear to be working for me.

All in all I think the dlc itself is a lot of fun and adds many new elements to the game that were previsouly missing. It is a bit overpriced, but if you buy the royal edition of CK3 the dlc is definitely worth it.

TL;DR It feels like paying to take CK3 out of Early Access, not like paying for exciting extras. Look, I love Paradox games, and I consider this DLC essential to the game. So why can't I recommend it? Well it's not JUST the price. It's the fact that they've locked so many basegame features BEHIND such a highly priced DLC. They basically took stuff that was already part of CK2, waited like a year to add it to CK3, and then charged more than 50% of the basegame's price for it. You're not covering any new ground, you're just giving us back features we already have access to from a different game - Other than the 3D rendered royal court, which is cool but very incomplete. You can spend on amenities but nothing visibly changes about your court or courtiers when you get elite fashion or endless servants. When this is on sale for $5 then buy it. No hate toward the workers who made this, just ... The absolute upper limit I'd put on the value of this is $15 which is saying something because it includes what should have been CORE FEATURES of the game ON LAUNCH. The only thing that feels like it should be part of a DLC is the 3D rendered court, which probably took up most of their effort and isn't enough by itself to justify a DLC. The rest is arbitrarily paywalled mechanics you shouldn't have to play the game without. I am seriously concerned about the future updates to CK3 if they intend to keep locking basic features behind DLC paywalls that cost almost as much as the game itself.

Royal court doesn't add a huge amount of mechanical complexity to the game, but it does add an enormous amount of flavor and make-your-own-fun storytelling capability, which is where this series really shines in the first place. is a sold base for a first expansion, and hopefully they will continue to build on it.

If you buy a Paradox game, it comes with the expectation that there will be paid DLC that supports the continued development and expansion of the game. So, I got the season pass  to get the first couple of DLC for free back when I got the game because I'm too impatient to wait for things to go on sale, and I play Paradox games, I know how this all works. So now that it's come out, it feels like I've gotten this DLC for free. Props to past me. 

The DLC is a blast! It adds a lot of flavor and variety, and just a lot more roleplaying and personality to the characters in the game. After several failed attempts I was able to re-enact the Norman Conquest and go about making London home to the grandest royal court in the world. Grand courts give a lot of positive modifiers, including to people's willingness to be recruited to your court, which gives a nice reliable way to invite talented people into your kingdom beyond marrying them in. 

Collecting artifacts is great fun, and balancing how much to spend on investing in your realm the old fashioned way versus getting nice new tapestries to hang up in your hall is pretty engaging. Some of the items you get are really powerful, especially in boosting prowess. With some famed armor and a famed weapon you're looking at well over +9 prowess, which you can pass down to your inbred fragile heirs to keep them alive. You can also gift artifacts to those clouts who hooked their way into your council, potentially buffing their doomed lines into some semblance of sentience. It's nice to see the nepotism of the medieval ages develop a couple of pros to balance the many many cons. 

The biggest criticism I have of the DLC is that I'd love to see more. I want to see more types of throne rooms, including a grand wooden feasting hall for tribals and norse Kingdoms. I want to see Empire titles unlock even more court positions and new mechanics in the same way reaching Kingdom opens up the court. I want more room to display my artifacts, I want more banners on the walls, an even larger court, more rooms to visit like the prisons and a treasury. Heck, medieval courts (especially pre 1066) often traveled, I'd love to be able to have more than one royal court, let me set up and decorate a winter palace separately from my summer palace, etc. The UI for gifting artifacts could and should also be improved.

That said, Royal Courts stands as an exciting addition to the game which adds a LOT of fresh content. Holding court is blast, the new events are great, commissioning artifacts is addictive. If you want to continue to support a gem of a game and have fun doing so, buy the DLC. If you can't afford it, wait for a sale, but this is definitely one you'll want to pick up at some point. I just hope that Royal Courts is the start of development in this direction, and not the only DLC we see that deepens the realms we govern.
Way overpriced. This is worth no more than 5 dollars USD.
Why exactly don't dukes or petty kings have courts?

Overall a mess that is not worth the amount charged. 

- Royal Court is very ordinary and "meh" with only a handful of generic events. Courts are Eurocentric and aside from the architecture, nothing changes no matter where you are on the map. Nothing at all for Tribal kings, but they still get the penalties to vassal opinions? Completely breaks the game if you don't play Feudal essentially. 

- Artifacts are really generic and ordinary. Not really worth anything. 

- The culture mechanics, while a great idea that adds loads to the game, is very badly implemented. Many of the mechanics just aren't realistically usable due to insane costs and/or time constraints. This means these mechanics might as well not be in the game at all, making the entire thing a waste of time. 

Overall content is low, and aside from the graphics assets with Royal Court, appear to mostly be low effort. You can cover the entire DLC in the first hour of gameplay. Making it boring and pointless. 

On launch are insane bugs, such as invincible AI armies, regular crashes, save file corruptions, AI getting stuck in endless wars etc. etc.

You can tell that not only did they not test the game properly, they have actually not played the game to see if their mechanics are even viable. It feels like a couple of people slapped this together in their weekends or something.

If this DLC had cost maybe $10 and was much better balanced making the content actually usable, it would be ok and I'd give it a thumbs up. But for the price being charged, is a complete and utter ripoff. 
Get this in a humble bundle or on 90% discount sale or something.

Like most Paradox DLCs, wait for a discount before buying. Its does provide a new shallow depth to the game but definitely not worth 30 dollars. Though I have a distinct feeling this is just a ploy by paradox to get people to do their DLC subscription service by making these shoddy expensive dlcs and make it seem like a cheaper alternative to spend 5 bucks a month than 30 up front.

The royal court system just feel empty, with only one or two events popping up every few years. Holding court just gives you 3-4 decision events that cause little effects to your wider realm and at times feel sloppily thrown together. I once had a count requesting vassalage under me and then the very next person, happens to be his kid brother requesting me to declare war on my new vassal and place him as count. Then after that, you gotta wait for another 5 years for another 4 events. You get 21 new courts positions, but if you go into your court the max amount of people you really see are 10 randos middling about. 
The relic system also feel mediocre. In your court you are allowed only 3 Banners, 3 small trophy, 3 furniture and 4 centerpieces with only two distinct types of relics, court and personal (which you can equip). You can turn your personal relic into a court relic but not the other way around. So if you want to wear the Crown of Justinian as you lead your empire, you can't because its only purpose is to be on display in 1 of 4(!!!!) slots in your court. So as a large empire with 20 plus relics, you're really not displaying the power and majesty of your court and more showing off a bit of nick knacks to your house guests. If I was a successful warlord, why can't I carpet the path to my thrones with the fallen banners of my enemies?

So save your money! Wait for the next christmas sales.

If there were a "middle" thumbs I would definitely chose it, this is an interesting expansion, however, the content it adds is a bit lack luster. For most realms, the primary feature of this DLC is unavailable since you have to be a non-tribal king or emperor ruler. Once you get a royal court, you can get "court events" which can either be good or bad. Every five years, you can take the "hold court" decision which gives you a series of events you have to deal with; you usually aren't able to circumvent something bad happening. You can lose any of your piety, prestige, gold, etc. as well as gain stress. The artifacts are an interesting feature. Though with so many other things to manage I usually don't have enough gold to care about sponsoring inspirations since artifacts barely change most of the management you have to do yourself. It's an OK DLC but I don't recommended it at it's current price.

I wish there was a maybe option for recommending things on Steam. I don't want to say that I don't recommend this, because I did enjoy this expansion. But at the same time, it doesn't feel right to recommend it in it's current state/pricing.
I'll summarise: 

1. Is it fun? - Yeah, adding actual 3D spaces to see your characters in gives the world a more 'lived in' feel. I', very curious to see how they would expand on this in future, adding more 'scenes' as it were e.g. banquet hall, battle fields, council chambers etc..
That being said, I personally feel that the real 'meat' of this expansion has nothing to do with the Royal Court itself, but rather the much requested culture rework. Also seems weird to exclude tribal rulers from having a court. You wanna tell me Genghis Khan didn't have a court? And why is there no native freecam option? I wanna see my grossly inbred King's face up close dammit!

2. Was it worth waiting for? - Depends on how long you were waiting for it. If you count from when they started selling the 'Royal Edition' prior to the base release that's almost two years. Obviously Covid threw a wrench into everything, but even so, I don't think the amount of content added by this DLC justifies how long people have had to wait for it. This is something that absolutely cannot be repeated by Paradox.

3. Is it worth the price? - LOL NO. See above. This is the most expensive DLC Paradox have ever released. Hell I got this through the Royal Edition and I feel a little shortchanged by it. Just wait until it goes on sale. I would not under any circumstances recommend buying this for full price.

It's hard for me to write the DLC does not add lot's of new gameplay after a few more hours in.
So far I've commissioned several new artifacts, diverged and hybridized cultures, decorated my court and even sent courtiers abroad on adventurers.
Beyond the surface features, you interact with your court and realm in new and more personal ways. Instead of yelling at your courtiers in a few events you are now represented living in your realm, the DLC makes the game much more personal to your character. 
The content added on it's own is subtle yet impactful on your realm, adding as much flavor as functionality.. yet the additional content is not 'tacked on'.. it changes the base game into something much more personal, intimate, and direct. You will feel and notice the change in the game. While not everything it could have been.. it is the first step into what CK3 will be - and for that it's worth the buy, but it's not everything you want it to be.

[h1] A DLC of Great Grandeur [/h1]

TL;DR If this DLC is reasonably priced is for you to decide, but it sets out to be the most ambitious DLC yet and in that it succeeds.

It’s hard to develop DLC for a sequel to a beloved game like Crusader Kings 2. On the one hand if you only add features already present in the prequel, people are miffed to be paying for the same features all over again. But if you only add completely new features people will start complaining about your priorities and form factions to demand their favourite feature be added to the game right now.
To circumvent this problem Paradox decided on a compromise for Royal Court, adding a completely new dynamic culture system, a 3D throne room, and reintroducing a fan favourite: artifacts.
Royal Court is considered the first major DLC for Crusader Kings 3, with a grand price tag of $30. This sets the bar high for Royal Court. To meet expectations, it must try to be more ambitious than any CK2 DLC ever was. Let’s see if it succeeds at this.

[b] Culture system [/b]
At launch Crusader Kings 3 distinguished itself from its predecessors by having a dynamic faith system. It not only had more religions, but also allowed players to start their own religion, greatly improving replay value and the RPG potential of the game.
With Royal Court a similar system is implemented for culture. Cultures are no longer one-dimensional but consist of various cultural pillars. Players and AI can now reform these pillars over time. Most significant of these pillars are the traditions. A culture can have up to 5 traditions at game start and there is a large amount of them in the game giving access to a variety of bonusses and mechanics. Most traditions are meaningful, and a well customized culture can greatly help lean into a certain playstyle.
Reforming a culture is not the only way cultures change in the new system. There is also the possibility of diverging from your culture. Diverging a culture is instantaneous and allows for faster customization if prestige is plentiful. As such it does lack the long-term planning that comes with reforming a culture. A third option is hybridizing, merging two cultures. Like diverging, hybridization is instantaneous, but does require some long-term planning as certain amount of cultural acceptance is needed before hybridization is possible.
With the added complexity of languages, ethoses and traditions to culture and with the addition of three ways to dynamically change cultures, Royal Court adds a lot of content and greatly increases the replayability. With this new culture system Royal Court proves it is willing to take an ambitious leap and back it up with quite the amount of content.

[b] Royal Courts [/b]
Also new with this DLC is its namesake, the royal court, visualized as a 3D throne room filled with courtiers. This space is used to stage some events in and represent the state of your court, abstracted to a value called grandeur. Grandeur can range from 0 to 100 and is mostly decided by your willingness to spend money on it, either through amenities or hiring people to fill court positions. Because money is relatively easy to come by in CK3, grandeur isn’t hard to max out. Because of this and the fact that an increase in grandeur only results in bonusses, there isn’t really any trade-off to grandeur and doesn’t present the player with any meaningful choice.
The virtual throne room looks visually stunning and does succeed in making the court feel more alive, expanding the RPG aspect of CK3 further. The court is however only visible in a window separate from the map where players will spend most of their time. To counter this the developers added events that pop-up in this window and the decision to hold court that present the player with a string of events, but players might find they still only occasionally check the court window.
With the addition of the royal court the developers take a risk by adding something very few people requested. It’s an ambitious step to utilize Clausewitz 2’s 3D capacity and elevate the game’s role-playing capabilities. But because players will only spend a limited time in the virtual court, there is only just enough content to justify it as a feature. Hopefully future DLC and patches will expand on this feature and give the player more stuff to do at court.

[b] Artifacts [/b]
One thing visible in your court not mentioned yet are artifacts. A first for Crusader Kings, artifacts actually show up as 3D models when added to a court. The virtual court is however not the only place artifacts might be collected. Characters also have a personal inventory, where artifacts that can be carried on their person are represented. Artefacts are primarily acquired via inspired characters, who can be sponsored to start crafting items, and there is an assortment of events that determine the outcome of the crafting process.
The total number and variety of artifacts added in Royal Court match those of CK2, even though CK2 needed multiple DLC to get to the same amount. This quantity of artifacts shows Royal Court is willing to go the extra mile to catch up and possibly even overtake CK2 DLC content.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
Having reviewed all this, we return to the question of if Royal Court adds more content than any of CK2’s DLC did, as its price tag seems to indicate. The answer to that question could be yes, especially when considering the amount of 3D models included in this DLC. Though the amount features added is limited, the culture system and artifacts especially are supported by an impressive amount of content.
Does this mean that $30 is a reasonable price to pay for Royal Court? That is a question only you can answer and one which heavily depends on your interest in the included features. It is undoubtedly a hefty sum to pay for a DLC, but if any Crusader King DLC is worth $30, it is Royal Court.
One important caveat is that this DLC does focus quite strongly on feudal kings and emperors and forgets about vassals and tribal rulers. While playing as a tribal or vassal can be just as interesting as playing a feudal king, Royal Court barely expands gameplay for these particular playstyles as they do not have access to courts or court artifacts.

TL:DR: I think that the DLC, while fun, is purposefully overpriced to try and get people to buy the expansion pass. 

I personally have had a lot of fun with this DLC, from forming Indian Vikings who raid overseas with war elephants, to making the kingdom of Sardinia a quasi-trade republic by reforming their culture to have bonuses to ports, farms, and guilds. However, for what is on offer here, I find the price that it's at to be too high, mainly because I want more out of $30. However, I think this is the point. 

If you go and check the price of the season pass, at the time of writing this, it is about $35 before any discounts. It's going to be worth watching the price of that season pass, because if it goes up by the time I'm writing this, then Paradox may be trying to get people to buy a more expensive season pass in order to get a little extra out of customers before any other dlc/flavor-pack/whatever get's released in the first place. The pass was $35 before royal court or northern lords ever came out, and if it goes up, then, to me, it's confirmed that they're trying to prey on people who think, "yea, the season pass is more expensive, but it means I'll get access to future updates and not get left behind with something that is overpriced."

To sum it up, if you REALLY want this dlc now, get the season pass. If you are willing to wait for sales, then please do so, and if the price of that season pass DOES go up, then, Paradox, that seems like a really slimy marketing strategy. 

Looking back at it now, that might be why Northern Lords is $15 dollars as well.

EDIT: Northern Lords isn't $15. That's my bad.

Would highly recommend to any CK3 player who is looking for more to add to their game. I feel like people are not truly appreciating how big of a deal the 3D throne room is. I have been dreaming of something that added exactly this since release of CK2. Adds the final level of immersion that gets you lost in your sandbox world, cultures and characters feel way more dynamic and well real.

As it stands, even with the price tag, personally I think it add a lot of flavour, suddenly characters come alive with the court and the events seem way more natural and memorable since you trigger certain events from your court, outside of holding court. Haven’t had a lot of time to fully flesh it out but it seems to run well and provide a lot unique artefact events as well as other unseen possibilities.

The only cons I see are it is limited the royal court to only kings and emperors, also you need to be feudal so a big chunk of the map doesn’t really benefit and I personally prefer being a dukedom or duke under a king, at least to start. But I imagine this will get added later on with DLCs probably and more flavour packs.

If you play Paradox games you know what to expect. In the end this is one of the better DLCs I’ve ever bought from them. For sure a lot of mechanics and flavour that add a lot to the game, expensive but if you have the cash and are eager to game, I think it is worthwhile. It won’t break your game or anything strange.

I will discuss the pricing of this DLC later but first I want to hit upon the stability. It was delayed for stability and I am fine with that however I guess it should have been delayed a bit longer. I can not play a game for more than 20 minutes with out one of the following happening; Game stops responding, Crash report window pops up, Computer freezing, or my favorite BSOD. At first my crash reports tried to do the very best they could but after submitting around 20 they may have devolved into "Trying to play the game."

Now for the price, this game costs more than half the base game and as such I expected a fair transformative product. However even if we take into account the free update [which I am not since most of it is there to support the paid content] this is not worth the price. I did not play CK2 but from what I have gathered they are adding back functionality from a previous title slowly. But honestly aside from the court positions that are part of the free game I don't think there is much here. 

I was gifted the DLC for my birthday since it came out a day before and I feel like the person that bought it for me got robbed That is how wholly inadequate I think this product is for the price. It is probably more at home at around 12.99 but it is hard to justify any more than that.

Perhaps my opinion will change in the future, infact I hope it does. I guess my final closing statement is please delay things until they are done, you have been doing the people who purchase your DLC dirty lately and we all know it. Shape up or we ship out.

[h1]Overpriced, oversold, overworked.[/h1]

Over the past few years, Paradox has more often than not released DLC that has failed to meet consumer expectations. Paradox developers have noted the challenges of dealing with COVID-19 and working from home arrangements, but their decline in quality and the overpricing of DLC begins as early as EU4's The Cossacks (for which I wrote a very lengthy negative review, hence why I specifically remember it), released nearly 7 years ago at the end of 2015. COVID-19 is not the problem.

At pain of making this review far longer, I could continue on about my speculations regarding Paradox Development Studios and how it's operated, and why this is causing problems. But reviews have a character limit, so I will reserve my remarks on PDS to this: STRATEGISE your time better, re-evulate how you value features, do not assume more time = more value.

[b]The DLC's added content: is it good?[/b]

It's just... okay. You couldn't say the content is 'awful'; the added depth to cultures is a welcome addition, the inventory and combat systems something I missed from CK2 and glad to have back, and the new royal court and its many new positions fairly mediocre but not [i]awful[/i] features.

Is the new content enjoyable, though? Not really. Not that it has made the game less enjoyable, but I can't say it has made the game more enjoyable either. The way I play CK3 hasn't really changed from before Royal Court. The features, though not awful, feel  "tacked on". They don't offer new ways to play, but merely supplement the existing gameplay loop. Aside from needing to keep your court's grandeur above the expected threshold, you could validly completely ignore your royal court and it would make no serious impact upon gameplay.

Engaging with your royal court also becomes quite tedious. I was surprised to find after checking CK3's Royal Court event files that there are 86 (as I counted) general royal court events, yet while playing it feels as though there are only 10-15. The issue is that many events rely upon specific conditions that are unlikely to change throughout a character's life. Many, for example, rely upon certain court positions being occupied, but as a vast majority of them cost 0.50 to 1.50 gold to upkeep, it is simply too expensive to have more than a handful of courtiers employed at any given time until the late game (by which time, given how easy CK3 is, most have stopped playing out of boredom). Consequently, you are faced with the same set of events again and again.

I'd also note that it [i]seems[/i] a majority of court events are negative, usually resulting in you losing money, prestige, and relations with one or more vassals. Positive outcomes are rare and not rewarding enough when holding court more often leads to negative outcomes. Events where gold is lost is especially harsh when your court grandeur threshold requires dedicating almost your entire income to court amenities.

And, on that note, the cost of court amenities and salaries scale awfully. Tying court costs to eras results in expense hikes completely disconnected from the pacing of the game. Income game design has been made to grow gradually as you invest in buildings and increase county development over time, but the +25% hike in court costs is instantaneous upon entering a new era. To use my current game starting as West Francia as an example, I formed the empire of Francia and rule over essentially eight de jure kingdoms. This makes my court grandeur expectation level 10, meaning I essentially need full court amenities. Going from Tribal to Early Medieval instantly increased my court amenities cost by 10 gold and made many of the court positions I had filled no longer affordable to maintain as their salaries also hiked by +25%.

This meant I needed to make many court positions vacant, meaning less interaction with courtiers and less event flavour, as well as it disrupting the flow of gameplay completely as I had to suddenly shift towards buildings and development all of a sudden without any graduality- a shift that is hard to do, given its reliance on stable income and time. I don't feel as though this janky kind of gameplay is the kind of gameplay intended, especially given how disjointed it is from CK3's game design approach to income.

Final issue I have with the royal court is the royal court view itself. Court artefacts, especially pedestal artefacts, look awkwardly out of place. After filling out all the artefact slots, your court more resembles a museum storeroom than it does a royal court. It begs the question why this feature was even implemented when it really serves no purpose.

I recall reading in a dev diary that a significant amount of coding went into adapting the engine so that the royal court could be visually represented. [i]Why?[/i] Several times in the past (after repeated controversies around pricing) Paradox has justified the price of their DLCs upon the time and effort they invested into developing them. The issue with such an approach is obvious: consumers don't value time and effort, they value quality and content.

Accounting for how feature-poor this [i]very expensive[/i] DLC is, I can't help but feel Paradox felt justified in their pricing due to the time they poured into coding and troubleshooting the engine to support the court visuals. Not only are these visuals very [i]average[/i] and completely lacking responsive variation (why doesn't my court change when I pour money into luxury amenities? why doesn't it look like a rundown shelter when I neglect it?), it serves zero gameplay function. Here, I believe, Paradox made a HUGE misjudgement, placing far too much value in the visuals.

CK3 is a [i]grand strategy game[/i]. While the visual representation of characters is highly appropriate for CK3's core gameplay, it being centred around the lives of individuals, it was unnecessary to extend that as far as visually representing the royal court, especially when doing so was so costly and needing further development of an already greatly functional engine. Frankly, it was a complete waste of time and money.

I think most players would have been equally as satisfied with simply a flat interface similar to the inventory system that represented the artefacts on display in their court, not needing the extensive effort that was invested into showcasing those artefacts visually. Interacting with characters in this interface is a hopeless affair. It has never been helpful and I continue to use either the council panel or courtiers panel. In fact, more often it becomes an inconvenience, as the intuitive and fantastic tooltip system CK3 introduced to Paradox's games doesn't work as fluidly with the royal court interface, it blocking the display of panels and requiring me to exit the court view during court events to check a character's aptitude for court positions they're requesting, or to check titles relevant to a court event as the title panel is also completely blocked when in the royal court view.

I believe the crux of this DLC's issue lies in the decision to have the royal court visualisation. If all the time and effort that went into implementing new engine code instead was dedicated to new mechanics, interactions, and flavour, there is no doubt this DLC would have been better received. The fact that the Northern Lords flavour pack actually changed the gameplay loop by offering new ways to play by varying choices and interactions, while this mainline major expansion fails to do so and sits more as an idle supplement and less a game changing major expansion, says a lot to how significantly those who direct Paradox's projects misunderstand what makes their games fun, engaging, and replayable.

Paradox Development Studios HAS talented staff, capable of making quality products, but I believe PDS's management of time and valuation of features is deeply flawed. They MUST improve their strategy. This spiral must end.

First I'll address the reason why the DLC has been review bombed,

The price of Royal Court might be a little steep for some, but the DLC helps fund the free patch content. A lot of the issues people have expressed in regards to the pricing wouldn't have been expressed if the free patch content was included with the expansion under the same price, and not available for all. You're basically getting half the DLC content for free, but you can pay for the *full* thing (including the free content) if you want it. It helps to fund the continued development of the game, which allows Paradox to continue to support their games for as long as they do.

Plus, if you have a group of friends you play with consistently, only one of you (the host) needs to own the DLC.

With that out of the way,

POSITIVES
- fits seamlessly into the standard CK3 gameloop and doesn't feel like a gimicky add-on
- seeing the characters in court and interacting with them brings them to life and makes you care about them a lot more
- gives you more to do during down-time and adds a lot of flavour to the game, which was sorely needed
- very pretty 3D models

NEGATIVES
- at present the artifacts system, which is a base game feature but featured most prominently in the expansion, focuses too much on generic and low-level items, and artifact bloat is even worse than in Crusader Kings II
- some minor issues with polish and bugs, particularly in loc texts which has some spelling and grammar issues, though we can expect these to be fixed with time

After so many failed expansions I was finally having hope for a return to form, but I'm once again bitterly disappointed. This feels like a minor patch, not a $40 PLUS expansion.

The court itself is remarkably barren and almost entirely cosmetic.
Artefacts you collect are represented with generic 3d models that do not resemble the item itself in any way, this could be a glitch but I'm 99% sure this is just working as intended. Eg, a small bust I found is represented by a bronze eagle statue.
Your weapons and armour do not even appear on your character, what is the point of this? Why bother forging or collecting a rare sword or piece of armour if you can't see it in-game outside of the 2d icon representing it in the menu.

Once again we have an absurdly overpriced "expansion" that offers very little, which is exactly what I've come to expect.

It's a very shallow DLC.

The novelty of the 3D court room very quickly go away once you realize it's just a facade for many of the random popup events that would pop up from time to time. 

Not worth it unless on sale.

The content of this "DLC" is not even accessible for half of the game. "Royal Court" means exactly that. You have to be a Fuedal King to even get a taste of what you bought here. That means no Royal Court for you if you're Tribal or even playing Fuedal under a king. No content for you! You just over-paid for a few 3D scenes that you don't even get to see.
What else is there? Cultures that take an astronomical amount of Prestige to make hybrid. Great. That's $30 for you.
Ugh. So much spent time, so much change to adjust, and such high price... Unfortunately, it's not really worth it. Maybe some patches will do more but right now, no.
Pretty solid but admittedly I didn't pay the full 30, which I agree is fairly steep
Paradox always did have a sketchy DLC policy but this takes the prize.

I bought this, for full price, like an absolute fool. It's not a bad DLC at all, but it's not what was promised. We were promised a completely game changing experience and it's not that. The reason I bought it was, mostly because I know Paradox. The free updates are never really worth it without the dlc, lots of cool buttons left unclickable until you buy something. Wanting to see exactly what this cool new 3D court system was. And man am I underwhelmed. Again, it's not a bad DLC at all. It adds cool things, and some useless. Like the language. It doesn't matter. Languages don't matter at all unfortunately. It would be a really cool addition if it wasn't so hyped up. We had to wait extra time due to covid, and that's okay I understand that. We saw what working from home did to CyberPunk 2077, without the ability for devs to test the games on consoles. So I don't mind  that it took a while. But it's just not game changing. It isn't what was promised. I think most of the time went to designing everything in 3D and making sure it worked, and nothing really interesting was added. This isn't worth $30. It isn't worth $30 at all. I would say it's barely worth $15. Paradox has entire games that cost less than this, let alone better DLC's that cost less. Don't do what I did. Don't get caught up thinking you need it for the better game experience. And don't get caught up in the hype the YouTubers are giving this DLC. 

Is it good? Yes.
Is it what was promised? No.
Is it worth the money? Absolutely not. 

If there is any pro I can say. It adds the base for a lot of new content later. Content that will hopefully be free or really cheap after asking so much for this.

Very recommended DLC.  Worth every penny.  The amount of depth added by custom cultures adds a lot for a player like me who likes to experiment with "ahistorical" builds.  Further adding onto the already customized religions, you can really fine tune your realm for whatever you goal is on any particular run.  Culture blending in particular looks like it can get really crazy.

The Court itself brings back a mechanic from CK2 that I sorely missed, Artifacts.  Stack wiping West Francia and taking their Battle Flag to hang on my wall was an official "Awesome Moment In Gaming" for me.

I even like the language mechanic.  Is your different cultured wife a little disinterested?  Learn her language.  Helps for making friends with hostile neighbors too.  I also used it as the final straw to push a foreign king into accepting a betrothal.

More options and flexibility in nearly every aspect of the game.  Simply put this is exactly what a DLC should be.  For 30 dollars I've tacked at least another 1000 hours onto a game that was starting to feel stale when it dropped.
Enjoying it but not a good standard of content for the price. Concerned that future DLCS will be overpriced for what they add to the game.

While the content this expansion adds is good, and (in the case of cultures) practically essential, there is simply nowhere near enough of it to justify the price tag of €30. Not even if we were to include the content of the parallel free patch.

For those of you who have yet to buy this, know that despite the amount of hype videos Paradox issued/sponsored for this release, it doesn't change the gameplay experience in a meaningful way, so please don't feel like you're missing out.

Wait for a sale, if you get this in future at say €15-18 then you'll have no regrets.

While I received the DLC through the Expansion Pass on Pre-Order, the pricing on this is completely absurd. I enjoy the DLC and find much of the content a welcome addition to the game. It is a good start to the Ck3 content and includes a lot of features that flesh out the already excellent base game. 

However, this is Paradox's most expensive DLC and do not forget that word 'DLC', while this is marketed as an expansion it is just more content. If this had many more mechanics and actual gameplay styles I would perhaps consider the price worthy. But it is not. It is far more expensive than additions such as Old Gods for CK2, Utopia for Stellaris, Art of War for EU4 and Waking the Tiger for HoI4 while not nearly being as important as any of these.

I understand that CK3 is supposed to be the next generation of Paradox Games and is consequently going to be much more expensive. However, the quality of the product must match the price. Paradox's DLC policy has always been unwelcoming and harsh to newcomers. If the rest of the 'expansions' are like Royal Court, than this situation will only make things much worse while hurting loyal players. I simply cannot recommend this expansion at this price and I do hope that Paradox re-evaluate this policy.

TL/DR Pros/Cons
Pros:
- Fletched out new systems: Artifacts, Culture
- New systems that adds flavor: Courts, Customization of Banners/Crests
- Tons of new ways to play the game with 10+ new Court Positions and Culture divergences.
- Great Mod-Support, playing the DLC with supported mods can increase the size of it ten-fold. (The mods are also high quality, just look through the Crusader Kings 3 Twitter Feed)

Cons:
- Can feel a little extra spammy with pop-ups at times
- The 'Hold Court' Interaction and Random Court Interactions sometimes feel pointless, tedious and may take more away than it gives.

People need to chill with their ranting about the price-tag.
This DLC changes your entire game, and it comes with a free major update for anyone less interested.
All cultures are changed with new systems, fundamentals and progressions, which changes the flow of your -entire- playthrough. 
They did it in a good way too, that adds depth but doesn't make it tedious. 
The artifacts are nice rounded system, which if you truly dig into, can boost and bolster your entire empire to almost overpowered extremes. 

Suggestions for improvement:
- Change the court scene in an Empire, so that it doesn't just appear as a Kingdom Court
- More customizations options for the court itself, so that we may make it a bit more personal (beyond artifact showcases)
- Balance the 'Dual for Artifact' interaction, can't believe a 40 prowess absolute mountain of a man can lose to a 91 year old granny
- Reduce the amount of random cultural divergences happening, as it gets quite overwhelming
- Generally reduce the spread of random cultures and hybrid cultures everywhere, as it feels as though you can't even hope to have an empire of the same culture anymore.
- Make more options to interact with the new court positions (Jester, Bodyguard, etc.) as currently it's almost always the same random prompts you get.

Overall, I recommend this DLC even at it's price-point. Though, with free update adding in a bunch of the quality content anyway, I can understand why you'd let this one simmer a bit till they update it once more.

I got the dlc as part of the preorder of the royal edition of ck3, i paid 60 euros for the total package. Now they released this single expansion at the price of 30 euros, which makes it the most expensive PDS dlc ever. Their main excuse for the increased pricepoint was that the expansions for CK3 would be massive and gamechanging, however, RC adds barely enough content to be priced at 20 euros (like holy fury for CK2), I would even say that 15 is a more suitable price. Most of their development efforts were spent on making the court itself, which left the expansion lacking in substance in regards to mechanics, pretty graphics is not content.

This expansion makes me worry that the decision to go 3D for CK3 was a bad one, as it maimed their development time by forcing to allocate resources to make the 3D models work. If their following expansions are also gonna take so long to release and will spend so much effort on graphics over new game mechanics - CK3 will never reach it's true potential.

If the expansion arrived 6 months sooner and was priced at 15-20 euros, most of the complaints would be gone. Sadly that was not the case and after waiting for almost a full year we got what feels like a dissappointment.

I had mixed feelings at first b/c of the price and some limitations on Royal Court (no courts for tribes or dukes), but after putting a few hours in I really enjoy it. It is hard to separate out the free patch features and paid DLC, but as a whole I love all the content they added (inventory, culture, court). I've always preferred CK for the role playing element, and can easily get bored as I blob through late game so having another RPG element is really quite welcome. The best part is I am losing track of time managing my court, which makes me more content to not constantly be expanding my borders. 

Yes it is 30 bucks, but hey that's inflation for you lol. I am hopeful they will maybe find a way to add the features in for tribes and dukes in the future. I've encountered no bugs or anything so it seems like a well made DLC.

Sure it's overpriced. But the features are cool.
As always with Paradox, wait for a sale or a bundle.

PS: For those with GPU usage issues, overheating or overall lag in the court room, try disabling the character animations.

Wie so oft wird mal wieder die harte Arbeit eines Studios in den Steam Reviews nicht gewürdigt, sondern nur kritisiert und deswegen gebe nun auch ich meinen Senf dazu.

Royal Court ist eine wunderbare Erweiterung zu dem Spiel und es fördert die Immersion des Spiels wie nichts was ich jemals zuvor in einem Crusader Kings Game erleben durfte. Der Königshof lädt die Spieler geradezu ein am Spielgeschehen teilzunehmen, indem die Spieler endlich richtige Anfragen, Bitten und Wünsche ihrer Vasallen und ihrer Höflinge erhalten. So wie es im mittelalterlichen Feudalsystem nun mal war.

Ist das DLC deshalb perfekt: Nein. Es gibt noch vieles das ausgebaut und verbessert werden sollte. Wie die Anzahl der möglichen Events, die Möglichkeit auch als Herzog einen solchen Hof zu haben oder auch der ein und andere Bug. Potential gibt es massenweise und ich bin mir sicher das Paradox mich da in Zukunft nicht enttäuschen wird. 
Darum will ich die Entwickler unbedingt weiterhin unterstützen, sodass es sich für sie auch rentiert weiter an dem DLC zu arbeiten.

The majority of the down votes are from people complaining about the price of the DLC which is valid enough, however it does add more than enough content to overhaul the game completely. New and improved cultures, artifacts, events, a new court system which brings more flavor to the game and many more. The only criticism I have is that tribal nations are completely left out which makes no sense as they too would have had courts of their own, as well as dukes regardless of being independent or a vassal, which is also another major reason for the negative feedback. However in saying that this is easily one of Paradox's most ambitious addition to any of their games and the future looks bright with future content for this game. Also the modding scene behind Crusader Kings three is insane as hundreds of mods have been created to further enhance your experience with additional content.

Lots of new interactions and minor events that reinforces the character roleplaying.
I really like the new culture system and that it is tied into the existing culture "tech tree" system. Now you need to consider a lot more of pros and cons of which culture you belong to. I like it better than the separated systems from ck2, and I hope to see it causes the world to be more diverse, on top of the diversity of government type and religion. 

Inventory system is a good, and a good foundation for mods and stuff to come.
Not so pleased with the court UI, holding court, hiring artisans and setting displays in the court itself is a lot of repetitive clicking, but can be improved as feedback checks in. Many good new events in the court, many dependant on two AI characters internal relations so now you have more reason to get to know your vassals not only in relation to you, but between themselves.I hope they dont become too repetive. 

I do get why the lower noble titles dont get a full court, it is better this way, it keeps the new options reserved for greater powers, instead of watering it down to be accessible to some degree for all. Also, it is not "locked", you are just expected to take part in your lieges court instead, and there is plenty to gain from it. 

I dont like that more actions are put into the existing advisors roles. Especially the steward has way too many important tasks to do, and he can't split his attention, instead has to focus 100% on one out of many important tasks.  I might not have encountered a "passive" cultural shift mechanic yet, but I feel it could be needed, unless the steward unloads to some jobs to other advisors.  

It is fair for people to critizise the price, but I am a big fan of starting out with dedicating DLC to developing strong foundations for core mechanics, and this is important for the main game but also for modding. There is much work put into this, culture is huugely important, and is not at a scale similar to the new religion system which is also a great foundation for many years of modding and expansions. New "content" like government types and regional content can come along the way. Maybe if the developers helped us understand the minor new features better, like "700 new dialogues" alongside "inventory system" it would help people understand what they are paying for. It takes time to encounter it all, yet here we are giving thumps up and down within 24 hours of release. 

Now there is a lot to do as kings and empires. I hope to see more government types in the future, and options for building tall as the lowest counts.
Really enjoying it so far. That said, it does need a lot of balancing and fixes.

When you pre-order CK3 this expansion came included and having also owned CK2 and knowing all the much better DLC they could have done for 30$ I can't say that im happy this is the DLC you get for the pre-order. Don't get me wrong what they have added are some cool features but not DLC worthy, more like a larger flavour pack. It's also worth saying that you can only access the actual "Royal Court" part of the DLC when youre a King/Queen or Emperor/Empress and not the lower titles that most playthrough start as. So like basically every other review on this DLC, No its not worth 30$, If you want it buy it on sale, and If I could have chosen a different DLC along the line for the pre-order I would have.
Wish they add an option to customize the appearance of the court. Other than that, it's pretty solid.
Great DLC!

The selling point of this dlc the royal court is stupid and takes you off the map to look at pretty pictures. The mechanics it adds culture mixing and artifacts are pretty nice though. Not worth the cash at all. Seriously why waste so much time 3d modeling stuff for something that basically adds no value to the game?

Update: After some 20+ hours of play and strategic cultural mixing (cultures main function seems to be to quickly knock out some innovations by hybridization) finally made it feudal and got my royal court. And boy, what a let down it is. Seriously, what is this? Visually, looks as bad as in the development diary pictures. Awkward few second animation loops or completely static characters. Functionally pointless. The court grandeur is just a punitive system (get to a certain level by spending gold to avoid punishments) with limited benefits (good to know that as Emperor people are now more willing to accept my children for tutoring...) Events are meh, 3 petitioners asking for random stuff, usually money or court appointment. But they don't even play out in court, it is still a textbox. The thrown-together "adult" visual novels that flood the new release page of steam have more visual interactivity than the royal court. Most of the time it is easy to forget that there is even a royal court, so disconnected it is from everything else: it is basically a completely self-contained subsystem because somebody at Paradox just doesn't understand that I did not want a dollhouse to display their mediocre 3D assets.

Ultimately does Royal Court make the game better? Not really, its additions are disconnected and have very limited affect on how the game is played. Does it make it worse? Kind of, royal courts are just a massive resource sink, court positions are convoluted, and culture now overlaps with religion in weird ways. What the DLC definitely does is put a nail in the coffin of any hope that Paradox can or is interested in delivering major additions to the underlying game.

I had this nagging feeling throughout the dev diaries and the whole game that royal court was some developer's gf/bf idea and they were very proud of it, so the dev had to put it into the game or sleep on the couch. How divorced royal court is from what the game actually needs (better economy, better warfare, better alliances, better diplomacy, etc.) it is as good an explanation as any.

                                                                     *****

There is just nothing major here: the cultural mechanics only imparts small differences and are pretty safe to ignore. Artifacts are ok, but it is not a major mechanical addition.

The most egregious thing is that after all this wait, half the people won't even get the courtroom or have to wait hundreds of years to do so. The idea that it would not be available for tribal leaders is just  ridiculous: playing as Hungary (one of the recommended starts) it takes centuries to become feudal because of the way that progression is set up. One can have an empire level title but still can't hold court? After 18 hours of play, the key selling feature of the DLC is still unavailable to my non-feudal empire. By the time I will eventually get to it, I doubt I will care at all. It is such a weird decision, it fits into the generally questionable mindset of Paradox perfectly.

Overall, it was a lot of build-up for a decisive dud. After all the anticipation, the DLC is thoroughly forgettable and is not a major addition to the game. Other Paradox games delivered a lot more for/with a lot less. Waiting almost an entire year with no content for this is just a let-down. This is the kind of DLC one would expect at the end of a game's life cycle: minor fluff to fill out some gaps, none that is essential to make the game better. As first DLC (and after all the hype) one could reasonably expect something significantly grander than this.

Coat of Arms designer is good, but it should have been a base game feature.

Also, not sure whether it is a DLC or Mod issue, but suddenly everyone is wearing turbans and random clothing which is both jarring and slightly amusing.

This feels like they delivered it to fulfil the DLC promise with as little work as possible either (a) saving anything more substantial for future paid DLC that will be out of the season pass most of the community got or (b) to sunset development on the game. How inconsequential the whole thing is, it really feels like an obligation they wanted to get out of, rather than any form of passion for developing the DLC.

A strong meh out of 10. Worth the wait? No. Worth the money? No. Would I buy it if I didn't already own it? No. So much about taking longer time to deliver larger DLC I guess. The way this cursed industry is going, I guess I should be thankful that the artefacts are not NFTs.

This dlc is pricy and does add some mechanics which if min-maxed could become very overpowered.

After waiting 6 months for this expansion pack, I wish i could give it a "neutral" or "mixed" review because it's neither good or bad, maybe disappointing is the right word. It is extremely overpriced for a few mechanics that are fun but get tedious very quickly. When waging a long term war, getting notifications about an inspired person, or the court, or even your artefacts breaking down gets tiring real fast.

I think I used the court for about 2 hours before getting bored- but it's cool that you can decorate the court room. It'd be better if it wouldn't scream at you with notifications but rather your Antiquarian did it automatically (maybe with a higher wage, or it cost you more monthly). 

The new roles at court are cool, it definitely gives a better role-play aspect which makes the game more enjoyable. I also had hoped for more cosmetics as the title "Royal Court" suggests new additions to the ruler's aesthetic as well as the court's aesthetic.

Merging cultures was something I was looking forward to, I was desperately trying to merge cultures but after about 7 hours I realised it won't benefit my culture in anyway. Maybe I need to try it again, but it seems minimally beneficial- maybe useful for multiplayer with people from different cultures?

I wish this expansion pack was better, at this point it feels on the same level as the Northern Lords pack... and wasn't that a flavour pack? My favourite part of the game's update wasn't this expansion pack... but customisable coat of arms
The court is neat but it is limited to non-tribal kings and emperors, and doesn't come close to the full expansion scale they are charging for.  Don't buy unless you can get it for at least 50% off.

As others have said, the amount of content is pathetic for the price. The ideas/content here aren't bad and I suppose one should give them some credit for making something genuinely new for CK.

However, this new (and small) system is coming into CK3 while it still has a shadow of the content that was in CK2. There is so much missing in this game that adding in something so superficial almost seems like an insult. It's painful because there is so much potential in this game, but the developers are failing to build to it.

Just to be clear, I am a big fan of CK3 and it is the game I play most.
I was looking forward to the extension but must admit I am a bit disappointed.
Beside the price, which seems high for what the extension is actually adding, I expected, after all the hype put out there by the developers, a lot more.
The inventory is fine and a really nice addition. It does not seems to have yet the impact on the game play I would have expected but I accept that I may have expected too much and maybe the impact should not be that severe.
Traditions etc are maybe interesting but seem to me more an endgame feature as the requirements to be able make any changes (prestige) are very high. So until now I have not used it.
The one thing I really do not understand at all is that the "throne room" or "royal court" is not available to tribe based governments. There is no real logical reason for that. I am currently the King of Ireland and also holding about a third of England and Wales. But as I am still tribal I can not access the royal court. Do the developers think that a ruler on "king" level would not have decided on disputes or tried to display grandeur only because they were still in a tribal environment ? Even if only located in a long house or larger "hut" they would have. I just do not see the need for this restriction or even historical relevance if you like. So at the moment someone who likes to play on tribal level misses out on about half of the extension.
On another note, I do have the feeling that a few bugs have been introduced into the game that I have never encountered before. I went to battle with about 8000 men against 2500. The quality of the troops were even. I was winning and the opponent was down to about 400 men when suddenly the battle window shuts down and I was declared the looser of the battle with my about 6000 remaining troops running away from the 400 of my opponent. This happened all in all three times, but only after the royal court release. Also I "swayed" another character. I was successful, but instead of the relationship improving the character disliked me for 25 points more rather than less. Again this has not happened before since I have been playing the game (since its release). This looks a bit like a pattern, ie a minus sign in the wrong place of the code. 

The AI of allied troops still is really really bad. There seems to be no logic. Together with my allies I outnumber the enemy by 2:1 but my allies are standing around next to me not engaging while I get slaughtered. And it is even their war not mine ! 
Anyway this is something that has been around from the beginning... sigh.

All in all, not what I expected. Even taking covid into account it seems that it took too long to get out. I can not get away from the feeling that maybe the developers were starting off with features that sometime down the line proved difficult or even impossible to implement. Potentially part of the additions they wanted to introduce were scrapped or watered down in order to be able to release the extension at all. With this in mind I could see that covid may have had a real impact here. Especially in the design phase of a software project sketchy communication can bring about that the project goes down a rabbit hole and ends up in a dead end. Something that under normal circumstances would have been detected a lot earlier. To recover from that is difficult. 
Anyway, so all in all not great. I would hope that the developers use the fact that a lot of people are disappointed as a pointer and resolve any bugs asap and remove the arbitrary restriction of the throne room.
So my 'no' recommendation is to make sure that the developers take note that things are not as they should be or could have been.

I know you can't compare two, but the Northern Lords flavor pack was packed with content to the brim and was rated accordingly - mostly positive. For some reason this DLC, while adding not much in terms of content (and it is still far worse in quality than certain mods on Steam Workshop), Paradox put a 30$ price tag on this.  

Only feudal kings and emperors can hold court, so people like me, who like to start from a single county, can't enjoy the new mechanics until you get to the "king" status. It is weird. 

For me, CK3 is more about roleplaying and while this DLC claims to be focusing on roleplaying aspect of the game (more events, artifacts, and so on), it's not available from the start of the game and I personally think that's the problem. You, as the player, should be able to have "Court" as any lord of any tier, starting from count or tribal or whatever. Counts and Dukes had their own courts and at some points of history, those courts could be more grandeur than that of their liege's. And it most certainly would've improved the roleplay aspect of the game, cause you have these interactions and the progression of your court (from rags to riches) from the start of the game. (Remember the societies in CK2? Now imagine them locked behind duke tier or Learning stat or something like that) Like, we have events in the game where you, as a Viking lord, deal with disputes and stuff on ting-meets, but the "Court" mechanic is unavailable for you.  Who thought that was a good idea?

Artifacts are cool, nothing bad to say about them, except it would be nice, again, to have MORE control of your narrative. When I order a weapon to be made for my Viking king, I want it to be an axe, since he's an "axe expert" as was stated in the event. Instead, I have a 33% chance to make an axe, war hammer, mace, and else. Like, why can't I choose to make an axe, war hammer or mace is beyond me, apparently kings paid in advance for a cat in a bag. 

The Court Room 3D screen is nice, but again, you can't change the looks of the room, you just have some slots for court artifacts to put into, that's it. The player doesn't really have control of his own stuff and that's disappointing. The camera angles are locked so you can't really see who's petitioning you and the whole scene really looks not so alive, with characters frozen in place, without even an idle animation (imagine having an idle animation, isn't it something?).

What else do we have? Making hybrid cultures and divergent cultures is all about combining modifiers you like and choosing how your units look. It's okayish... but I guess it would be much to ask for something more deep and creative from a game development studio that spent almost a year developing this DLC and charges 30$ for it? Oh, I dunno. 

All in all, not much content, and the content we have is rather bland and unimaginative in my humble opinion. I paid for the deluxe or whatever version of CK3 that got me this DLC for "free", but the price they charge is rather high. 10$ - yeah, but the content here is worth 5$ and it is still too much. 

I really wanna love CK3 and Paradox and I was actually expecting them to make something good and of high quality, after 8 months this game went without any updated but if this DLC is a quality mark for the future, then I guess CK3 will never be better than CK2 and it sucks.

Not worth the price. If this was $15, then I think it would be worth it, but at $30 this is a travesty. The base game is currently $33 and even though that is a stripped down version of CK2, it still contains an entire game. This DLC gives you a 3D room which you will tire of soon and some artifacts to display. In fact a modder has already released a massive mod that gives you more customization options than the devs put in. What an absolute embarrassment to the devs that should be. I now truly believe Paradox is going to royall fu$k Victoria 3 and all us poor saps should avoid it like the plague.

RC ajoute trois mécaniques de jeux qui viendront interagir avec ce qui est déjà là pour proposer encore plus d'opportunités pendant les parties : les inspirations (basées sur les capacités des personnages à votre Cour, qui vont générer des événements et des artefacts), les mécaniques de Cour (niveau de Magnificence, doléances avec les nobles et les roturiers qui pourront mener à des situations nouvelles, artefacts de la Cour), et tout un gameplay lié aux cultures hybrides et divergentes, qui va malmener la carte dans toutes sortes de directions différentes à chaque partie.

Globalement, le DLC ajoute plus de CK à CK3, même s'il se focalise surtout sur les royaumes féodaux. Et c'est ce que les personnes sensées lui demandaient.

8 aydir topluluk olarak dört gözle bekledigimiz bir DLC idi Royal Court. Her bir gelistirici günlügünü tercüme edip videolar halinde hafta hafta paylastim. Dolayisiyla bu paketin gelistirme asamasinda ne denli çetrefilli yollardan geçtigine tanik olmus ve oyunu toplamda Game Pass + Steam'de 1300 saati askin bir süre oynamis biriyim. Yani neden bahsettigimi biliyorum.

Okudugum kadariyla negatif yorumlarin büyük çogunlugu 30$/€'luk fiyata tepki gösteren yabanci arkadaslardan gelmis ki fiyat gerçekten çok yüksek ve anlasilabilir bir durum. Fakat Paradox'un oldum olasi is modeli bu. Oyunun vanilya halini binanin temeli olarak görüp, zamanla DLC'lerle insaati tamamliyorlar. Bu model benim de hosuma gitmiyor zira bir oyunu satin aldigimda tüm içeriklerine aninda erisebilmek isterim fakat Paradox bu sekilde çalisiyor ve bunu degistirmeleri  - yakin gelecekte - mümkünmüs gibi görünmüyor. Royal Court'un oyuna ekledigi 3D taht odasi yeniligi misal Paradox'un daha öncesinde hiç girmedigi bir toptu dolayisiyla bu süreçte ekibini büyütmesi gerekti ve bu da maliyete yansidi. 

Oyuna negatif Türkçe yorum atan arkadaslarsa gördügüm kadariyla Royal Court'un ne vaat ettigini tam olarak takip etmemis ve CK2'nin 8 yilda 72 DLC ile getirebildigi içerige RC sayesinde tek bir DLC ile ulasmayi beklemis arkadaslar. Yani TR'de olay abes bir sekilde CK2 vs CK3'e dönüyor hep. Bombos bir tartisma zira PDX is modelini degistirmedigi takdirde bu arkadaslarin CK4 çiktiginda da ayni kavgayi CK3 vs CK4 baglaminda sürdüreceklerini öngörmek için müneccim olmaya gerek yok. Esas meseleyi kaçiriyorlar. DLC'nin TR fiyati globalde 30$ iken bizde 50<U+20BA>, dolayisiyla TL'nin mevcut deger kaybini düsününce ne yazik ki pek sikayet edebilecegimiz bir durum degilmis gibi duruyor.

Royal Court ile ilgili sahsi yorumum ise su sekilde: Royal Court'a dair ne bekliyorsam karsimda buldum. Bir oyuncu ve bu oyunu globalde Twitch üzerinde en fazla yayinlamis içerik üretici olarak gelen içerigin vaat edilenden fazlasini sundugunu görmek beni çok mutlu etti. RC ile birlikte Paradox oyuna tonla yeni mekanik ekledi ve tüm bunlar ileride gelecek DLC'ler için oyunun mevcut temelini daha da saglamlastirdi. CK3 eksiklerine ragmen esi benzeri olmayan bir 4x RPG oyunu. Umarim gelecek DLC'ler için 8-9 ay beklemek zorunda kalmayiz zira bence negatif yorumlarin temelinde aslen insanlarin bu DLC'ye dair beklentilerinin içerik kurakligina bagli olarak sürreal seviyelere ulasmis olmasi yatiyor.

Sonuç: Royal Court'un etrafinda dönen dramayi degil de sundugu içerigi merak edip yorumlara göz attiysaniz size tavsiyem bu DLC'yi kaçirmamaniz yönünde olur.

Der DLC bietet interessante und gut durchdachte Mechaniken rund um den königlichen & kaiserlichen Hof und damit wunderbare Möglichkeiten zum Rollenspiel. Einige Features kommen sogar mit dem kostenlosen Patch.

About the court itself:

You can't actually look around your court. You can't tell people where to stand. 
Displayable Court Artifacts have a few pre-designated spots with pre-designated pedestals; so no decorating your court as you like it.
They are also severely limited in number.
Holding Court is actually just a time-gated decision that gives you 3 mini-events in sequence.
Sometimes you get random little events that you have to open your court view for and click the person.

Not all of the court events even take you into the court but appear as a normal event window; such as when your vassals voluntarily decide to pay homage to you. In your court. Except it happens in a normal event window.
Several of the court events are just very obvious references to popular works or memes which atleast for me broke what little immersion the court itself provided.

It doesn't at all feel like YOUR court; it doesn't even feel like A court.
It feels like an ugly pre-rendered background that you can slap your war loot into.
This is made especially jarring by the beauty of the base game's main menu background images.
I feel like painted static backgrounds like the menu images would have been better, not to mention equally functional as there are maybe four camera angles you ever see your court from.

About the cultural system:

It's fairly simplistic and horribly unbalanced.
Most of the traditions don't tell you exactly what they do, so you have to look the numbers up.
You can't pick your balance of ethnicities for your new culture when hybridising. The game arbitrarily decides it.

Overall the DLC feels very unfinished.
The amount of content it provides is extremely limited.
As such the price is extremely high for what it provides.

I do not recommend buying it.
I personally only own it because I pre-ordered the CK3 version with it included.

At the time of writing the DLC content has lots of small to medium bugs and feels very untested.

Being able to see my court and all my courtiers is a huge plus for me. It makes the fiction of being a ruler seem more real to me, and not just me staring at the map the whole time  
The free update of the culture rework is great; it gives some more variety and uniqueness to the whole game world, and being able to hybridize/diverge cultures gives you a way to tweak that. 

This update doesn't change how you play the game; it's more subtle than that. But it is a welcome addition.

At this price, nope. It's good. There are some good things here. However, it's very buggy and there isn't enough content. At this price, there's about 10% of the content you'd expect. Artefacts are a nice system, but in actual fact they aren't very good.  And they decay. And you need to spend money not only to repair them, but to have someone capable of repairing them. At this juncture, they are just a money sink - a means of addressing an imbalanced economy.

The courts are grossly limited. You can only be Feudal or Clan, you can only be a King or Emperor. The idea that Dukes can't have courts is not only silly, it's a-historical. 

It's just ... weak. It'd be a bit weak at $15, but it's very weak at $30.

It is not worth the price at this time.

This DLC expands the game on a number of points. The most visible addition is the Royal Court in 3D. It's a shame it's not available to everyone and no alternative is offered for tribals or dukes. Because having a Royal Court and holding court is a nice addition. Also the artifacts that you can place in your inventory or your court are nice. My first artifact was the skull of a local bandit lord. Which was subsequently inherited by my successors and has remained a permanent part of the court. That contributes to telling your family's story. I haven't really played with the adjustments to culture yet.

In terms of content, I think Royal Court is a good DLC. I bought this DLC as part of the Royal Edition. I understand that developing this DLC takes time and money, and maybe more than usual because of the 3D court. This translates into a higher price for the buyer. Whether that price is really justified for what you get is up to each individual to determine. But I can imagine that the fact that not every ruler has a Royal Court means that many people find the current purchase price too high.

I'll echo what most are saying. The content itself is not "bad," per say...it adds some nice flavor content to the game where you can "hold court" and make some decisions as your vassals plea to you for this or that. It also adds some immersion to see your player and you court standing around the room. That being said, it is really not that deep of an expansion. The free update itself added some solid content, but this DLC itself doesn't add more than just some nice flavor on top of an already good game. Additionally, the $30 price tag is truly criminal, but, if you play this game as much as I do, you will likely get it to support the developers and because, let's face it, if you love the game, you're going to get every DLC to get as much content as possible into the game. 

TL;DR Highly overpriced, but, if money isn't a concern, it adds a little bit of flavor to the game. Not much though. You could definitely live without it and enjoy the game.

I prepurchased the Royal Edition of CK3, so essentially paid for this DLC before the base game was released.

There are a lot of negative reviews about the price - my take is:
a) The changes to the game make it a "meaningful" expansion (thinking back to CK2, where some DLC was really essential, others completely pointless);
b) A lot of these changes are available in the free Fleur-de-Lis Patch (patch notes: https://forum.paradoxplaza.com/forum/threads/ck3-dev-diary-89-1-5-0-fleur-de-lis-patch-notes.1509587/ );
c) Don't forget that the base game of CK3 included a lot of the best DLC features of CK2 from the beginning.

As for the changes themselves:
1. The Royal Court: Apart from 3D rendering of the court itself, displaying artifacts and (customisable) banners, the Hold Court Interaction adds RP elements through opt-in events, and can lead to a variety of in-game effects.
2. Cultural overhaul: Seems really detailed. Cultural traditions and ethos incentivise playing to your culture and hybridisation/divergence/reformation give longer term gameplay goals. Cultural men-at-arms are now tied to traditions, meaning you can hybridise to get longbowmen, catapharacts, horse archers, varangians and war elephants, if you really want.
3. Artifacts are back! Apart from some buffs and being able to display them in your court, you can buy claims on artifacts and scheme to steal them.
4. Minor court positions are back too.
5. Customisable banners are pretty neat - I wrote IKEA on the Swedish flag, for example.
6. Changing your realm/culture/religion's map colour is a nice touch.
7. Languages, meh, kind of just ties in with the cultural mechanics.

I'm really happy with this expansion, as you can probably tell. I'd recommend reading the patch notes and comparing the free/paid features if you are on the fence about buying it, though.
Good enough

While I understand why many people are bothered by a $30 price tag, I feel it's mostly justified. I believe an additional feature would've justified it fully, but I still feel that looking at it through the lense of almost a pseudo-"subscription service" makes more sense. 

I say this because they offer free updates all the time -- the dueling, for instance -- along with the Northern Lords flavor pack (which I would argue is underpriced at only 6.99). I have no problem supporting a dev team with only $45 per year (assuming only 2 flavor packs, 1 expansion) for all the other content that's provided over the course of 12 months, instead of having to buy a new game that doesn't expand much for $60 every 1.5-2 years. 

Not to mention that that they made many features free in this update, i.e. the cultures, which is a huge feature to make available for everyone. Many people, I believe, take free updates for granted and feel entitled to them with just the base game purchase. If people want grand strategy games like ones that Paradox makes to have fully fleshed out mechanics, then they have to embrace this kind of a model.
