Es ist kein schlechter DLC, dass muss man schon sagen. Die Frage, die man sich aber stellen sollte, ist, ob das Gebotene mit dem Preis irgendwie zu rechtfertigen ist. Und ich denke, dass der Preis arg teuer ist. 
Positiv ist, dass der Thronraum ganz nett aussieht, alle 5 Jahre kann Hof gehalten werden (u.a. Vasallen werden eingeladen, es gibt Eventketten) und es gibt eine nette 3D Animation der Artefakte und des Thronaales bei statischer Kamera.

Die Artefakte kennt man aus CK2 und sieht hier ebenfalls gut umgesetzt. Sie können wieder angefertigt, erobert oder in Auftrag gegeben werden. Zudem besteht die Möglichkeit aus ihnen verschiedene Boni zu erhalten, wie erhöhte Prachtstufen, mehr Prestige etc. 

Dass ist alles auch ok. Aber a) nicht bei dem Preis und b) hätte der Gameplayanteil des Patches/DLC deutlich höher ausfallen müssen. Denn: ihr werdet in einer neuen Partie mit dem DLC nicht viel anders spielen als zuvor. Und das ist schade.

I, impulsively, brought this for full price and while I've found it enjoyable enough, it is disappointing and shallow with its features for its hefty price. 

- Cultures. Best part so far, really allows for customisation and language learning is nice immersive feature. But most of this feature came for free, making the actual dlc's price even harder to swallow. 

- Royal Court. A neat feature that is quickly forgotten about. Court events are a bit too rare and are rather repetitive, and there's no really no other reason to use the Court. Events such as Coronations, Weddings, Council Meetings and more would've really helped flesh out this feature and give it more reason to exist. The fact that tribal governments don't get one really restricts enjoyment of the previously fun Norse and Mongolian cultures. It would have also been nice for dukes and counts to receive a court, and there for to be graphic differences when court grandeur increases. 

- Artefacts. Neat but little more than modifiers in the end. Would've been nice if you could display more of them in the court. 

- Price. I would not recommend full price. In terms of content, Royal Court feels just as substantive as the far cheaper Northern Lords dlc. Don't do what I did, and just wait for this dlc to go on sale. 

Hopefully, in the future, Paradox can build on these royal court features but this dlc should've been more for its price.

So I buy the Royal Court DLC, fire up CK3 for the first time in a while, and settle in for another epic session of inbreeding. A few hours of familiar gameplay in, it dawns on me, "Oh right, the DLC! I should do DLC stuff". So there I am, poking around in the game looking for DLC stuff to do. Hey, let's commission an artifact because that's a thing, right? So I click a few prompts, wait, and hooray, there's my shiny new whatever. I equip it then immediately forget all about it because its impact on the game is virtually meaningless. Next I decided to learn another language because that's a thing, right? So I dedicate 6 years of my character's miserable, gout-ridden life to learning another language, and hooray, I now know 2 languages. I think it applies a modifier somewhere because, you know, unseen math equations are fun. I immediately forget my character learned it because its impact is virtually meaningless. Then I look at the culture divergence only to see that it's a less interesting version of the core game's religion reformation mechanic. Yada yada, you see where this is going.

My review is simply: I fail to see the point.

Money down the drain.

Just because this DLC took a year longer than it should have doesn't mean mismanaged production costs should be passed on to the consumer. If this is their pricing plan the complete edition of Crusader Kings 3 is going to be the most ridiculously expensive Paradox game yet. I guess Europa Universalis 4 with DLC being almost $500 wasn't enough profit margin. Unless you got this with the deluxe edition of CK3 there's no way in hell this is worth the price. Wait for heavy sale.

Royal Court is a solid DLC, however, it is not even close to being worthy of its $30 price point, nor its massive delay. It's a real shame. What's included with Royal Court is good, not great. The court gimmick is cool, but is functionally no different from any other event. The minor court positions are more interesting and more impactful than in CK2, but again is functionally no different. The artifacts are cool, but functionally no different from CK2. Hopefully with the end of restrictions in Sweden Paradox will get their house in order and start making decent products again.

I find the DLC enjoyable and fun since I like Crusader Kings, however there are major glaring issues regarding what could've been.

Firstly, the DLC has a pricetag of $30, which should be much cheaper. The price is unnecessary and doesn't fit for the content that it adds. The DLC content is good, but not worth the 30 dollars.

Next, the lack of royal courts is a problem. The purpose of the royal court DLC is to bring a court system to all of Europe, however these courts are limited to solely King and Emperor titles. There are no courts for Counts, Dukes, or Tribal nations, which all should have courts based on the time it took to make this DLC and how much was advertised. Not once in the process of advertising this DLC did I, the average consumer, notice that the Royal Court was not for Count or Duke titles. This information was really kept on the down low and my disappointment when I couldn't have a court as a duke was a lot. The mods that allows Duke's to have courts though are very poor because of the way the system is implemented, it allows for a single court language to dominate the map within 50 years for whatever reason, usually Greek, so those aren't any solutions to this problem.

Overall, fun and good content, but not worth the price and definitely underwhelming for what was advertised and hyped.
Finally

The pricing of this add-on tops even the most over-priced Paradox DLCs as e.g. for Stellaris. While the contents is nice to have, it is not essential. For EUR 8, it might have been a solid and good bargain. I am beginning to step away from Paradox games and focus more on Matrixgames, if this is the future path, Paradox intends to follow.

I agree with many of the common negative reviews here. I love the base game, and what this adds *is* great and different - but it's just too narrowly applied.

You can view your royal court as a king rank or higher - but only if you are a kingdom or clan government. This should not be restricted - I want to see nomad khans in their tents gathering their kin and norse chiefs in their mead halls with their clans! Each major government would have had some form of 'court'.

Also - I would even argue that lower ranking can have a form of mundane meeting as well - greatly restricted, but could still call low borns or something.

Also, the rule where 'holding court' is restricted to 5 years. Why? - Why not give a major penalty if held within 5 years instead? - make it increasingly costly to hold court frequently - but it just seems arbitrary to take it away for 5 years.

Again, it feels weird - because it is good - but you won't get to see it unless you be very specific with the type of character/civilisation you play.

I feel like they are going to break up what should have been a fuller experience into two different DLCs because $$$$$$$$$$.

TL;DR - what is added is intriguing and unique, but the narrow application of it doesn't make it worth it.

Lot of reviews bashing the amount of content being insufficient based on the price of the update, and I understand that.  However, it is becoming increasingly difficult to come out with expansions that modders can't already do.  Why should Paradox waste resources flushing out portions of a game that the fan base is capable and willing to do on their own if they choose to do so.  In this regard, I applaud Paradox for taking a completely different approach and implementing very in-depth features.  And guess what, the mods will take what Paradox has given them, and extend the limits of the game even further.  I'm excited to explore further the nooks and crannies of this expansion, and am ecstatic to see what modders are able to do with it.  The sky is the limit.

Por mucha calidad que tenga un DLC, no es normal, ni justo que cueste la mitad un DLC que el precio de un juego: 30 euros. Además que con el formato digital que está en auge en los videojuegos, puedes conseguir en oferta muchísimos juegos por simplemente 10 euros y tirarte cientos de horas. Paradox abusa claramente de marketing y de precios excesivos en todos sus juegos, pero este se lleva el premio al más exageradamente caro y abusivo.
En cuanto al contenido de este DLC, no es una expansión, yo lo encuentro divertido, me gusta su contenido, sus logros, pero no es una expansión es simplemente una característica. Te permite ver una corte de tu reino y cambiar la cultura de tu reino para hacerla que se mezcle con otra.

Paradox una humilde idea y petición al mismo tiempo: saca más contenido de historias escritas como cuando le das a jugar a un jugador, que salgan varios reinos, pongan una descripción de cada uno de forma histórica y que haya logros por conseguir victorias con cada uno. Otra cosa que le falta a los juegos de estrategia de Paradox es más contenido descriptivo (un codex), hay juegos de acción y rol que tienen más contexto que los juegos de Paradox, esto es simplemente un gran fallo.

Shallow and mostly meaningless changes for a game a year and a half after launch at an inflated price point.
I mean the 3D court is cool for about 20 seconds (does anything actually happen in the 3D court? No), the culture stuff is an afterthought most of the time. 

The court, artifacts management and creation, minor titles and offices all add additional costs for players but this DLC and the patch offer very little in terms of a way to supplement income and that is all in conjunction with the nonsensical economy that existed in this game from launch (and CK2 as well to be fair) Hiring an bodyguard shouldn't cost half the entire monthly income of a county, hiring a physician shouldn't be 1/4 the price of building a brand new castle. So now the economy still makes no sense and there are easily 10-20 ducats of additional costs to be incurred for a mid tier court and a few minor titles.

The problem is readily apparent as well, most people even when complimenting RC lean heavily on the idea that this will be expanded on at some later time or that creative modders will have a field day both may be true but if those are the highest praise that can be offered then it reflects poorly on the product's individual merits currently.

The main feature of the DLC is the royal court a feature only available to Feudal or Clan Kings and Emperors which is honestly so baffling I can't believe anyone who actually plays CK regularly play-tested that and thought that it was a good idea ( so good luck if you want to play pagan tribes or anyone below King tier for an extended period maybe check back in 2-3 years)

I seem to be in a minority, but I think the pricing is valid. It’s expensive, yes, but considering the amount of content added for free alongside I think it’s a fair price. Just because the content is free doesn't mean the dev team shouldn’t get a paycheck for their efforts.

Looks like shit. Until the mods that make this game playable are updated, don't buy it.

Way too expensive for what it adds, typical for Paradox, still cementing their legacy as the most greedy developer in the gaming industry next to EA.

This is also one of those DLCs that makes you question the competence of the devs working on it. Lots of the mechanics make very little sense, add tedious levels of micromanagement or are just extremely underwhelming/generic:

- Court Amenities get RESET/lowered on succession, which means when your character dies, for some reason your entire court just stops functioning: It goes from serving the best exotic meals to bread and soup in a matter of a day, everyone exchanges their fine garbs for peasant's attire, all the "Endless servants" disappear into thin air and your Grand lodgings get reverted back to shared bedrooms and straw mats. It also takes a long time to get your "Court Grandeur" back over time. WHY? No clue, I suppose this is their idea of balance, but it makes absolutely no sense and just means you have to do even more micro management on leader death. Speaking of which:

-The reset also applies to Court Positions, which there's many, many of now. you have to click through and find proper characters for each (with "Aptitudes" that aren't explained at all), and of course every character dies sooner or later, so you endlessly have to look for new ones. You don't even get notifications when those important Courtiers die. Micro is good and all, but not really fun when all you're doing is getting minor boosts for a few years and you have to keep eyes open in several different menus.

- Items/Artifacts are alright, but mostly the same generic stat sticks with very minor increases to secondary stats you'll barely need. Has some immersion/nonsensical issues which seems to be the theme of this DLC, with weird modifiers like "+FERTILITY" on gear like scepters, but compared to the other stuff this is the most serviceable, if underwhelming, feature

-The Culture options are all good, very similar to Religion, and add even more potential for modding. But the Prestige costs are EXTREMELY expensive for making custom changes with some strange prerequisites (like not having different culture on your borders, or locked behind late innovations), so until fairly late into the game you likely won't be able to customize much. 

-For whatever godforsaken reason, Courts (the main feature of the DLC) are not available to Tribal rulers or anything below King tier. This not only makes ZERO historical sense (Genghis Khan, Longhouses, family houses that have been a thing since neolithic times and at their prime 800years BEFORE the game starts), it also makes you miss out on a lot of the content that would help especially lower rank rulers immensely.
 This decision especially just baffled me at how this could get past any sort of testing or rationality. You'd think ANYONE working at Paradox with a hint of historical knowledge would immediately bat an eye at this, but nope. You don't get to sit down in a hall and rule your lands until you reform your religion, become feudal, and become King at least, which means the majority of starts won't have access to the main content until 100+ years into the game.  It borders on developer Incompetence.

I echo other people's sentiments that the price value for this DLC (at $30 no less!) is not at all reasonable given what's been added to the game.

[hr][/hr]

Royal Court is a small DLC with very minor features in totality, which is strange as it was touted as the first major expansion for the game, and part of the Royal Edition, which I paid for. The aforementioned royal court mechanic is the main aspect of the DLC, which is effectively divided into two systems: grandeur and events. By having court, you receive three events, with petitioners asking you to decide between various decisions. Some of which, such as permitting a noble to pay [b]you[/b] for the privilege of constructing a barony, is imbalanced or broken. Occasionally your court, even when not in progress, will receive random events as well, requiring you to return to the court screen.

Personally I find this aggravating, as these events are really nothing different than the kind you'd get receive that pop up. Effectively, I have to constantly return to this screen, even when I have no other reason to, to see an event. This is a minor complaint of course, but I find that it interferes with the flow of the gameplay.

The second mechanic, grandeur, is basically just another minor mana system that benefits every avenue of your realm and family the more of it you have. Generally the best way to get it is to spend money on your court, or just to spend money on events. New and revamped court positions can also influence it, which I think is good. Artifacts can also modify the baseline rate of grandeur.

Speaking of artifacts, the system for it is robust and rather simple. You can choose to seek out an artisan to make you an artifact, at a worse quality, or wait until a notification about a traveling inspired guest happens. Always take the inspired guest, they make better artifacts for effectively the same if not more reasonable prices. Annoyingly, they seem to have crammed in the rivalry system a bit with the procurement of artifact, as I find that every artifact I commission seems to come with an event or two aggravating my Antiquarian or some person at court. To this affect, having good diplomacy helps.

The culture system seems interesting, but the paid aspect of it is relatively minor. Unless you are actively going for strange culture hybrids, or playing as a tribal or norseman, you will likely not find yourself using much of it unless you go out of your way since it comes with ridiculously high renown requirements to change something even as small as a tradition.

[hr][/hr]

Ultimately, Royal Court really isn't that special of a DLC, especially after waiting so long for it. For the price they're asking, as a supposed 'major expansion' to CK3, it causes reasonable concern to wonder what the future path for this game looks like.  Even after some long delays, the actual released content is not that significant, and in many cases (such as the royal court itself!) feels like an actual paid mod.

Personally, as a Royal Edition owner, I find it upsetting since the expansion content we paid for is so far a small norse-flavor pack and now an overpriced new screen and culture mechanics that encourage meta-play.

The dlc does not add enough content to justify $30 dollars enough said people are praising this dlc because of the neat immersion features and cool little things , but artifcats were in ck2 and 3d models are cool and the culture stuff is cool ,but even with those features and a few extra features added this dlc is no way in hell worth half a triple A game.

Sadly the Paradox method of making games and DLC is very anti-consumer, just look at the price of this DLC that adds a *minor* addition to the game that does not even effect tribal nations. Tribal nations are a good portion of the game and they unaffected by this DLC. Half the price of a full game. Ridiculous.

This expansion is not reinventing the wheel, it does not need to for me to enjoy it.  It's changes/additions are more procedural than substantive, and while I do wish they had added more, I am pleased with the increased strategic autonomy and the new mechanics. 

That said, this was simply not a $30 dollar dlc. From what I have seen so far, which is limited and may change with more playtime, it needed more substantive additions, e.g., new nations in the East, origins, units, philosophical traditions, or jesters in fancier hats. As is, it should be a $15-20 purchase for most of you. 

Nevertheless, Paradox is one of the last great strategy game companies and it has a healthy track record of post-launch content, so I am optimistic more will be added. As it stands, I am pleased with the DLC and, with any luck, it will be the first of a hearty two or three course meal.

Whether or not you like Royal Court will depend on how much you like RPGs. If you’re an RPer like me, there is a lot of cool stuff to enjoy. I love decking out my throne room with artifacts I’ve purchased (with gold or blood), and I also enjoy upgrading my character’s personal gear.  What I like most are my interactions with vassals in 3D and getting more chances to create friendships or rivalries. 

Now if you’re primarily a strategy gamer I can see this DLC being more of a disappointment. The bonuses for artifacts and court levels aren’t that game changing, and I can see strategists feeling like they need to do every interaction to squeeze out some extra renown or gold. Courts also don’t work at duke level unless you play mods. There's also the ability to reform your culture or even combine cultures. For example,  in one game I became half Norse-half Scottish as Ivar the Boneless. This is a cool feature but IMHO not as interesting as reforming religions. 

So in summary, I highly recommend if you want to feel more invested in your characters. If you’re playing this as a medieval war game it’s not worth the price.

I'm at a loss as to why this is Mixed. Majority of the reviews are screaming at the price range, not at the content of the DLC. 

Royal Court is a fantastic addition to an already-packed CK3 experience, presenting huge roleplaying opportunities and enhancing the overall experience. Heck, the artifacts help increase renown which will make it loads easier to disinherit your kids :D 

The culture rework is nothing short of fantastic. I've managed to create my own Middlehavet culture, mixing Greek with Norse, enabling me to easily rule over the Byzantine Empire as Emperor Ragnarr I Haesteinnian. 

The Hold Court mechanic is pretty cool, and though the effects aren't that profound, they simply let you do more stuff aside from the standard CK3 experience. The best part about it is you can see your characters and family members, brought to life. 

I do hope that, in the future, we'll see more customization options, as well as fully customizable courts and more varieties :)

I got this expanison through the pass so I can't really speak for the price, but as for the content, this is a lovely first expansion for CK3. As a long-time player paradox it is incredible to finally see a screen that isn't just the map, and the throne room is great for adding atmosphere to the campaign and increased peace-time interactions through the court petitions. I feel like the artifact system could be further fleshed out so you have something to do with all the excess items you end up hoarding, but it is a good start. The system of diverging and hybrid cultures is really cool, as it adds replayability to different parts of the world other than just genociding everyone into your culture each campaign. The languages are also cool but I think the court language feature could be more developed. One last thing that I really enjoyed was the new music tracks. For the last couple hundred hours of playing CK3 I've had podcasts on in the background, but these new medieval tunes have actually gotten me to turn the audio on again. Overall good stuff, especially if you already have the expansion pass. I would say wait for a sale if you don't, but this feels like must-play content for CK3, even if it is not worth the whole 30 dollars.

[B][U]Overall, I'd say the DLC and accompanying free patch is great but not perfect - massive, thoughtful, fun content, especially for roleplayers, but some issues here and there.[/U][/B] The scope of a lot of the content is not readily apparent from a superficial glance, and is under the hood or will only be encountered after either playing a lot or looking in the code directly. For context, I am speaking mainly from the PoV as a roleplayer who hates minmaxing.

The culture rework is ambitious and while wonky in a few places (such as debatable choices for some culture's traditions and ethoses) a good step in revolutionizing cultures to be more dynamic compared to previous GSG games. Ethoses are boring and might border on stereotypical/pop history, but traditions are where the new additions shine - for both roleplayers and minmaxers, there's a lot of stuff that's offered in finding interesting traditions to take advantage of. Languages are cool flavor as well, and reflect an aspect of history not often seen in strategy games.

Artifacts are perhaps the funnest part of the expansion to me. There's a lot of stuff that can happen to them behind the scenes, and they're more dynamic than their CK2 counterparts from both a gameplay perspective and how they're coded.

New events and decisions are also fun and nice for roleplay, and always welcome.

The big letdown for me is 3D courts which, while nice and definitely something the devs put a lot of time and love into, are underwhelming to me from a roleplay PoV - it's nice to see my characters, sure, but it feels like a side distraction that's disjointed from the game, and a glorified variation of the event window at times. Hopefully it will be improved on in the future.

[B][U]TLDR: All in all, a solid 8/10 DLC giving CK3 much needed life especially as a roleplayer, that expands flavor and gameplay for all parts of the map in a well-integrated manner, though not without its issues.[/U][/B] As to whether it's worth your money, I will hesitantly say yes, given how much content is offered, but I can absolutely understand if others see the price as too high.

CK3 Royal Court is a decent DLC, but not worth 30€. While nothing is wrong with any of the new court mechanics they also aren't that great that they earn the price tag. Let's go into detail.

Mechanically you pay for the ability to hybridise and diverge cultures and for the court system itself. I will mostly focus on the core of the DLC, the court, but acknowledge that the new culture system is great. 

Mechanics

The court system is a way for non-tribal emperors and kings to tunnel some of that high gold income in to other avenues like prestige or renown and to incur some other benefits. Each court has a court type, court language and amenities, four sliders with five steps each that influence your base glamour and each have different benefits. Glamour is basically your court level and the higher it is, the more benefits you unlock. Court types are influenced by your culture type and also confer various benefits depending on your glamour level. Court language also affects glamour and in the case of less powerful courts and kingdoms, it may behoof themselves in adopting the language of a more powerful court/country.

You can hold court and court event can happen. Holding court gives you three events which can give you some boons or drawbacks. Beyond that you can get petitioned by vassals or as a vassal petition yourself. Once a liege, a vassal can also present themselves to court, giving the liege renown and the vassal other bonuses as well.

Then there are the artifacts. You can commission artifacts, like tapestries, weapons or even books to wear or showcase in the court. These also give beneifts, mostly in the form of prestige and glamour. They generally have durability and you need to repaired them every so often. While the general artifact system is free, to use those showcased in the court you need the DLC.

Lastly, there are court positions, similar to the minor titles in CK2. These are free of charge and include your Court Physician and others. Having the Royal Court DLC enables certain special roles for kings and emperors, like a Seneshal that speeds up construction, or a food taster that can save your life at the risk of said taster being in cahoots with plotters. The largest issue with these is that there are a lot of positions and when you play at higher speeds position holders tend to die away. There is pop up, but depending on what you are doing it's a flash in the pan and you miss it.

Visuals

I'll be frank, the visuals of the DLC are lacking. The court culture types are nice, what exists is well modeled, however I question why the court rooms were included in the first place. What you see in the screenshots is what you get. Courtiers standing still, some in new idle poses, doing nothing, while your displayed artifacts are lovelessly being shown in the room. If they are in the capital your character sits on the large seat, while their (first) spouse sits left next to them. Women for some reason kneel im most cultures, looking like they are doing penance or going to confession, but this is not the primary issue. 

The primary issue is that there is no dynamism. Regardless of how much money you invest in the court, visually it stays the same. A court with no amenities looks the same as a court with every amenity under the sun. One amenity you can invest in is fashion, however beyond the numerical bonuses your court won't change their attire. This goes further. The game now forces you to open the court view to do certain events, however beyond involved characters being in certain idle animations there is no reason to open the window. The court itself doesn't even react to the scenes. The events are still dealt with in an event window and with a lot of events you will need to leave the view to find a title or character. Finally, there is the camera. It is locked to three different angles by default with events moving the camera around a bit, but nothing more.

After having looked at the different cultural courts and the initial court events there is nothing there to keep the player coming back. Even roleplayers will not be satisfied. Did their grand vision for the DLC not work out? I don't know, I can only critique something that is there.

Royal Edition vor 2 Jahren gekauft. 2 Jahre auf Royal Court gewartet. Muss sagen bin schwer enttäuscht. 

Pro
- Das neue Kultur System ist gut wenn auch absurd teuer ingame. 
- Der Hof ist angenehm gestaltet und erfüllt die neuen RPG Elemente sehr gut. 
- Boni von Artefakten sind gut umgesetzt und weder overpowered noch nutzlos. 
- Gerade im Kultur Bereich lässt sich nun auch eine eigene Kultur erstellen. Sehr gut. 

Cons
- Platzhalter und fehlende Übersetzung. 
- Das 3D Modell des Hofs ist zwar nett anzusehen aber weder eine zoom Funktion noch eine freie Kamera drücken die Stimmung extrem.
- Der Hof wird schnell repetitiv und langweilig. (Ständige Wiederholung der selben Abläufe) 
- Fehlende Mechaniken für den nett anzusehenden Hof lassen ihn schnell als nutzlos erscheinen lediglich die Boni sind gut. 
- Nur Könige oder Kaiser können einen aktiven Hof haben was irgendwie schlecht durchdacht wirkt und historisch völlig falsch ist. 
- Gerade Hof Mechaniken die mehr Spieltiefe bieten sucht man vergeblich. Sehr schade. 
- Es ist nicht wirklich ersichtlich wozu man diverse Hof Posten überhaupt benötigt oder ob man diese Posten besetzen sollte. Manche Posten wirken abseits von Kosten völlig nutzlos.  
- Gerade das Hof halten fühlt sich wie eine Dauerschleife von Events an die sich wiederholen und sehr schnell nerven anstatt dem Spieler mehr Spieltiefe zu geben. 

Alles in allem ist das keine 30€ Wert auch wenn ich weiß das da sehr viel Arbeit eingeflossen ist muss da mit Patches einfach mehr kommen und mehr Spieltiefe etabliert werden. Sollte sich das in Zukunft ändern werde ich auch die Rezension abändern und neu bewerten. 

Kaufempfehlung für 10 bis 15€ aber nicht darüber hinaus. Wer warten kann sollte das auch tun.

Paradox is frequently criticized for DLC being too expensive. I don't know what to say to that. I have 250+ hours played of Crusader Kings III. Much of that is from the baseline game. I didn't get Northern Lords until recently. With this expansion, I will likely play at least another 100 hours. So between $2.50 - $3.80 per hour played. Seems like a good value to me. 

I like this expansion because it adds a vital element to Crusader Kings: something to do other than paint the map. A big learning curve for new CK players is telling them it's ok if nothing happens for months, years, or decades. Sometimes your realm is doing ok and you're just riding the wave baby. With Royal Court, there's always something happening. It's not always important. Sometimes it's trivial and easy to ignore, but there's something going on.

I played Crusader Kings for the role playing element of the game and Royal Court adds to that. To me, this is an essential DLC. More than that, I want Paradox to make more DLC like this. I don't care to play as the tribal north, or in other regions with other stuff going on like India... well maybe idk I would I don't actually know... but if it were up to me I'd ask for a deeper more role-playing orientated improvement to the classic Europe game I already love. 

If I have a gripe with Royal Court, it's the repetition of certain scenarios. I've played it for maybe 8-12 hours and I keep getting new issues at court, so that's a sign there's a lot of content. However, I've had maybe 5 physicians steal bodies from the local cemetery. It's silly to see that same issue happen to every ruler, sometimes multiple times, with the same physician. I think they could add more of those.

I also think the user interface is a little clunky when considering other things within the Royal Court view. For example, i'll get a dilemma like Joe from Town A and Bill from Town B are disputing, but it's not easy for me to look at Towns A and B without completely Xing out of the entire interface. I don't exactly remember all the towns in my domain.

Otherwise, I wish there was a Royal Court interface for lower lords. If I'm a count or a duke, can I make asks of the King every now and then? Or can I hold my own court for lower-rank issues? That seems vital. The game should be fun at all stages, not just kings and emperors imo.

Anyway, I'm happy with it.

Is this some must have DLC that completely changes the game. No, and that is a good thing.

Lots of work went into this update to develop a bunch of features and those features had to be split between the free update and the paid DLC. All the most important stuff ended up in the free update which is part of the reason why many people say there isn't enough in the DLC. 

A big problem with CK2 was that all the features were in the DLC and that caused a huge mess when other later features had to work with any combination of DLC (or more likely just kind of didn't work without all the required DLC). Royal Court shows Paradox is doing better and actually prioritizing long term health and stability of the game over a quick buck. So, yes the changes in the DLC aren't necessary, but by buying it you are helping finance the free 1.5 patch which really is great.

But also, the actual DLC features are pretty cool.

Royal Court is a strong contender for the best expansion Paradox has ever released. The systems included in it are deep and engaging both for min-maxers and role-players. The new culture mechanics are the best system for representing cultural practices in any strategy game I've ever played. They allow for change, divergence, and hybridization to happen dynamically and to actually matter, with tangible benefits.

The Royal Court itself is the single most ambitious system Paradox has ever added to any game. While some lesser expansions of other titles can be accused of simply adding more modifiers, the court adds a stage for the drama of intrigue and diplomacy to play out in. Both literally, thanks to the physical representation of the space itself, and metaphorically insofar as it allows for a host of new interactions.

Finally, the artifact system is back from CK2 but is both far better balanced, better integrated with other systems (you can display artifacts in your court), and is just generally more interesting.

I think there are only two complaints I have so far: 1) the price is high, and 2) there are a few bugs.

I personally think the price is reasonable for what this is: a content rich and systemically sophisticated expansion. It is priced similarly to a full Civ V or VI expansion, and it feels like it adds as much or more to the game. That being said, for Paradox fans used to the level of content typically on offer in a new Paradox expansion, I think the price clearly is raising some red flags for people. Rest assured, this expansion is well worth the money.

As for the bugs, I suspect they will be ironed out fairly quickly. I haven't experienced anything game breaking, but something is wrong with the 3d models for characters (they all look a bit uncanny) and I've had some faction formation notifications coming up way too often (once every few days). These are ultimately annoying but don't ruin the experience. But I was hoping for a slightly smoother experience given how long this has been in development.

Overall, I highly recommend the Royal Court to anyone who enjoys CK3 and wants a deeper experience. I don't think you will be disappointed if you can get past the high price tag.

I rarely do reviews and when I do it's typically just a joke but this dlc is the only joke that needs to be seen. There were so many possibilities that could have come with this dlc but paradox has dropped the ball once again with an outrageous price for a VERY minor dlc. For $30 you get a 3D royal court to 'interact' with, an overhaul to cultures, more court positions, and a new artifact system. Now at first you might think you are getting what amounts to a complete overhaul considering this is $30. No, you will be getting a 3D courtroom (only if you are a kingdom or empire) that is extremely bland, an artifact system that is decent but arbitrary, and a nice culture rework. None of this is worth $30, nothing it adds is necessary to the game and most importantly, the focus of the dlc seemed to be building a 3D space that is quite honestly subpar. The events that happen in your court can range anywhere from decent to straight up bad. There will be times where somebody will come to your court, make their plea, and your choices are bad, really bad, and really really bad. The over 20 court positions have about 5 useful ones while the rest are fluff, your throne room is a bunch of 3D models standing completely still while occasionally looking around or swinging their arms with generic crowd noise in the background. When you hold court it is more or less the same as dilemmas the only difference is now your camera is in the throne room which again, doesn't move or have voice acting. Now credit where credit is due, the culture overhaul is very nice. There are around 6 ethos that set up the base of your culture and around 70 traditions to select from, it is a very nice system to set up some long term goals but there isn't much more to it. Overall I feel this dlc was an extreme overuse of resources for something that nobody was really asking for, a 3D court is nice but not at the cost of all substance in the dlc. $30 for what this dlc offers is ludicrous and really goes to show how paradox plans to put as little effort in with as large of a price-point that they can get away with.

Most of the features in Royal Court are nice but hot damn it is not worth $29.99. Game for the most part plays out the same except there are new mechanics connected to artifacts, culture, and the ability to have a 3D model of a throne room. The new culture mechanics are nice because they add way more flavor to how they work, instead of just forcing your entire region into your culture type, you can merge cultures together to get the best bonuses of said cultures. You can diverge away from your culture into a new one or reform your already existing one. The artifacts are a nice feature but CK2 had artifacts too, this isn't a new feature but a pre-existing one imported from CK2. The throne room feels like a gimmick. It honestly feels boring and if it wasn't for the artifact/furniture slots in the throne room to give bonuses, it feels like a massive waste of time. It adds flavor to the roleplay prespective but definitely doesnt add jack to the gameplay. If the dlc was worth $20 I would recommend it but $30 feels way too steep, even by Paradox's reputation. $30 for some new mechanics but I would have rather sunk the $30 into something else. Oh well.

So far I have completed one campaign and here are my thoughts thus far. I really like a lot of the mechanics added such as the new dynamic culture system and the 3D court. However, I have issues when it comes to content based around them. 

On Culture:
I played as Duke William in 1066 with the idea that blending cultures of Anglo-Saxon and Norman would be an interesting path. However I found that once winning the war and moving my capitol to London I got the old decision to form English Culture. From my basic understanding it would be disadvantageous to build cultural acceptance and form my own convergent culture with Anglo-Saxon based solely on the time required to do so. That leaves me with questions: 

Why does this event not require any cultural acceptance or any new requirements for that matter? 
Why does this event exist the way it does?
 Where is the roleplaying of moving your capital and on the same day form a new culture?

 It would be nice if this event instead of bypassing the new DLC it would embrace it and incorporate it. A suggestion I would have is to require the same level of cultural acceptance to take the decision. The one nice portion is that English Culture does get new Ethos in Longbows.

3D Courts:
I am sad to say that it is an absolute performance nightmare. I have a 2080s, but still would be maxing out my GPU and hitting temps of upwards of 80C whereas I would normally only get to ~60-70C pre-DLC. This point will probably be irrelevant as new patches come out improving performance (hopefully). 

Finding out that nomads/tribals don't have a court is just sad. I was hoping to play a Viking raider holding a court in a wooden hut surrounded by the great artifacts I have conquered from around the world (Speaking of artifacts they feel so small and insignificant in the court). 

Overall I think the DLC is average to good with lots of potential left on the table (for mods to pick up at this point). While I wish Steam would allow more nuanced scores rather than yes/no I feel like my voice will only be heard by developers if I highlight the aspects that were disappointing. 
6/10 - Wait for a sale/patch

Ich habe das DLC von einem Freund geschenkt bekommen, deswegen ist es für mich schwierig im Bereich des Preises vom DLC einzugehen. Jedoch kann ich auf jeden Fall sagen, dass das DLC seinen Preis nicht wert ist. Wenn man es für unter 20 Euro bekommt, ist das eine andere Geschichte.

Die Gameplay features finde ich aber schon echt cool gemacht. Wenn ich meinen Hof halte und ich auf die Probleme meiner Vasallen eingehe, sehe wie sie sich vor mich verbeugen, dann fühlt sich das schon wirklich immersive an. Finde aber ein wenig schade, dass die Artefakte teilweise sehr lame im Raum plaziert werden. Vor allem bei Waffen ist mir dies aufgefallen, da dann wenn man ein Schwert in seinem Hof ausstellt in der Mitte des Raumes einfach ein Waffenständer mit der Waffe drauf steh und das ist schon sehr unbefriedigend. Ich wünschte mir in dem Bereich, dass man Waffen an die Wand und dann vielleicht auch mehrere Waffen auf einem Slot hängen könnte.

Dann finde ich auch schade, dass man die Ausrüstung, welche man in seinem Inventar trägt nicht optisch an seinem Charakter sieht. Das einzige was sich hier ändert sind die Stats, was sehr enttäuschend ist. In Crusader Kings 2 hat man auch z.b. die eigenen Kronen gesehen, die man gebaut hat.

Sonst ist der Rest meiner Meinung nach echt gut gemacht. Es macht finde ich bisher Spaß ein Hof zu halten, es macht Spaß sich mit den Kulturen auseinanderzusetzen, vor allem wenn man ein Großreich hat mit vielen verschiedenen Kulturen und Sprachen. Diese Tiefe hat das Spiel nach 1 Jahr ohne zugefügtem Content auf jeden Fall gebraucht, deshalb lohn sich das DLC meiner Meinung nach auch.

Was ich auf jeden Fall noch erwähnen muss ist, dass endlich das Kriegssystem ein komplettes Rework braucht. CK hat bei weitem das schlechteste Kriegssystem von allen Paradoxspielen und dazu auch das langweiligste und das nervigste, da Kriege einfach nur sehr repetitiv und grindy sind. Bitte in den nächsten DLCs vor allem den Bereich beachten (Vor allem wenn man sieht, wie CK2 das in seinem letzten DLC gemacht hat)

[h1] Neither good nor bad [/h1]

There is no point in dwelling on the fact that this expansion is receiving mixed / negative attention.

The issue with this "expansion" is within these two points (in my opinion),

1. Its price - Its too expensive for what you get
2. Paradox's format for CK3 content, or lack of

Too call this an expansion is a bit of a joke, and for A$ 42.95 (or someone who has also purchased the season pass way back when) does leave a bitter taste in my mouth.

Yes the court system is an interesting and fun concept, but its fluff - it barely changes ANYTHING within the base game, my main concern is that if Paradox thinks that if this is appropriate for expanding CK3 then we they really need to have take a look at them selves and maybe find another job. The viking addon content was cheaper, and although also lacking was far more appropriately priced.

TLDR - This "expansion" should have been cheaper and after a year of waiting for a proper expansion we're left bitter like my lord is when my best friend cheats on my spouse for the 100th fucking time.

Crazy that this DLC is rated so low on Steam. Between the content in the free patch, and the content here, there's loads of additional content and mechanics in play on top of an already great game.

Yeah, $30 is high for a DLC, especially when a lot of the coolest content came via the free patch that went live alongside this. However, $40 was a steal for the base game before the free patch, and now I'd consider that ridiculously low for what you're getting. You can't criticize the devs for making a money grab here when they've already provided tons of content into the base game.

I'm not positive which of the features came free and which were part of this DLC, but the rework of cultures is absolutely game-changing. If you're a fan of putting yourself in weird situations (like taking a Viking clan to India), this addition makes that playthrough totally viable and very immersive. The artifacts mechanic is as much fun as it was in CK2, and the royal court feature is neat (in my opinion not as nice as artifacts or cultures, and still a tad buggy, but an interesting feature nonetheless). Certainly makes the mid- and late-game less tedious. 

If you've already been impressed with CK3, and dumped loads of hours into the game, I highly recommend buying this DLC because it will enable you to dump loads more time into it.

While I do agree with most of the reviews that it's a bit overpriced for what you get (I'd peg it as maybe worth $20), you also have to consider that this price tag helps pay for the culture update as well. With this in mind, I definitely love the update and the DLC, for one huge reason: it gives you things to do aside from go to war, and even discourages warring at some points via the cultural interactions. The royal court, though not the prettiest thing (I'd really appreciate a change to how the lighting works), gives another goal for the player to achieve, which means making the map bigger isn't really the main focus like it used to be, at least for me. Dealing with artifacts, trying to keep my income stable in large realms with large courts, commissioning every artifact and adventure I can, etc. really gave me a lot more to do. That, and the changes to culture that this DLC is paying for really improved the game in a big way.

First off I want to say good work paradox, despite some minor bugs I'm sure you will squash in the first update beyond this release, the dlc is everything I expected and more. This time however it was about 10x more fun with the introduction of my very own royal court! The Vikings are giving me an absolute battle for my life on my coastlines and the Karlings are swirling about Europe as usual. What makes this playthrough different with the dlc is my plans to adopt the things that make Norse so great into Frisian, and the roleplaying aspect of this run has been extremely fulfilling. So all in all, hats off fellas you did well.

P.s whichever employee you sat in front of the ruler creator for an eternity to modify literally every playable characters appearance deserves a freakin gold medal!

The content itself is basically fine, but it doesn’t solve much about the base game being very easy and extremely bereft of things to do. Also you should note that if you start as a Count or a Duke, the royal court feature only becomes available at the King or Emperor level. This means the vast majority of available characters to play won’t have any interaction with the DLC at all. And by the time you’ve hit king or Emperor you’ve basically already “won” so this becomes a victory lap simulator.
Unfortunately it’s just more bonus stacking. Everything you do merely adds more meaningless positive modifiers. 
Here’s an example: I’m playing Basil I in 867. I get a pop-up that someone has an inspiration to craft a piece of jewelry. A few events later and I have some kind of brooch. All that clicking and reading for…+.22 prestige per month? Nothing against the writing, which is clever, but the rewards just don’t seem that commensurate with the input requirements, which frequently involves years worth of income. The crafting events repeat as well in future projects (this was a problem in Holy Fury too), so I had to admonish my wife repeatedly to avoid her ruining my chances of a good item. Which I guess is exactly the sort of wacky meme stuff they’re setting out to do with this game now.
On a technical level the royal court itself is very laggy, any camera movement will result in choppiness and stuttering. The lighting is also bizarre, most of the characters look like they’re glowing in my gloomy castle. 
So no pop system, no economy, not much to do in the way of realm management, and the new culture system is part of the free update. $30 gets you something that makes the game run worse and will make you notice immediately how small the event pool still is. Unfortunately for me I bought the Royal Edition of CK3 so I’m stuck with this.

Is the content Royal Court adds to the game fine? Yes. I'd even go so far as to say some parts of the DLC are good. 

HOWEVER, I am not recommending Royal Court due to its outrageous price tag for the amount of content and too narrow a scope for its price tag. Why do only Emperors and Kings get a court? Dukes and Counts should also have courts (albeit a smaller scale appropriate to their station). There are too few court styles. Why, having just had a Northern Lords Norse flavour pack, is there not a Norse themed throne room for owners of that pack?

The amount of time and money spent on the 3D court, while cool, isn't worth it from a game play perspective. The throne room is static, nothing cool happens there with its static view and ridiculously easy grandeur level progression. When you hold a feast, there's not even a different view, signalling a grand event is happening at your court right now! Courtiers standing in random areas, limited atmosphere...all for what? $33 CAD and a couple small buffs via items? 

TLDR: Disappointing for how long development was and the price tag. Get on 50%+ off sale at best

It's true this expansion is pretty expensive (33.99 CAD for me) for what it is. However, I think some people are underselling it. It adds court mechanics, as well as artifacts you can commission, plunder, find, give, trade, show off in your court, wear... Plus the content in the accompanying free update which includes a pretty major rework of how culture works. It's nothing mindblowing, but they are features you're going to see and use regularly throughout the game, so I wouldn't say it's small stuff. It adds a lot of flavor and many mechanics as well. It's true the free update doesn't require paying for this DLC, but in reality the major free updates would never get made if they weren't offered alongside paid DLC.

Just like most Paradox DLC, this is kind of expensive and much better value on sale, but it supports ongoing development on a big game that's going to receive content for a good long while as long as DLC sells. It's up to you to decide whether you're willing to spend the money, and I more than understand that many people aren't willing to pay full price, but this isn't a bad DLC.

This DLC really changes impacts thesis of the game, and adds more than the typical paradox expansion (as per the new DLC policy, with cheap regional flavour packs and more expensive expansions).

If you play CK3 like you would EU4, with little regard for roleplay, then this DLC might not be for you. I mean, it does provide useful mechanics and whatnot, but I think it is mostly a boon for RP'ers. It really brings your court and realm to life, and you no longer view those things as just borders on a map. The cultural mechanics are also great if you're not so RP inclined (though they still cater to RP'ers), they're kind of like an improved religion mechanic, and add a lot more depth to the game. I can say the same for the new inventory system as well.

Is the price high? Yeah. Is it reasonable compared to other Paradox games, yeah I'd say so. It is substantially larger than most other expansions, and CK3 DLCs come out much more infrequently (this has been in the works for what, 1.5 years?). Now, is Paradox's DLC policy in general unreasonable? Maybe, I'm not sure, but I don't blame you if you think it is. I just don't agree with the reviews which are comparing this expansion's price to the expansion price pertaining to titles from games like EU4 or HOI4. 

Overall, if you're comfortable spending a bit more than usual, this DLC is a huge step up as far as Paradox and CK games go, and I recommend it wholeheartedly, especially for RP'ers.

Quick Review - A good solid update to the game. Slow development to get there though. Worth getting despite the high price.

Longer Review -

Positives:
Better cultural depictions,
Fleshes out diplomacy more with new modifiers and negatives,
Cultures now have more depth to them and changing them is possible, allowing for more customized gameplay,
Vassalizing foreign culture and religion rulers is now viable,
Court artifacts and grandeur allow for easier control of vassals and make playing a King or Emperor feel better than a Duke,
New Councilor interactions and new court roles!,
Since diplomatic rule is now possible, it feels like a new side to the game beyond being a simple warlord,

Neutrals:
Running the court can feel like a chore sometimes but gives a deeper sense of rulership beyond rebellions, vassal management and wars,
Peacetime is more interesting with court stuff occupying your time but it takes more time and isnt what some people like,

Negatives:
Not completely balanced yet, gold income hasnt changed but courts require more gold upkeep,
Some areas of the map are more interesting than others still,
Long development time means people are angry with the developer,
No tribal royal courts which is really inaccurate and you feel the absence of them,
The developer kill off other games to make this including Imperator may it RIP!

TL;DR: This expansion adds new systems and mechanics that improve role-playing and make managing a large empire significantly more complex and interesting. Recommended for roleplayers and for experienced players looking for replay value.

Overall, this expansion succeeds in making prestige and gold more valuable and useful than in the base game, tying the former into the new grandeur system and using the latter to fund inspirations and pay for court expenditures. Growing your court alongside your empire will be much more engaging, and the new cultural mechanics make managing a large empire much more interesting and dynamic. Highly recommended for anyone looking for more mechanics to consider, deeper roleplaying, or more interesting large-domain management.

The Throne Room:
-Represents the characters and court in a grounded, physical way unlike anything in previous paradox games. The individual interactions displayed here greatly improve immersion and the role-playing of interacting with your vassals.
-Seeing your character in a 3D space, surrounded by symbols of your wealth and power, shifts the feeling of the game from playing as a nation and map-painting like many other paradox games and reinforces the unique status of CK3 as a medieval roleplaying experience.
-Holding court adds context to many of the events you might see in the base game, while adding many, many more events for a player to experience. After seeing most of the events the base game has to offer, these new interactions significantly improve replayability.
-Court positions make paying attention to the skills of guests more important, and tie together with plots, warfare, and court mechanics well.

Cultural mechanics:
-Cultures finally have mechanics for dynamic growth and emergence, making culture as important and flexible as the base game's religion system
-Language and cultural heritage add depth to cultural differences. These build on the existing culture group system to create a much more dynamic system for the internal conflicts of large, multicultural empires.
-When growing a small duchy to a powerful empire, you now have the option to facilitate the growth and divergence of your culture, rather than painting the map with a single culture (looking at you, Andalusian)
-Cultural uprisings now have more context and feel like a reactive part of your interactions with your subjects, rather than just a mob of peasants

Artifacts and Equipment:
-The least interesting part of the update, somewhat awkward, but ties in well to the court system. Overall an improvement from CK2's implementation, but barely.
-Event chains from adventurers and craftsmen are engaging and interesting, and can spice up an uneventful year
-Legendary weapons and objects are fun, but honestly the most engaging use of the system is acquiring a crown, regalia, a throne, and other items when first growing your court

While this DLC is more expensive than expansions for older games by this developer, I can see its mechanics remedying many of the frustrations I had with the game and easily doubling the time I will put into the game. While maybe not for everyone, it's an easy purchase for me and sets a new standard for DLC releases by paradox.

And why does my famed throne look the exact same as the default throne? And why does no one move, or speak, or interact with each other in the throne room? Why is my nephew standing in the corner clapping for six minutes straight during court hearings? Why don't I have a court free cam? Why are all of the courts small, rectangular rooms? Why is there absolutely no visual difference between the highest court expenses and the lowest? Why is every event about leaky walls and freeloaders instead of court intrigue or festivities? Why is this so *half baked*? Seriously, is it too much to ask that the royal courts look *at all* alive? The culture system is great, but that's not even part of the DLC. This entire thing screams "good 'nuff". For a year of development and $30, I expected much, much more.

As someone who paid for the Royal Edition when the game came out, I've got to say that this expansion is amazing and has changed the way that I view this game. Being able to see my ruler and all the artifacts his dynasty has collected throughout the generations is amazing. 

Also, the changes the expansion makes to culture, allowing you to diverge and create hybrid cultures is likely to drastically change the way you play the game.

I get that people are mad about the price. 30 bucks is a lot, but if you're a big fan of crusader kings, I would recommend checking this out. If you're tight on cash, or only play CK3 every now and then, try waiting for a sale. 

Personally, I really like the direction Paradox is taking CK3. The potential for storytelling seems so much greater with this expansion.

This expansion is GOOD. The new systems are completely changing the way the a playthrough unfolds, and pretty much all for the better. Sure, there are a few interface annoyances, but they are minor compared to the sheer delight of seeing what new weird items your dynasty picks up on its journey through the centuries.
The culture rework is massive, and totally awesome, and I encourage people to think of it as part of the expansion even though it is free. The devs clearly had to make this feature free because it is so deeply embedded in the game systems that it can't be enabled just for the expansion and turned off for the base game. 
The decisions you make regarding the evolution of your culture are extremely rich in terms of both role-playing AND strategy, and I just love it. My African king sails up the coast and siezes Cordoba - prior to the rework this would have been purely for the mechanics of getting the special building and switching to a more advanced culture so I could feudalise. After the rework? Suddenly I don't want to change culture; sure they have more technology, but their traditions are crap (hit an run tacticians, lolwut?), so instead I am putting my steward to work trying to convince the Cordobans that my people are not that bad and we should merge our ways together. It's still a painfully slow process, so I try and speed it up by conquering some more Andalusian lands, which helps because our realms are intermingling more (even if in the short term the Andalusians are mad at me for declaring war on their territory). Eventually I create the new 'Cordoban' culture, gaining the technological knowledge of the Andalusians, the much cooler traditions of the Malinke (sorcerous metalurgy, yes please!), and teaching my people back home how to speak the much-more-useful Arabic language. And this is just round one of the story of my realm's evolving culture. Utter, freaking, briliant.
Think of this expansion as the next chapter in the evolution of the game, and if you buy it (you should) think of yourself as supporting the continued development of the game as a whole. I have many hours in this game BEFORE the expansion, and the total reimagining of so much of the game means I will be getting many hundreds more.
It's a little expensive but a great addition to the game.

I really hope the devs re-evaluate this, because after a few more expansions the game could easily turn into endless pop-ups a la EU4. 


I am, on the other hand, very pleased with how it ties together with Northern Lords. PDX has historically avoided building on their DLCs but changed this policy with Stellaris, and I am hopeful that they will preserve this change for CK3.

From what I have tested with the DLC so far, I have to say it's great. Tons of new events, items and actual things to do other than war! The new events and systems really flesh out the game more for what it is supposed to be, a character / dynasty simulator. The people who are only interested in war might not care as much about Royal Court for it but all of the new things to do really make the game more interesting. You know how it is, different strokes for different folks. 

Even more exiting is how good a system like this will be for modding, can't wait to see what the big fantasy mods can do with all of this when they are finally released. 

For those of us that play CK games as more than a map painting game, this is a great DLC that really makes the game feel more alive and interesting. If all you care about is warfare then it's something you can skip, there are weapons and other items that help in war, give you more stats and bonuses but I don't think it's worth buying the DLC for that alone. I usually like to play as a smaller lord but now I really enjoy being a King and managing my court. I really recommend Royal court for those of you who are interested in events, role playing and what not. 

As for pricing, I don't buy Paradox DLC at full price, sorry but I'm poor and can't afford it. They always give us a free patch that add some new things and improvements and I don't mind waiting for a good deal more in my price range. Always wait for a sale unless money is not an issue for you in my opinion, considering I bought the royal addition of the game on sale for like $45 or less (Paradox and others sell keys off steam for a little less that you can then use on steam. Check the safe/trusted sites for sales the same time you see a steam sale. Make sure you look into the site to make sure it's legit, not all key websites are safe or are even allowed to sell the keys they have.), and I'm happy with what I paid for. 

We knew the price of the major DLC for CK3 will be $30, we where told this before the game came out. They spent over a year on this and I think it's fair, just wait for a sale in the future if you are on the fence about pricing. Over time, as with all Paradox games you will be able to get DLC for 75% off if not higher at times, it's just a matter of waiting.

Paradox ogrywal Royal Court na streamach juz dwa tygodnie przed premiera. Mieli sporo czasu na polerowanie i testowanie, wiec nie spodziewam sie jakis krytycznych bugów - sam zadnych nie doswiadczylem. Jednak wiadomo - co innego setka testerów a co innego milion graczy i róznych konfiguracji...

Poszukiwanie i pozyskiwanie (wszelkimi mozliwymi sposobami) wybitnych osobistosci jest teraz kluczowe. Na tym koncentruje sie dodatek i moim zdaniem wyszlo to grze na dobre.

Both an in game and real world moneysink. 

The content in this DLC is good and the features make the game notably more immersive. But it's massively overpriced. 

What you get: 
-The courtroom (where you can look at yourself and your court members as 3D models) + some repeatable events, both as vassal and liege
-The Grandeur mechanic (i.e., how extravagant your court is), which is an extensive moneysink and gives various bonuses the higher you get it
-Minor court positions, again, moneysink with minor bonuses for maintaining them
-Court artefacts (to exhibit in your throne room for bonuses) and personal artefacts (to put in your newly introduced equipment inventory for bonuses) and a couple of different ways of getting them. 

And that's about it. The content is decent but it's nowhere near an amount that would justify charging half the price of a newly released full price game for it. 

Honestly, I was still going to recommend it for those starved for new CK3 content, but the update also introduced a number of bugs (e.g. train commander councilor task not working anymore). Just not really acceptable in its current state. Wait a bit and ideally buy it on sale.

I never wished for a more customizable culture when I was playing CK2, and never wished the same while playing CK3 too.

Developers of this game acts like Crusader Kings games are role playing games with strategic elements. But they aren't. They the exact reverse of it. The main thing that you did on CK2 was managing your realm. I fear that it isn't going to be like that anymore in the future of Crusader Kings series.

IT COSTS TOO MUCH

CULTURES
The culture rework is nice: you can create new cultures, combine two into one, and create your regional culture out of already existing one - I like these changes
Each culture has now few traditions, the cultures got divided into groups - for example, Polish, Polabian and Pomeranian are in the Lechitic group. You can now learn other languages.

ARTIFACTS
Now you can hire a person to create an artifact for you - a melee weapon, a chestplate, a crown and many other things.
Or you can just steal them during a war with your neighbour. I've got an artifact that gives me -100% fertility :P
Many of these artifacts increase dynasty renown, prestige, fertility, prowess and other traits.

THE THRONE ROOM/COURT
For me it is a boring, laggy, unnecessary addition - they could've sold it separately... 
The court is only available to emperors or kings, AND you can not be a tribal government :(
You can see people there but they just stand and do nothing more.

ADVISORS
Now you can hire more advisors - the food taster, the jester, the court doctor, bodyguards, the language tutor etc.
It's a pretty cool addition because they are pretty cheap - 0,02 to 0,15 ducats monthly. They provide nice bonuses :)

However, the price for this DLC is too big - it should cost 15$ max. The DLC was overhyped. I would buy it without the court addition if it costed less.

Every negative review is talking the price. Yes, it is steep. That doesn't mean this is a bad DLC, which can give that impression given the bevy of negative reviews that are *only* about the price. Folks get angry, demand a refund, and then come to this page to lambaste, all the while ignoring the DLC content. Don't let this ridiculous outrage influence your purchasing decisions. If you want this at full price and its features are worth it to you, buy it - otherwise, wait for a sale and enjoy it at a price that makes sense to you. I personally didn't feel like waiting 6 months to get this for $15 less or like I needed to complain about the price tag that *I agreed to pay based on the features they were very transparent would be in this DLC*. But maybe that's just me.

The DLC adds much needed flavor to this game, as well as a reason to actually play a feudal character. Creates an actual court system, adds cultural richness and depth, re-works a lot of the previously static and by-and-large uncontrollable features (cultural dynamics, language, court events, tutoring, assassination) and introduces a very real concept in the medieval world: grandeur. I'm actually having *fun* playing as Alfred of Wessex, for example. The stuff added in this DLC is cool and good, don't let sticker-shocked negative reviews detract from that.

An excellent DLC that enhances the game-play and adds more layers to what is already a fantastic game. It adds several layers that one may not realise on the surface. A lot of work and effort has gone into producing this additional content. I must congratulate the game development team for all their efforts in putting together the Royal Court and game update that was released at the same time as this DLC. It is much appreciated. Whilst there are still a lot that can be added to the game, it was a good place to start after the Northern Lords flavour pack. In my view, Royal Court is well worth the full price for such a feature-rich DLC. 

The enhanced culture system is great as it introduces a dynamic system that allows you to evolve your culture and this makes the game even more enjoyable to play. It also adds novel ways to gain new traditions and makes the game an even better story-telling experience. Showing off your artifacts, holding court and the extra court positions are wonderful additions as well. I can highly-recommend this DLC.

This is one of the few times I have felt compelled to write a review because of the review climate on the page. People are being absolutely ridiculous about this DLC, and I don't think they have any idea how precarious PDX is right now, and how important this expansion was.

I would like to say, my review is that this is a very good expansion. To paraphrase something ProudBavarian said about the expansion, it can completely change the way you interact with the game and leans heavily into roleplaying which is the thing I most appreciate about CK3 as a title in particular. I saw a review that said it was $30 for "minor mechanics" and that is completely unfair-- adding a 3D space with positioned characters to a game where usually you spend 90% of the time staring at a map is a massive departure from form and a very ambitious addition to the game. 

Would it be cool if there were Tribal Courts, or lower level Duke and Count courts? Of course, but there is every expectation that such a thing will be added later, perhaps even in a free update. How could we expect that? By looking at the free culture features which came along with this update. The new culture system is a massive upgrade to the former system, as large in scope as the entire religion system was at release, and everyone got it for free. The one best way to make sure you never get Tribal or Ducal courts is to tell people not to buy this DLC, and not to buy the next flavor pack.

I think if you play CK3 to tell stories and revel in the drama that comes with building your legacy, this expansion is an absolute must-have. If the next expansion is as bold and ambitious as this one, I will be overjoyed.

Mechanically, I am satisfied with the content. The artifact and the court systems, as well as the improved cultures, add much needed depth to the otherwise bland base game. The culture aspect is especially enjoyable with its wide variety of choices as well as providing an outlet for prestige that previously tended to build-up when playing feudal rulers. What is disappointing is the implementation of the court mechanic for feudal governments only. While "tribal" governments may not have historically held court in the same way it is portrayed in this DLC, there are plenty of historic analogues that could utilize this mechanic existing within what is CK3's current gross over-generalization of tribal/nomadic peoples in game. This fact is ironically contrasted with Paradox's own sponsored YouTube content leading up to the DLC's release, specifically those videos exploring historical Mongol court protocol. I hope to see this remedied in the future.

Additionally, the use of 3D models in Royal Court is a departure from previous content and the developer's aims feel misguided when considering what the majority of the community is looking to get out of this game. It seems likely that this decision soaked up much development resources leading to the aforementioned lack-luster and even partially implemented court mechanic., This is not to mention the the price tag, which is at least twice what you should be paying for DLC. If you'd like to play Royal Court, I would recommend waiting for a sale.

EDIT: Upon playing the DLC further, it seems like the artifact and, primarily, court interactions are somewhat superficial. Regardless, I am still pleased with the culture systems but at this point it may as well have been one of the smaller $5 content packs.

A bit overpriced, I agree, but I think its price is mostly justified: this expansion brings a whole new dimension to the game and connects to the other systems in quite an organic way, vastly improving its immersion aspect. While I would have appreciated a bit more in terms of contents, especially in terms of courts themes (only 4 at launch) and a visual feedback of amenities improvements, courts appear to be a solid foundations for modding and (alas) future DLCs.

Contra:

Conclusion:
- Nice new game mechanics and conent
- not ready, the DLC is still work in probress

i had an event where 'an ally gets usurped by a rival and then you can invite that ally to serve in your court with a nickname "footstool" ' happened 3 times in a row... out of 4 times i held court... and the last time it happened, it was my wife's holding that got usurped by our infant son. As "amusing" as it was, it broke what little immersion i had. After that i turned the game off, it is clear that nobody ever tested this garbage. This event should be programmed as an extremely rare, not happen almost every single time you utilize the game's key mechanic. Also the way its implemented doesnt make any sense, it shouldnt be coded this way, when it just selects random charaters to usurp holdings, it makes zero sense for holdings of the queen to be usurped by a baby. One very impatient baby, considering it was going to inherent them anyway.

EDIT: After glossing over other reviews, I've decided to chime in with my opinion about the price matter and overall quality of this DLC. 
Look guys, when they're selling you the DLC that breaks graphics and adds a ton of bugs which they never bothered to test over a year while this "expansion" was in development, at this point you're basically doing their job for them and testing their product. So no, you shouldnt pay $30 for an opportunity to participate in the beta-test. They're the ones who should pay you. 

Also, what ppl in the positive reviews are calling "new mechanics" are really just new buttons you can press to get flat modifiers, like pay 100 gold to the artisan - get a legendary sword that adds 1 prowess (which is like nothing). Also you get to create hybrid-cultures, hooray! Its exactly like creating religions in the base game, only duller. Wow, so much innovation, this gameplay is fire.

Conclusion: do not buy, not even on sale. Even if they fix all the bugs, which they wont, its still a bad dlc that doesnt really add anything new to the game. Promo screenshots were just lie, you never have interesting feasts in your court or anything like that.

After all, why did people like previous installments of this franchize? Because of the storytelling and because of the interesting events. In this game you see basically all the events this game has in the first 3 hours you play, so it was obvious, for me anyway, that the first DLC desperately needed to add some storytelling content. But all you really get is a hall with broken lighting and frozen statues with ugly facial features, because this DLC also decided to downgrade the graphics, on top of adding a bunch of bugs. It doesnt add what it needed to add for this game, game is still just a boring map painting simulator. What little events it has are at best poorly thought out and at worst are immersion-breaking. Nothing worse that a game can be other than being boring.

dear paradox, if you want your games better received: hire new writers and hire at least some testers, i know you think you got an army of unpaid shills to do that, but actually you do pay, not with money, but with your reputation. Also get a new product manager, from the premise to execution this DLC screams of the lack of coherent vision of what this game wants to be. I am sorry to say this, but youre not a small family company anymore.

I feel that what you get for 30 euros is very lacking, but the free update makes up for it in a big way. You know how Paradox said they were focusing on larger DLCs for CK3, so we'd excuse the long wait time and higher price? This feels very much like a normal $20 DLC that should have come out 3 months ago. Of the 1.5.0 features, I was more excited for the free customizable banners than any paid feature. In addition, the lack of free camera in the court, and limiting it to kings and emperors were two of the first things I changed with mods. The base game is fantastic and made even better with the free features in 1.5.0, and this DLC is a step down by comparison.

That being said, Royal Court marks a decisive turn away from min-maxing and towards immersive role-play, and this is the first time I've ever lost track of time playing CK3. In a way, this DLC is almost necessary towards this role-play vision, even if the features are rather limited. I highly encourage Paradox to continue down this path with future expansions.

Overall I'd highly suggest waiting for a $10-$15 sale a year or two from now. However I firmly believe that you should still plan on getting it as some point if you like the role-playing side of CK3. One could reasonably argue that this DLC is greater than the sum of its parts for what it does to immersion and role-play.
